( 250 ) Let me celebrate in good fortune the Dionysia here in the countryside without enemy attack , and bless my libations for a thirty-year peace ! Now , daughter , hold that basket up nicely , my pretty , and make sure you put on a face as if you \u2019ve just eaten bitter herbs ! How happy the man ( 255 ) who \u2019ll take you as his wife and make little weasels with you that fart just as good as you do in the morning ! Step forward now , and keep a sharp lookout in the crowd that someone does n\u2019t pinch your jewelry while you \u2019re not looking ! Xanthias , the phallus has to be kept erect ( 260 ) behind the basket-girl ! I \u2019ll bring up the rear and strike up the phallus song . And you , wife , watch me from the roof ! Forward march !

#Text=Phales , Bakkhos \u2019 friend , fellow comast , nightwanderer , ( 265 ) adulterer , pederast , I greet you for the first time in five years , happy now that I \u2019ve come back to my deme and made my own personal peace-agreement , freed from troubles , wars , and warmongers like Lamakhos . For it \u2019s much nicer by far , o Phales , Phales , to snatch Strymodoros \u2019 pretty Thracian virgin from the stony ground , grab her by her hips , lift her up , ( 275 ) then throw her down and ream her good and proper , o Phales , Phales ! If you want to get drunk with us , tomorrow first thing at dawn you \u2019ll be hungover and slurping down a bowl of peace , and the shield will be hung up in the chimney .

#Text=Dikaiopolis brings the procession into formation by means of a speech act : his daughter functions as kan\u00EAphoros , who is responsible for the \u1F00\u03C0\u03B1\u03C1\u03C7\u03AE ; she is followed by the slave Xanthias as phallophoros ; Dikaiopolis , following behind as symbol of comic inversion and distortion , fulfills as solo-singer the role of a citizen chorus , while at the same time acting as \u1F10\u03BE\u03AC\u03C1\u03C7\u03C9\u03BD or \u03BA\u03BF\u03C1\u03C5\u03C6\u03B1\u1FD6\u03BF\u03C2 of the mini-procession . After a brief prayer ( 247ff . ) , he begins the actual song , all on his own instead of with a chorus , while the role of the crowd participating in the ritual is assumed by his wife on the roof . [ 132 ] The ritual of the procession , which is based on the participation of the crowd and on the presence of a comastic choral dance group , which this woman represents , is kept to the bare minimum of performers and participants . From the perspective of the plot we have here imitation and reworking of a familiar ritual , with ritual happening within ritual , theater within theater , but without any real reenactment ( \u03BC\u03AF\u03BC\u03B7\u03C3\u03B9\u03C2 ) as in the other songs .

#Text=As in most of the choral utterances in comedy , here too in this pseudo-choral passage there is no commentary or narrative , but only a ritual being staged that proceeds as a speech act . Action is completed by utterance . Self-reference also has the function of self-ostentation . In contrast to the songs in Semos , which are given a comprehensive performative context , here the performance of this kind of song is set as a whole into the scene .

#Text=It is only in the commands and announcements that come before the song that we get the actual sense of the procession , which would otherwise be lost if only a brief song without these attachments were presented here . It is in the orders of the leader and producer that the formation of the mini-group and its connection with sacrificial ritual is brought about ; in the case of the texts in Semos , much of the ritual background has to be surmised because the compiler of the passage did not consider that every detail was worthy of transmission . In this performance it is the other way round : there is no reference to the \u1F44\u03C8\u03B9\u03C2 , since this is perfectly plain to the spectator . One cannot , then , entirely exclude the possibility that Dikaiopolis and his assistants wore a particular type of costume or equally that the carrier of the phallus had makeup on his face . The procession derives its particular comic and parodic nature in particular from the sexual remarks directed at the daughter , who leads the parade as bearer of the sacrificial basket . She is a potential victim of the phallus that walks erect behind her . The presence of the girl introduces the suggestion of a sacred marriage into the proceedings .

#Text=The iambic vulgarity is in many respects reminiscent of the brief sacrificial procession in the Thesmophoriazusae ( 282\u2013291 ) that the relative of Euripides stages in order to gain access to the Thesmophorion . There , too , the path to the Other is connected by means of sacrifice and pomp\u00EA with ribald wishes for fertility for the little daughter ( cf. Thesmophoriazusae 289\u2013291 with Acharnians 254\u2013258) . [ 133 ] In a further command Dikaiopolis positions Xanthias as phallophoros behind the virgin . The phallus has to be carried erect behind the maiden . This happens as soon as the procession gets underway . This sexual juxtaposition induces further laughter . Dikaiopolis himself takes up a position at the end of the procession . Using the performative future in the \u201C I \u201D form , Dikaiopolis announces the presentation of his song ( \u1F84\u03C3\u03BF\u03BC\u03B1\u03B9 \u03C4\u1F78 \u03C6\u03B1\u03BB\u03BB\u03B9\u03BA\u03CC\u03BD , 261 ) and sends his wife to her post as internal observer . Immediately after the announcement of the performance and the order to proceed ( \u03C0\u03C1\u03CC\u03B2\u03B1 , 262 ) , the procession gets under way to the accompaniment of the song struck up by Dikaiopolis . Actual cult song and improvisation with attacks on individuals are here fused together . The variation between \u201C I \u201D and \u201C we \u201D is striking . The emphatic \u201C I \u201D expresses the isolation of the hero , while the \u201C we \u201D forms and the command for silence and attention in the second-person plural ( \u03B5\u1F50\u03C6\u03B7\u03BC\u03B5\u1FD6\u03C4\u03B5 , \u03B5\u1F50\u03C6\u03B7\u03BC\u03B5\u1FD6\u03C4\u03B5 , 241 ) involve not only the fellow performers from his household , but also the audience as participants in cult and spectacle . [ 134 ] This involvement is also especially brought about by laughter . Dikaiopolis becomes a kind of prayer-leader , and with his refrain-like cry of \u201C O Phales , Phales ! \u201D the audience \u2019s imagination may be stirred and instead of spectators become in fact fellow players in a communal \u201C we , \u201D gradually declaring themselves in agreement with Dikaiopolis \u2019 action .

#Text=The ritual staged here reflects polis ritual and as with the two songs transmitted in Semos , reworks basic elements\u2014such as the comastic ( Ach arnians 264\u2013265 , 277\u2013279 ) , the ribald and erotic ( 254\u2013260 , 265 , 271\u2013275 , 277\u2013278 ) , aiskhrologia and personal ridicule of Lamakhos and Strymodoros ( 270 , 273 ) , sacrifice together with pleasure in eating and drinking , the symposion ( 277 ) , and musical performance [ 135 ] \u2014 into something new . All the rites and pleasures mentioned are fused into the worship of peace ( 251 , 268\u2013270 , 278\u2013279 ) and simultaneously refer to the festival currently taking place . [ 136 ] For these are the elements not only of this small \u03C6\u03B1\u03BB\u03BB\u03B9\u03BA\u03CC\u03BD , but also of Old Comedy as a whole . Despite being reduced to a monody , the scene thereby becomes a kind of proto-comedy of a sort that could have arisen at the festival of the rural Dionysia . [ 137 ]

#Text=Redundancy , repetition , simple rhythm , and the blending of the different horizons and ritual aspects characterize this song too as a ritual text . [ 138 ] The monodic form of performance is a striking expression of the lack of pragmatic reality in the imitation of a choral dance song . It is particularly noteworthy that choral self-representation and performative speech acts concerning the performers \u2019 own singing and dancing are largely absent in the actual Phales song and are shifted to the speech of preparation . Here there is no chorus that talks with and about itself ; rather , Dikaiopolis exercizes an exclusive right to speech in the performative portion as well . [ 139 ] The chorus is reserved for the role of the Acharnian charcoal burners , who are opposed to this antisocial behavior by Dikaiopolis and thus attack the individual , after their attention is drawn to him by his sacred activity .

#Text=The symbolic meaning of aggressive phallic demonstration and iambic ridicule in the k\u00F4mos , [ 140 ] namely the dissolution of the normal order of things , the separation of the everyday world from the world of the festival , and the marking of the liminal , all serve the plot and the external cultic connection . And even in an instance like this of monodic reworking the ritual choral dimension is apparent . The monodic reactualization of a choral song serves to remind the audience of the actual choral performance of this procession , especially since Aristophanes shapes the scene in such a way that it is played \u03B5\u1F30\u03C2 \u03C4\u1F78 \u03B8\u03AD\u03B1\u03C4\u03C1\u03BF\u03BD and that the audience , the whole citizenry , characterized as a great \u201C throng \u201D ( \u1F44\u03C7\u03BB\u03BF\u03C2 ; see 257 ) , together with the female spectator in the plot , thereby in fact becomes an active participant in a ritual familiar to it , even though it has been transformed for the comic plot . [ 141 ] In the activated imagination of the audience even this adjusted scene becomes an act of worship and Dionysus takes pleasure in the comedy , even among this kind of this confusion , a ritual within a ritual . [ 142 ]

#Text=In contrast to the uncontaminated \u03C6\u03B1\u03BB\u03BB\u03B9\u03BA\u03AC in Semos , then , this song is situated in the context of a plot and in its particular form concentrates distinctive Leitmotive in the Acharnians . Nevertheless , this text also is clearly located between ritual and theater : for apart from its dramatic function , which until now has been almost entirely overlooked in this scene , the passage also has a particular effect by itself alone as a reenactment of a cultic action .

#Text=Within the drama this song as independent episode , which reflects the privileging of paradigmatic over syntagmatic action that is characteristic of comedy , evokes the laughter necessary for its success by concentrating together the elements of ridicule , the sacred , and ribald sexuality . [ 143 ] Naturally Dikaiopolis did not really improvise this song ; yet around this cultic shout the author composes this simple form with fixed ritual elements corresponding to the improvised models based on orality . At the same time , the song is a staging of an independent ritual , though with features clearly exaggerated for comic purposes . Both in the fragments of Semos and in Aristophanes the phallus song is set in the public space of the theater ; in both cases cult becomes spectacle . To draw a precise distinction between art of an entertaining nature and ritual presentation is obviously impossible . Both have in common their characteristic theatricality . With the songs of the Ithyphalloi and Phallophoroi the theater , dedicated to the god , serves as a place for carrying out a cultic action . The Greek theater was never understood as a purely profane meeting place for cultural amusement , but as a gathering place for the polis under the auspices of the god and in connection with certain distinct ritual practices .

#Text=In Aristophanes , by contrast , the ritual of the everyday world , which serves as a differentiation between what precedes and the actual dramatic ag\u00F4n , is embedded in the spectacle of a comedy . The players here occupy , like the comic chorus , a particular middle position between a role that is connected with the plot and a function as actual performers in a ritual context . It becomes more and more clear in the scholarship on Aristophanes that his plays as a whole are dependent on ritual models , that is to say , on patterns derived from the actual cycle of festivals of the polis . The author integrates these varied ritual subtexts in an intertextual process into a new dramatic text . The scene-like technique of interlacement allows one to see behind the lack of unified plot the independent character of a choral song or cultic performance .

#Text=A spectacle of this sort presented before the public is thus both cult and theater . It is difficult in the case of this passage of Aristophanes to determine definitively in terms of Quellenforschung what the antecedents and imitators are . As with many choral passages , in particular odes and hymns , one ought not treat even Aristophanes \u2019 Phales hymn either as a reflex or as a parody , [ 144 ] at least not in the traditional and usual sense of the word , but rather as an authentic product of an artist composing within a living choral culture . In a society that is based on orality and that thinks and acts using fixed forms of myth and ritual , a stable model that is firmly established as a genre is reactualized in a performance for a particular occasion . [ 145 ] In the marked form of the speech act the spectacle is staged , that is to say , translated into pure action : neither commentary , narration , nor reflection appear . [ 146 ] In the case of the phallic songs one can identify the occasion as a festival for Dionysus and the model as a k\u00F4mos . In the texts , accordingly , using a manner peculiar to ritual , the ideas of wine , sacrifice , ribald and aggressive sexuality , and ridicule are fused with the self-referential emphasis of the performative act . [ 147 ]

Graf 1998 ; for tragedy see now Easterling 1997 , Seaford 2005 , and Sourvinou-Inwood 2005 ; against the communis opinio of a connection with Dionysiac ritual see now the vehement attacks of Scullion 2002 ( for tragedy ) and of Stark 2004:11\u2013102 , especially 97\u2013102 , 322 ( for Old Comedy) . Stark \u2019s sociohistorical approach is highly reductive and questionable , as she does not refer to Greek culture in all its aspects . On the complex program of the City Dionysia , cf. Pickard-Cambridge 1968:57\u2013125 , Goldhill 1987 , Connor 1989 , and Cole 1993 , especially 25\u201329 ; cf. also the latest attempt at reconstruction in Sourvinou-Inwood 1994 and now in detail Sourvinou-Inwood 2003:67\u2013200 . On the comic play as continuum , see also Sfyroeras 1992 , especially 3\u20138 .

#Text=[ back ] 2 . On choral dance as ritual action par excellence see Burkert 1985:102 : \u201C Rhythmically repeated movement , directed to no end and performed together as a group , is , as it were , ritual crystallized in its purest form . \u201D
#Text=[ back ] 3 . Cf . the remark of des Bouvrie 1990:89\u201392 on Greek theater as an oral medium .

#Text=[ back ] 4 . On ritual theatricality , see also Lanza 1983 , especially 107\u2013108 and 115\u2013116 . Lanza sees ritual as incorporated into the theater in the form of lament , laughter , and fear . He especially recognizes the relationship of spectacle and ritual . Cf . especially 107 : \u201C Ogni rito \u00E8 dunque in qualche modo spettacolo . Si potrebbe allora distinguere tra rito , nel quale chi si esibisce e chi osserva non sono distinti , e spettacolo vero e proprio , nel quale attori e spettatori sono istituzionalmente separati . Ma anche questa distinzione \u00E8 difficile : i confini appaiono labili : la stessa messa , per rifarci a un esempio relativamente familiare , pu\u00F2 apparire da questo punto di vista volta a volta rito o spettacolo . Dipende dai margini di coinvolgimento degli intervenuti ; e lo stesso si dica anche per le processioni , le laudi con responsorio , talune forme \u2018 sperimentali \u2019 di teatro contemporaneo ecc \u201D [ \u201C Every ritual is then in a certain sense spectacle . One may thus distinguish between ritual , in which performer and observer are not distinct from one another , and spectacle in the correct and proper sense , in which actors and spectators are institutionally separated . But this distinction also has its difficulties : the borders appear to be slippery . The very same Mass , to use a relatively familiar example , may appear from this point of view to be now ritual , now spectacle . It depends on the limits of involvement of those attending ; the same can be said for processions , praises with responses , certain \u2018 experimental \u2019 forms of contemporary theater , etc. \u201D ] . This is strongly reminiscent of the theories of theater anthropology and performance studies ; consider e.g. Schechner 1977 and Schechner 1985 .

Cf . the remark in Muff 1871:6n3 , who reports on the view in scholarship that the Ithyphalloi represent a stasimon ( because they come first to the center of the orchestra and sing only once they have done so ) , and the Phallophoroi a parodos . He relativizes this theory and also refers to \u03C3\u03C4\u03AC\u03B4\u03B7\u03BD \u1F14\u03C0\u03C1\u03B1\u03C4\u03C4\u03BF\u03BD . Cf . also Navarre 1911:249 , who translates \u03C3\u03C4\u03AC\u03B4\u03B7\u03BD \u1F14\u03C0\u03C1\u03B1\u03C4\u03C4\u03BF\u03BD in a similarly one-sided fashion as \u201C ils jouaient en place fixe ( loco stantes agebant ) \u201D [ \u201C they perform while standing on the spot \u201D ] . Kolster 1829:58\u201360 sees it the opposite way round : the song of the Ithyphalloi is a prosodion , and that of the Phallophoroi a stasimon ( \u201C Erat igitur ithyphallus carmen \u1F10\u03BC\u03B2\u03B1\u03C4\u03AE\u03C1\u03B9\u03BF\u03BD , phallophororum vero \u03C3\u03C4\u03AC\u03C3\u03B9\u03BC\u03BF\u03BD \u201D [ 58]) . He thinks the song was originally accompanied by dance and violent movement and that in being transferred from the street into the theater it was changed into a standing song , so that the original movement can still be observed in the entry procession (58\u201359) .

#Text=[ back ] 17 . Baur 1997:45n48 ( = Baur 1999a:27n45 ) emphasizes , as do I , that one should not overestimate the historically determined difference that Calame 1994/95 brought out between the chorus of choral lyric and that of drama . Seen from the point of view of the performative there is clear continuity : independently of my conclusions Baur ( ibid. ) also thinks that \u201C wer den Trag\u00F6dienchor verstehen will , mu\u00DF weniger die Unterschiede zur verwandten Chorlyrik als vielmehr die zum unser abendl\u00E4ndisches Theaterverst\u00E4ndnis so stark beeinflussenden aristotelischen Modell betonen \u201D [ \u201C whoever wishes to understand the tragic chorus should emphasize to a lesser extent the differences between it and the choral lyric related to it and rather emphasize its differences from the Aristotelian model , which has had such a strong influence on our Western notion of theater \u201D ] . Though he correctly defines the special status ( Sonderstatus ) of the ancient chorus ( Baur 1997:44\u201347 ; Baur 1999a:26\u201328)\u2014\u201C[d]er Chor spielt immer einen Chor \u201D [ \u201C the chorus always plays a chorus \u201D ] ( 1987:44 = 1999a:26)\u2014he does not locate this in its continued ritual function the way I do here .

#Text=[ back ] 18 . Kannicht 1989:47\u201351 , especially 50 . Claude Calame ( per litt . ) correctly draws my attention to the fact that in investigating this one ought also to consider the status of poetry ( \u03C0\u03BF\u03AF\u03B7\u03C3\u03B9\u03C2 ) in Greece during the classical period . Ritual songs exist ultimately only in poetic form , and the distinction between songs that can be ascribed to authors and carmina popularia ( as with that between Homeric , anonymous , and inscriptional hymns ) is somewhat illusory in this connection .

( k\u00F4mos and song combined ) ; Pratinas fragment 708 , especialy lines 1\u20135 and 14\u201316 PMG ; cf. also the performative self-description in the first-person plural , without explicit mention of the \u03C7\u03BF\u03C1\u03CC\u03C2 , in the folk songs fragment 848 PMG ( Rhodian swallow song ) , 870 PMG , and 882 PMG ( Sicilian song of the boukoliastai ) and in the begging song of the Samian eiresi\u00F4n\u00EA , carm . pop . fragment 1 D. The phenomenon is also found in the so-called song of the koronistai by Phoinix , fragment 2 D. = Powell 1925:233\u2013234 , lines 15ff . , which is however not an authentic folk song but rather a Hellenistic imitation ; see Sch\u00F6nberger 1980:50\u201356 and Furley 1994 . As in the Callimachean hymns , the performative clich\u00E9 is inbuilt , although the work is aimed at a reading audience ; cf. ibid. , especially 25\u201331 . Cf . furthermore the self-referentiality in customary hymns : the Palaikastro hymn , West 1965:149\u2013151 , 149 = Powell 1925:160\u2013162 , 160 , lines 6\u201310 ; Macedonius , Paean in Apollinem et Aesculapium ( Powell 1925:138\u2013140 , 138 = K\u00E4ppel 1992:383\u2013384 , 383\u2013Pai . 41 ) , lines 1\u20135 ; Paean Delphicus I ( K\u00E4ppel 1992:387\u2013389 , 388\u2013Pai . 45 ) , lines 14\u201316 = Powell 1925:141\u2013148 , 141 , lines 12\u201313 ; Limenius , Paean Delphicus II ( K\u00E4ppel 1992:389\u2013391 , 390\u2013Pai . 46 ) , lines 15\u201317 = Powell 1925:149\u2013159 , 149 , lines 13\u201315 .

#Text=[ back ] 25 . A similar self-presentation of the chorus , also in connection with choral performance ( cf. the switching between performative and dramatic function ) is found particularly in Aristotle Frogs 209\u2013220 , especially 212\u2013214 : \u03BE\u03CD\u03BD\u03B1\u03C5\u03BB\u03BF\u03BD \u1F55\u03BC\u03BD\u03C9\u03BD \u03B2\u03BF\u1F70\u03BD | \u03C6\u03B8\u03B5\u03B3\u03BE\u03CE\u03BC\u03B5\u03B8 \u2019 \u03B5\u1F54\u03B3\u03B7\u03C1\u03C5\u03BD \u1F10\u03BC\u1F70\u03BD \u1F00\u03BF\u03B9\u03B4\u03AC\u03BD , | \u03BA\u03BF\u1F70\u03BE \u03BA\u03BF\u03AC\u03BE , 229\u2013235 : \u1F10\u03BC\u1F72 \u03B3\u1F70\u03C1 \u1F14\u03C3\u03C4\u03B5\u03C1\u03BE\u03B1\u03BD \u03B5\u1F54\u03BB\u03C5\u03C1\u03BF\u03AF \u03C4\u03B5 \u039C\u03BF\u1FE6\u03C3\u03B1\u03B9 | \u03BA\u03B1\u1F76 \u03BA\u03B5\u03C1\u03BF\u03B2\u03AC\u03C4\u03B1\u03C2 \u03A0\u1F70\u03BD \u1F41 \u03BA\u03B1\u03BB\u03B1\u03BC\u03CC\u03C6\u03B8\u03BF\u03B3\u03B3\u03B1 \u03C0\u03B1\u03AF\u03B6\u03C9\u03BD , | \u03C0\u03C1\u03BF\u03C3\u03B5\u03C0\u03B9\u03C4\u03AD\u03C1\u03C0\u03B5\u03C4\u03B1\u03B9 \u03B4 \u2019 \u1F41 \u03C6\u03BF\u03C1\u03BC\u03B9\u03BA\u03C4\u1F70\u03C2 \u1F08\u03C0\u03CC\u03BB\u03BB\u03C9\u03BD | \u1F15\u03BD\u03B5\u03BA\u03B1 \u03B4\u03CC\u03BD\u03B1\u03BA\u03BF\u03C2 , \u1F43\u03BD \u1F51\u03C0\u03BF\u03BB\u03CD\u03C1\u03B9\u03BF\u03BD | \u1F14\u03BD\u03C5\u03B4\u03C1\u03BF\u03BD \u1F10\u03BD \u03BB\u03AF\u03BC\u03BD\u03B1\u03B9\u03C2 \u03C4\u03C1\u03AD\u03C6\u03C9 . | \u03B2\u03C1\u03B5\u03BA\u03B5\u03BA\u03B5\u03BA\u1F72\u03BE \u03BA\u03BF\u1F70\u03BE \u03BA\u03BF\u03AC\u03BE , and 240\u2013250 ; on the song of the Frogs and the parodos of the Mystai ( Frogs 316\u2013459 ) in the switching between performative and dramatic role cf. Dover Frogs , 57\u201360 and Dover 1993 . The self-description is entirely comparable to the chorus of swallows , carm . pop . 848 PMG . Cf . Lefkowitz 1991:21\u201322 . She correctly states : \u201C These choral swallows , like the Wasps and Frogs of Aristophanes \u2019 comedies , preserve some of their human characteristics , and only with their final words do they reveal their true identity . \u201D Comic choruses always present their appearance and action in verbal terms as well . Comparable with the passage in the Frogs are the parabasis odes in the Birds 737\u2013752 , especially Birds 745\u2013752 : \u03A0\u03B1\u03BD\u1F76 \u03BD\u03CC\u03BC\u03BF\u03C5\u03C2 \u1F31\u03B5\u03C1\u03BF\u1F7A\u03C2 \u1F00\u03BD\u03B1\u03C6\u03B1\u03AF\u03BD\u03C9 | \u03C3\u03B5\u03BC\u03BD\u03AC \u03C4\u03B5 \u039C\u03B7\u03C4\u03C1\u1F76 \u03C7\u03BF\u03C1\u03B5\u03CD\u03BC\u03B1\u03C4 \u2019 \u1F40\u03C1\u03B5\u03AF\u1FB3 , | \u03C4\u03BF\u03C4\u03BF\u03C4\u03BF \u03C4\u03BF\u03C4\u03BF\u03C4\u03BF \u03C4\u03BF\u03C4\u03BF\u03C4\u03BF \u03C4\u03AF\u03B3\u03BE | \u1F14\u03BD\u03B8\u03B5\u03BD \u1F61\u03C3\u03C0\u03B5\u03C1\u03B5\u1F76 \u03BC\u03AD\u03BB\u03B9\u03C4\u03C4\u03B1 | \u03A6\u03C1\u03CD\u03BD\u03B9\u03C7\u03BF\u03C2 \u1F00\u03BC\u03B2\u03C1\u03BF\u03C3\u03AF\u03C9\u03BD \u03BC\u03B5\u03BB\u03AD\u03C9\u03BD \u1F00\u03C0\u03B5- | \u03B2\u03CC\u03C3\u03BA\u03B5\u03C4\u03BF \u03BA\u03B1\u03C1\u03C0\u1F78\u03BD \u1F00\u03B5\u1F76 | \u03C6\u03AD\u03C1\u03C9\u03BD \u03B3\u03BB\u03C5\u03BA\u03B5\u1FD6\u03B1\u03BD \u1FA0\u03B4\u03AC\u03BD . | \u03C4\u03B9\u03BF \u03C4\u03B9\u03BF \u03C4\u03B9\u03BF \u03C4\u03AF\u03B3\u03BE , and Birds 769\u2013784 , especially 769\u2013773 : \u03C4\u03BF\u03B9\u03AC\u03B4\u03B5 \u03BA\u03CD\u03BA\u03BD\u03BF\u03B9 | \u03C4\u03B9\u03BF \u03C4\u03B9\u03BF \u03C4\u03B9\u03BF \u03C4\u03B9\u03BF | \u03C3\u03C5\u03BC\u03BC\u03B9\u03B3\u1FC6 \u03B2\u03BF\u1F74\u03BD \u1F41\u03BC\u03BF\u1FE6 \u03C0\u03C4\u03B5- | \u03C1\u03BF\u1FD6\u03C3\u03B9 \u03BA\u03C1\u03AD\u03BA\u03BF\u03BD\u03C4\u03B5\u03C2 \u1F34\u03B1\u03C7\u03BF\u03BD \u1F08\u03C0\u03CC\u03BB\u03BB\u03C9 , | \u03C4\u03B9\u03BF \u03C4\u03B9\u03BF \u03C4\u03B9\u03BF \u03C4\u03AF\u03B3\u03BE . Cf . also the self-presentation at the entry of the Clouds , Clouds . 298\u2013313 , especially 308\u2013313 with the ritual self-referentiality to the here and now of the festive context in Athens : \u03B5\u1F50\u03C3\u03C4\u03AD\u03C6\u03B1\u03BD\u03BF\u03AF \u03C4\u03B5 \u03B8\u03B5\u1FF6\u03BD \u03B8\u03C5\u03C3\u03AF\u03B1\u03B9 \u03B8\u03B1\u03BB\u03AF\u03B1\u03B9 \u03C4\u03B5 | \u03C0\u03B1\u03BD\u03C4\u03BF\u03B4\u03B1\u03C0\u03B1\u1FD6\u03C3\u03B9\u03BD \u1F65\u03C1\u03B1\u03B9\u03C2 , | \u1F26\u03C1\u03AF \u03C4 \u2019 \u1F10\u03C0\u03B5\u03C1\u03C7\u03BF\u03BC\u03AD\u03BD\u1FF3 \u0392\u03C1\u03BF\u03BC\u03AF\u03B1 \u03C7\u03AC\u03C1\u03B9\u03C2 | \u03B5\u1F50\u03BA\u03B5\u03BB\u03AC\u03B4\u03C9\u03BD \u03C4\u03B5 \u03C7\u03BF\u03C1\u1FF6\u03BD \u1F10\u03C1\u03B5\u03B8\u03AF\u03C3\u03BC\u03B1\u03C4\u03B1 | \u03BA\u03B1\u1F76 \u03BC\u03BF\u1FE6\u03C3\u03B1 \u03B2\u03B1\u03C1\u03CD\u03B2\u03C1\u03BF\u03BC\u03BF\u03C2 \u03B1\u1F50\u03BB\u1FF6\u03BD . The Dionysia represent the current occasion for the dramatic competitions ( in song , round dancing , and aulos ) and the sacred offering . On the performative choral \u201C I \u201D in comedy and tragedy cf. Lefkowitz 1991:22\u201325 .
#Text=[ back ] 26 . See my observations in Bierl 1991:111\u2013119 , 225\u2013226 . On Aristophanes , see Hubbard 1991 , passim ( on intertextual self-references ) and Bremer 1993:160\u2013165 .

#Text=[ back ] 27 . For reference to choral dance song , cf. Callimachus Hymns 1.52\u201354 ; 2.8 , 12 , 28\u201331 , 85\u201387 , 93 ; 3.3 , 170\u2013174 , 180\u2013181 , 240\u2013247 , 266\u2013267 ; 4.79 , 279 , 300\u2013315 ; in general on the interplay between traditional generic conventions and artistic freedom , see Henrichs 1993 , especially 129\u2013130 ( on the cultic framework and association with a ritual performance that is connected with group solidarity) . On the connected problem of the so-called mimetic hymns that reconstruct the conditions of the \u00E9nonciation within the song itself , which are undoubtedly unconnected to the extradiscursive reality , see Calame 1992a:55\u201358 , especially 57n19 ( with further references) .

#Text=[ back ] 28 . Cf . Calame 1995a:16\u201317 ( on the dances and songs of the Delian Maidens , i.e. the choral embedding of Homeric Hymns 3.146\u2013173 ) : \u201C Est-ce \u00E0 dire que les Hymnes hom\u00E9riques , dont la fonction introductive ne devrait plus faire de doute , \u00E9taient chant\u00E9s par un ch\u0153ur ? Ou , sinon par un groupe de choreutes , en tout cas par un a\u00E8de entour\u00E9 d\u2019un ch\u0153ur , selon le mode citharodique illustr\u00E9 par de nombreuses descriptions de performances \u00E9piques dans l\u2019Iliade ou l\u2019Odyss\u00E9e ? \u201D [ \u201C Does this mean that the Homeric hymns , whose introductory function should now be beyond doubt , were sung by a chorus ? Or , if not by a chorus , then in any case by a bard surrounded by a chorus , in the citharodic fashion illustrated by numerous descriptions of epic performance in the Iliad or the Odyssey ? \u201D ] . See also Furley 1993:24\u201329 .

#Text=[ back ] 29 . Cf . Adrados 1975:40 : \u201C Komos , I say , was the generic term for every type of chorus which changes place in performing ritual actions accompanied by dance , and eventually song , whether mimetic or not . \u201D Similarly Heath 1988:182 : \u201C It is not only the revelry after a symposium that could be described as a \u03BA\u1FF6\u03BC\u03BF\u03C2\u2014any mobile celebration will do . \u201D

#Text=[ back ] 30 . Cf . Adrados 1975:37\u201349 , who originally argues for a broad meaning that extends beyond the later restricted use of the term to the more or less comic (37\u201338) . He thus thinks that \u201C [ a ] komos can perform all the genres of the Dionysian contest , besides various others . \u201D Ghiron-Bistagne 1976:207\u2013297 is the best modern discussion of the k\u00F4mos . On the k\u00F4mos as origin of all dramatic genres see 265\u2013297 ; she divides the k\u00F4mos historically into three areas : a ) the carnevalesque festive procession of people going to and returning from a festival ( 208\u2013225 ) ; b ) the chorus that dances and sings ( 225\u2013231 ) ; and c ) the k\u00F4mos after a symposion ( 231\u2013238 ) ; cf. also Kuithan 1808:44\u201376 , Lamer 1922:1286\u20131304 , Reckford 1987:443\u2013451 , and Heath 1988 ; Hoffman 1989:97 also quotes the passage from Semos as indication of the inverted world . See now also P\u00FCtz 2003:156\u2013191 ( \u201C The Komos in Aristophanes \u201D ) ( with my critical review in CR 55 [ 2005]:422\u2013424 ) and Schmitz 2004:280\u2013320 , who classify the k\u00F4mos among the R\u00FCge \u2013 and Heischebr\u00E4uche of peasants and young people in the countryside and villages , later transferred also to city life . These customs have according to Schmitz a function of social control . On comasts in archaeological research see now Bron 1999 , Smith 2000 , Smith 2003 , Isler-Ker\u00E9nyi 2004 , Steinhart 2004 , and Rothwell 2006 ( I thank Erich Kistler , Zurich , for these references) .

#Text=[ back ] 31 . On the praxis of signifiers , see Lohr 1986 , passim , especially 1\u201328 , who is here is strongly influenced by the Telqueliens of the French poststructuralist school , in particular Julia Kristeva . For a radical critique of Kristeva \u2019s positions proceeding from the structuralist concept of knowledge , see Hempfer 1976:13\u201365 . In one of the more recent books on ritual Bell also works intensively with the concept of practice , drawing on Bourdieu \u2019s ( 1977 , especially 72\u2013158 ) concept of practice ; see Bell 1992 , passim , especially 74\u201388 , 140\u2013142 , and index s.v. practice .
#Text=[ back ] 32 . See Lohr 1986:74\u201380 .
#Text=[ back ] 33 . Lohr 1986:63\u201368 calls the phenomenon \u201C comic fall \u201D ( komischer Sturz ) .
#Text=[ back ] 34 . On the connection between initiation and symposium , see Bremmer 1990 .

#Text=[ back ] 35 . See Herter 1947 , especially 16\u201318 . The description of the Autokabdaloi is also reminiscent of the Autolekythoi . The Ithyphalloi , Autolekythoi , and Triballoi have a special tie to the phallus . Demosthenes 54.16\u201317 reports that the Ithyphalloi dedicated themselves to Ithyphallos in a kind of initiation . For the Autolekythoi and Triballoi as phallus gangs , see Whitman 1969 and Griffith 1970 . The name \u03C4\u03C1\u03B9\u03B2\u03B1\u03BB\u03BB\u03BF\u03AF has been interpreted as \u03C4\u03C1\u03AF\u03C6\u03B1\u03BB\u03BB\u03BF\u03B9 ; Herter 1938c:1681 . On the Athenian aristocratic drinking clubs , see Parker 1996:335\u2013336 and Murray 1990 . In Athens it appears that the Ithyphalloi also danced in the theater to rhythm ( Hyperides fragment 50 Jensen ) : \u03BF\u1F31 \u03C4\u03BF\u1F7A\u03C2 \u1F30\u03B8\u03C5\u03C6\u03AC\u03BB\u03BB\u03BF\u03C5\u03C2 \u1F10\u03BD \u03C4\u1FC7 \u1F40\u03C1\u03C7\u03AE\u03C3\u03C4\u03C1\u1FB3 \u1F40\u03C1\u03C7\u03BF\u03CD\u03BC\u03B5\u03BD\u03BF\u03B9 . The theater is thus an important gathering place for these ephebic groups ; in the trial of the Hermokopidai , Diokleides ( Andocides 1.37\u201338 ) makes the final statement that he saw about three hundred of the aristocratic conspirators in the orchestra of the theater of Dionysus and that they were arranged ( \u1F11\u03C3\u03C4\u03AC\u03BD\u03B1\u03B9 \u03B4\u1F72 \u03BA\u03CD\u03BA\u03BB\u1FF3 ) in groups of six or seven , some in groups of up to twenty . Might he have been thinking of the Ithyphalloi , who normally gave small performances in the orchestra in a chorus of varying size ? In Semos the Ithyphalloi also perform in the orchestra ( Athenaeus 622b ) : \u1F45\u03C4\u03B1\u03BD \u03BA\u03B1\u03C4\u1F70 \u03BC\u03AD\u03C3\u03B7\u03BD \u03C4\u1F74\u03BD \u1F40\u03C1\u03C7\u03AE\u03C3\u03C4\u03C1\u03B1\u03BD \u03B3\u03AD\u03BD\u03C9\u03BD\u03C4\u03B1\u03B9 .

#Text=[ back ] 36 . For a similar synaesthesia , consider in particular Pindar \u2019s dithyramb to Athens , fragment 75 S.-M . In a cletic hymn Dionysus is summoned to the Dionysia and the dithyrambic performances currently underway . Precisely as in the description of the heavenly Dionysia ( Pindar fragment 70b S.-M . ) , Pindar in his picture of the Bacchic spring festival ( 14\u201319 ) , where reference is made to its own occasion and performance , fuses together impressions of color , sound , movement , and smell in a manner characteristic of ritual speech ; see also Zimmermann 1992:53\u201360 , especially 54 . On \u201C thick \u201D description , cf. Geertz 1973:3\u201330 ( \u201C Thick Description : Toward an Interpretative Theory of Culture \u201D and Jensen 1986:119\u2013120 ( \u201C \u2018 thick \u2019 performance\u201D) .
#Text=[ back ] 37 . Cf . above , Introduction n180 .

#Text=[ back ] 38 . Their name seems to be derived from \u03B4\u03B5\u03AF\u03BA\u03B7\u03BB\u03B1 , which Hesychius glosses as , among other things , \u201C masks \u201D ; further explanations and passages in Pickard-Cambridge 1962:135 . On \u1F00\u03C0\u03BF\u03B4\u03B5\u03AF\u03BA\u03BD\u03C5\u03BC\u03B1\u03B9 and \u1F00\u03C0\u03CC\u03B4\u03B5\u03B9\u03BE\u03B9\u03C2 in the sense \u201C present publicly \u201D and \u201C public presentation , \u201D see Nagy 1990:217\u2013224 and 515 ( in the index , with numerous further references) . For \u1F10\u03C0\u03AF\u03B4\u03B5\u03B9\u03BE\u03B9\u03C2 , see Goldhill 1999:3\u20134 .

#Text=[ back ] 39 . \u1F10\u03BA\u03B1\u03BB\u03BF\u1FE6\u03BD\u03C4\u03BF \u03B4 \u2019 \u03BF\u1F31 \u03BC\u03B5\u03C4\u03B9\u03CC\u03BD\u03C4\u03B5\u03C2 \u03C4\u1F74\u03BD \u03C4\u03BF\u03B9\u03B1\u03CD\u03C4\u03B7\u03BD \u03C0\u03B1\u03B9\u03B4\u03B9\u1F70\u03BD \u03C0\u03B1\u03C1\u1F70 \u03C4\u03BF\u1FD6\u03C2 \u039B\u03AC\u03BA\u03C9\u03C3\u03B9 \u03B4\u03B5\u03B9\u03BA\u03B7\u03BB\u03B9\u03C3\u03C4\u03B1\u03AF , \u1F61\u03C2 \u1F04\u03BD \u03C4\u03B9\u03C2 \u03C3\u03BA\u03B5\u03C5\u03BF-\u03C0\u03BF\u03B9\u03BF\u1F7A\u03C2 \u03B5\u1F34\u03C0\u1FC3 \u03BA\u03B1\u1F76 \u03BC\u03B9\u03BC\u03B7\u03C4\u03AC\u03C2 . \u03C4\u03BF\u1FE6 \u03B4\u1F72 \u03B5\u1F34\u03B4\u03BF\u03C5\u03C2 \u03C4\u1FF6\u03BD \u03B4\u03B5\u03B9\u03BA\u03B7\u03BB\u03B9\u03C3\u03C4\u1FF6\u03BD \u03C0\u03BF\u03BB\u03BB\u03B1\u1F76 \u03BA\u03B1\u03C4\u1F70 \u03C4\u03CC\u03C0\u03BF\u03C5\u03C2 \u03B5\u1F30\u03C3\u1F76 \u03C0\u03C1\u03BF\u03C3\u03B7\u03B3\u03BF\u03C1\u03AF\u03B1\u03B9 . \u03A3\u03B9\u03BA\u03C5\u03CE\u03BD\u03B9\u03BF\u03B9 \u03BC\u1F72\u03BD \u03B3\u1F70\u03C1 \u03C6\u03B1\u03BB\u03BB\u03BF\u03C6\u03CC\u03C1\u03BF\u03C5\u03C2 \u03B1\u1F50\u03C4\u03BF\u1F7A\u03C2 \u03BA\u03B1\u03BB\u03BF\u1FE6\u03C3\u03B9\u03BD , \u1F04\u03BB\u03BB\u03BF\u03B9 \u03B4 \u2019 \u03B1\u1F50\u03C4\u03BF\u03BA\u03B1\u03B2\u03B4\u03AC\u03BB\u03BF\u03C5\u03C2 , \u03BF\u1F31 \u03B4\u1F72 \u03C6\u03BB\u03CD\u03B1\u03BA\u03B1\u03C2 , \u1F61\u03C2 \u1F38\u03C4\u03B1\u03BB\u03BF\u03AF , \u03C3\u03BF\u03C6\u03B9\u03C3\u03C4\u1F70\u03C2 \u03B4\u1F72 \u03BF\u1F31 \u03C0\u03BF\u03BB\u03BB\u03BF\u03AF\u00B7 \u0398\u03B7\u03B2\u03B1\u1FD6\u03BF\u03B9 \u03B4\u1F72 \u03BA\u03B1\u1F76 \u03C4\u1F70 \u03C0\u03BF\u03BB\u03BB\u1F70 \u1F30\u03B4\u03AF\u03C9\u03C2 \u1F40\u03BD\u03BF\u03BC\u03AC\u03B6\u03B5\u03B9\u03BD \u03B5\u1F30\u03C9\u03B8\u03CC\u03C4\u03B5\u03C2 \u1F10\u03B8\u03B5\u03BB\u03BF\u03BD\u03C4\u03AC\u03C2 ( Athenaeus 621e\u2013f) . In Thebes they are known as Ethelontai , volunteers , because they are not organized by the state . In Athens , too , as Aristotle reports ( Poetics 1449b2 ) , comedies were performed by ethelontai until 486 BCE ; that is to say , comic performance was not yet under the control of the polis , and so at this stage amounted to a kind of freeform farce without any overarching or structured plot , which was only introduced by Krates . Improvisation privileges the paradigmatic level , while the syntagmatic level of action appears only secondarily and is never carried through in a consistent fashion . On improvisation as spontaneous use of signifiers and precondition for the comic , see Lohr 1986:172\u2013175 . On reflexes of improvised theater , especially that of Oscan Attellan farce , in Plautus , see Vogt-Spira 1995 , whose conclusions may be applied to Aristophanes as well . On the Ethelontai , see Kranz 1933:8 . Cf . now on Athenaeus 621d\u2013f Stark 2004:34\u201340 , especially 34\u201335 .

#Text=[ back ] 40 . A passage from Alexis \u2019 Mandragorizomen\u00EA ( Alexis fragment 146 K.-A . ) is quoted by way of illustration : see Arnott 1996:430\u2013434 ; on the introduction to the play , 419\u2013421 . On the role of the doctor in Greek and Roman comedy , cf. ibid. , 431\u2013432 . The act of stealing food is a fundamental motif in farce and a typical source of low humor ; fruit and wine may also be associated with Dionysus , to whom they are in fact supposed to be offered . On the stealing of food , cf. Aristophanes Knights 418 ; on stealing fruit , Epicharmus fragment 239 Kaibel . Robbery and theft stand in opposition to the code of civilization ; the motif also belongs , for example , to the staged counterworld of Spartan initiation , where the initiates are supposed to steal cheese from the sanctuary of Artemis and are subject to a whipping if caught . There is also the Spartan mimetic dance called the tyrbasia , in which people caught in the act of stealing meat are imitated ( Pollux 4.104\u2013105) . The Athenian young men \u2019s association of the Triballoi is charged with the sacrilegious action of stealing and eating offerings to Hekate ( Demosthenes 54.39) . The simple transgression of norms induces raucous laughter in the group . The doctor can be associated with the alaz\u00F4n , and the fruit thief with the b\u00F4molokhos . The division into the types alaz\u00F4n and b\u00F4molokhos can already be seen in Aristotle . The eir\u00F4n , the ironic and cynical wise man , is also often mentioned in addition to these . Cf . Arisistotle Nicomachean Ethics 1108a21\u201325 and 1127a13\u20131128b4 ( detailed distinction between alaz\u00F4nes and b\u00F4molokhoi ) ; cf. also the Tractatus Coislinianus ( in Kaibel 1899:50\u201353 , here 52 [ \u00A76 ] and Koster 1975:63\u201367 , here 66 , lines 38\u201339 ) ; cf. generally also Hubbard 1991:2\u20138 . On the passage of Sosibios in particular ( Athenaeus 621d\u2013622a ) , see among others Pickard-Cambridge 1962:134\u2013137 , Koller 1954:44\u201345 , Breitholtz 1960:114\u2013122 , and Taplin 1993:49\u201351 ( on the phylakes) .

#Text=[ back ] 41 . Reich 1903:274\u2013280 sees comedy as a conglomerate of nonchoral mimes and choral members ( Autokabdaloi , Phallophoroi , Ithyphalloi ) ; Sosibios is influenced here , Reich thinks , by Aristotelian and peripatetic theory , which characterized mimos and phallikon as original comic forms ( ibid. , 254 and 280) . Breitholtz 1960:116\u2013117 emphasizes that Sosibios \u2019 report says nothing about dance . Webster in Pickard-Cambridge 1962:136 thinks that this involved small , popular scenes that were originally danced\u2014he makes a connection with the potbellied dancers , phlyakes , and the Spartan dance of men caught in the act of stealing meat ( Pollux 4.104\u2013105)\u2014and that later , under the influenced of developed comedy , became fossilized as a spectacle without dance .

#Text=[ back ] 42 . On the passage as a whole , especially on the fragments of Semos , see among others Muff 1871:5\u20137 , Thiele 1902 , Reich 1903:274\u2013280 , Cornford 19612:106\u2013111 , especially 106\u2013109 , Radermacher Fr\u00F6sche , 12 , K\u00F6rte 1921:1218\u20131219 , Pickard-Cambridge 1962:134\u2013151 , Wilamowitz I 1931/32:200\u2013201 ( = repr . I , 196\u2013197 ) , Herter 1938b:1678\u20131680 , Herter 1947:18\u201335 , Pohlenz 1949:35\u201339 ( = Kl . Schr . II 1965:501\u2013505 ) , Gelzer 1960:210 , H\u00E4ndel 1963:107\u2013109n17 , Gelzer 1966:68\u201369 , Sifakis 1971:20 , West 1974:23 , 36\u201337 , Adrados 1975:307 , Ghiron-Bistagne 1976:208\u2013212 and 245 , Blech 1982:208\u2013209 , Reckford 1987:487 , Leonhardt 1991:37\u201338 , Cole 1993 , especially 32\u201334 , Csapo/Slater 1995:94 , 97\u201398 , and Csapo 1997:264 . See also the discussion in the literary histories M\u00FCller II 1857:197\u2013198 , Schmid 1929:635 , and Lesky 19713:271\u2013272 . Breitholtz ( 1960:114\u2013122 ) is extremely skeptical about any conclusions relating to the possible origins of comedy . He concludes ( 122 ) : \u201C Wir haben es hier mit einer der von der Theatergeschichte am meisten missbrauchten Textstellen zu tun \u201D [ \u201C We are dealing here with one of the textual sources most abused by scholars of the history of theater \u201D ] . Athenaeus is not interested in the precise distinction between chorus and the individual mime ; rather , in his dinner conversation he is clearly only concerned about the effect of the behavior of performers of this type . In Hellenistic theater the choral song becomes considerably less important as the aria becomes favored and as soloists take over the choral parts as entertainment in the theater . Cf . Gentili 1977:11\u201322 (20062:41\u201349) .

( = Bergk III 18824:657 ) , carm . pop . 47 and 48 D. ( = Diehl II1 1925:206\u2013207 ) , also in Kaibel 1899:73\u201375 , Jacoby III , 290\u2013291 on Semos , FGrHist 396 F 24 , and Tresp 1914:201\u2013203 ( fragment 165) .

#Text=[ back ] 44 . Burkert 1983:24 , 58 , 69\u201370 , Fehling 1974:7\u201338 , and Burkert 1979:39\u201341 , 45 ; for more on the phallus , see Burkert 1983:58\u201372 , especially 69\u201372 , and Burkert 1985:104 ( in processions ) , 244 ( phalli made of dough at the Thesmophoria) . On the phallus , see Herter 1938c . In earlier work the phallus was seen to have a mainly apotropaic function , but Herter interprets it as an indication of fertility in particular . Yet the connection to death and the world beyond is also emphasized ( ibid. , 1728\u20131733 ) ; cf. also Leonhardt 1991:32 . Ghosts from the otherworld and daimones also have erect phalli . But one should on the contrary , though without completely losing sight of the traditional aspects , also emphasize in particular the moment of inversion , the mixing of all categories , and the grotesque , carnivalesque body that attracts attention to itself , thereby marking the Other ; cf. similarly Graf 1998:15 . Csapo 1997:259\u2013260 also criticizes the traditional pattern of interpretation that views the phallus as symbol of fertility , aggression , and something apotropaic ; he considers the Dionysiac phallus from the perspective of Turner \u2019s \u201C interstructure \u201D ( in contrast to the \u201C antistructure , \u201D which Csapo defines as a clear exception to the norm ; Turner uses both concepts without drawing a clear distinction between them ) , the total confusion of all standards , so that a contradictory function is fulfilled , namely returning society , vulnerable to social divisions , to normality without bringing these social differentiations themselves into question . Cf . Csapo 1997 , especially 253\u2013254 and 287\u2013288 . Instead of \u201C interstructure \u201D I use the phrase \u201C betwixt and between , \u201D which also goes back to Turner and comes close to the concept of liminality ( Turner 1967:93\u2013111 ; cf. above , chapter 1 n370) . In my view , the k\u00F4mos as wild choral procession reactualizes in accordance with the rules of the comic genre the inverted , chaotic world of initiatory rites during the marginal phase .

#Text=[ back ] 45 . \u03A3\u1FC6\u03BC\u03BF\u03C2 \u03B4 \u2019 \u1F41 \u0394\u03AE\u03BB\u03B9\u03BF\u03C2 \u1F10\u03BD \u03C4\u1FF7 \u03C0\u03B5\u03C1\u1F76 \u03A0\u03B1\u03B9\u03AC\u03BD\u03C9\u03BD ( FGrHist 396 F 24 ) \u03BF\u1F31 \u03B1\u1F50\u03C4\u03BF\u03BA\u03AC\u03B2\u03B4\u03B1\u03BB\u03BF\u03B9 , \u03C6\u03B7\u03C3\u03AF , \u03BA\u03B1\u03BB\u03BF\u03CD\u03BC\u03B5\u03BD\u03BF\u03B9 \u1F10\u03C3\u03C4\u03B5\u03C6\u03B1\u03BD\u03C9\u03BC\u03AD\u03BD\u03BF\u03B9 \u03BA\u03B9\u03C4\u03C4\u1FF7 \u03C3\u03C7\u03AD\u03B4\u03B7\u03BD \u1F10\u03C0\u03AD\u03C1\u03B1\u03B9\u03BD\u03BF\u03BD \u1FE5\u03AE\u03C3\u03B5\u03B9\u03C2 . \u1F55\u03C3\u03C4\u03B5\u03C1\u03BF\u03BD \u03B4\u1F72 \u1F34\u03B1\u03BC\u03B2\u03BF\u03B9 \u1F60\u03BD\u03BF\u03BC\u03AC\u03C3\u03B8\u03B7\u03C3\u03B1\u03BD \u03B1\u1F50\u03C4\u03BF\u03AF \u03C4\u03B5 \u03BA\u03B1\u1F76 \u03C4\u1F70 \u03C0\u03BF\u03B9\u03AE\u03BC\u03B1\u03C4\u03B1 \u03B1\u1F50\u03C4\u1FF6\u03BD ( Athenaeus 622ab) . Here , too , a later dramatic development seems to be conflated with an earlier choral stage : after the dance the choral performers seem to transition in a clearly improvisatory way into a speech and ridicule the audience in true iambic fashion , so that the performances as a whole are accordingly called iamboi after the meter . On improvisation and ridicule , see Vogt-Spira 1995:81\u201384 . On the iambos as ancient choral form , see West 1974:34\u201337 and Nagy 1979:242\u2013243 . West 1974:35 correctly sees the Syracusan \u1F30\u03B1\u03BC\u03B2\u03B9\u03C3\u03C4\u03B1\u03AF , who are compared to the Dionysiac round-dancing chorus of Athens ( Athenaeus 181c ) , as dancers who clearly correspond to the Athenian performers of the dithyramb . The dance of the iamboi will also assume a central position in my interpretation of the songs in Semos . According to West , iambos may represent a choral address as well as a speaking verse , and may also describe the combination of chorus and individual speaker that develops from the exarkhos of the choral group . Iambos thus does not , he maintains ( West 1974:22 ) , consist of the specific verse form , but the style of vulgar invective characteristic of iamboi , which is connected in particular with Dionysus and Demeter ( ibid. , 23\u201325 and Richardson 1974:213\u2013217) . On the ribald ridicule in the Thesmophoriazusae that is sandwiched between the Demetrian role and the Dionysiac function of the chorus , see above , pp. 169\u2013171 . On the combination of iambos and comedy , see Degani 1987 , Degani 1988 , Degani 1993 , and Rosen 1988 . See now also Treu 1999 , especially 129\u2013140 and Saetta Cottone 2005 , especially 143\u2013151 .
#Text=[ back ] 46 . On ivy as a Dionysiac characteristic , see Blech 1982:185\u2013210 .
#Text=[ back ] 47 . On the inversion of the world in Dionysiac ritual , see Hoffman 1989 .

#Text=[ back ] 48 . In contrast to Herter 1938b:1679 and Herter 1947:21 , and because of the song that follows , I follow Pohlenz 1949:35 ( = Kl . Schr . II 1965:501 ) in the view that neither the Phallophoroi nor the Ithyphalloi were themselves equipped with an erect phallus . Herter 1938b:1679 thinks this must have \u201C been visible through the see-through Tarentine clothing . \u201D Elsewhere he even says ( 1947:21 ) : \u201C vielleicht hob er sich aber auch plastisch ab oder wurde geradezu exhibiert \u201D [ \u201C perhaps it stood out prominently or was simply exhibited \u201D ] . A fetish carried by the Phallophoros need not of course exclude the presence of other phalli in the group , especially since as a kind of chorus leader he encompasses the characteristics of the whole ensemble . Blech 1982:209n133 connects figurative representations with the highly decorative headgear of the Phallophoroi ; on a fragment of black-figure pottery from Segesta , a man with a cap covered in phalli can be seen , and on a fragment of red-figure pottery there is a depiction of a man with an ivy wreath with phalli fixed to his forehead and nose ( Athens , Acropolis 702 ; ARV 213 , 238) . This is strongly reminiscent of grotesquely extended bodies in carnival rites .
#Text=[ back ] 49 . For the biological and ethological derivation of ritual , see Burkert 1996 and Baudy 1998:67\u201399 .
#Text=[ back ] 50 . Cole 1993 , especially 30\u201334 .

#Text=[ back ] 51 . For the joyful , comastic aspect of sacrifice , see the pictorial analysis in Peirce 1993 , who emphasizes the positive traits of ritual as opposed to the darker aspects of guilt that Vernant as well as Burkert and Meuli accentuate . She shows that \u03C0\u03BF\u03BC\u03C0\u03AE , \u1F11\u03BF\u03C1\u03C4\u03B1\u03AF , \u03C7\u03BF\u03C1\u03BF\u03AF , \u03BA\u1FF6\u03BC\u03BF\u03C2 , victory , joy , celebration , laughter , and symposion are often combined with sacrifice into a visual network of signs .

#Text=[ back ] 53 . On the lack of consistent illusion ( in terms of how the spectators react to the fictional role of the player ) and \u201C inlusion \u201D ( in terms of how the players behave toward the spectators with respect to a subjective knowledge of their role identity ) in folk plays and in ritual performance , see Lohr 1986:53\u201358 , 74\u201380 . In contrast to the veristic theater of the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries , actual performers and the bearers of fictional roles never overlap completely . On the mask ibid. , 78\u201379 ; like Calame 1989 , Lohr treats the mask as a means of achieving distance between performer , role , and spectator . Cf . Lohr 1986:78 : \u201C Die Filterwirkung der Maske schw\u00E4cht die eindringenden d\u00E4monischen Kr\u00E4fte im archaischen Ritual ab , die urspr\u00FCnglich im enthousiasmos vollkommen vom Ich Besitz ergriffen hatten . Diese Funktion der kultischen Maske wird in einer Art phylogenetischem \u2018 Maskensprung \u2019 in die s\u00E4kulare Darstellung des Mythos transponiert \u201D [ \u201C In archaic ritual the filtering effect of the mask alleviates the threatening , demonic powers that in the process of enthousiasmos had originally completely taken possession of the I. This function of the cultic mask is transposed in a kind of phylogenetic \u2018 mask leap \u2019 into the secular presentation of the myth \u201D ] . The qualification \u03BC\u03B5\u03B8\u03C5\u03CC\u03BD\u03C4\u03C9\u03BD refers of course to wine-drinking associated with the cult of Dionysus and the symposium . Kugelmeier 1996:154n269 is wrong not to see a reference to drunkenness in fragment 851 PMG .

#Text=[ back ] 54 . The ivy-wreath was worn as decoration by Attic citizen choruses , actors , participants in Dionysiac processions , the victorious poet , and the khor\u00EAgos ; see Blech 1982:208 . On ivy as decoration , cf. also above , chapter 1 n110 .

#Text=[ back ] 55 . Cf . Aristophanes Peace 168 ; Theocritus Epigrammata 1 , 2 ; Nicander Theriaca 67 . Blech 1982:209 identifies \u1F15\u03C1\u03C0\u03C5\u03BB\u03BB\u03BF\u03C2 with thyme , LSJ , s.v. and Olson Peace , 99 ad 166\u2013169 with Thymus sibthorpii .

#Text=[ back ] 56 . According to LSJ , s.v. \u03C0\u03B1\u03B9\u03B4\u03AD\u03C1\u03C9\u03C2 , this plant is Quercus ilex . A special kind of rouge appears to have been extracted from its berries . According to Paus . 2.10.6 , the \u03C0\u03B1\u03B9\u03B4\u03AD\u03C1\u03C9\u03C2 grows only in the sanctuary of Aphrodite in Sikyon . Despite the fact that Phallophoroi are mentioned just before in the quotation of Sosibios ( Athenaeus 621f ) , these Phallophoroi are not necessarily connected with the ones in Sikyon , although most commentators admittedly for this reason associate Semos \u2019 Phallophoroi with Sikyon ; cf. Herter 1947:19 and 50n83 . The fact that the two plants are attested for Sikyon in particular is not sufficient , since the plants are of such a general type and so widely distributed that their appearance can hardly be limited to one place alone . Delos is again a more likely candidate , since Semos came from Delos and also writes about cults of Delos in his own work . In particular Dionysus and phallophoria play a prominent role there , as Cole 1993 , especially 32ff . , argues . The following also argue for Delos : Wilamowitz 1921:266 , Wilamowitz I 1931/32:160 with n3 , 201 ( = reprinted ed . I , 156 with n4 , 197 ) , K\u00E4ppel 1992:54 and 330 ( test . 100) . In the general introduction to his commentary on the fragments in Semos , Jacoby remains undecided ( 204 ) : \u201C Dieses buch [ \u03A0\u03B5\u03C1\u1F76 \u03C0\u03B1\u03B9\u03AC\u03BD\u03C9\u03BD ] geh\u00F6rt ins gebiet der realphilologie und vielleicht der literarhistorie ; es war sicher nicht musiktheoretisch und nicht auf Delos beschr\u00E4nkt oder auch nur von delischen zust\u00E4nden ausgehend \u201D [ \u201C This book [ \u03A0\u03B5\u03C1\u1F76 \u03C0\u03B1\u03B9\u03AC\u03BD\u03C9\u03BD ] belongs to the realm of Realphilologie and perhaps to literary history ; it was certainly not concerned with musical theory , nor was it confined to Delos or exclusively concerned with Delian matters \u201D ] . Shortly thereafter he then comments on F 24 in particular ( 208 ) : \u201C Alle diese formen kann es auch auf Delos gegeben haben \u201D [ \u201C All these forms could also have occurred on Delos \u201D ] ( in the separate volume of notes by Jacoby ( 135n49 ) with reference to Vallois 1922) . Bruneau 1970:312n2 disagrees with Marcad\u00E9 1969:189n3 and does not see the connection with Delos . The language of the extant songs corresponds to the language of Attic drama , with only slight Doric coloring ; there is no Sicyonian Doric to be found , at any rate . But the songs are not ancient either ( cf. Wilamowitz I 18952:59n19 ) , and are influenced by koin\u00EA . West 1982:148 considers the possibility of an Athenian origin for the Ithyphalloi ( fragment 851a PMG) .

#Text=[ back ] 57 . E.g. Plato Symposium 212e ; cf. Herter 1947:19 and 50n85 . On the crown of violets as sign of the spring , the time of the occasion for Bacchic performances , cf. also Pindar fragment 75.6 ( and 17 ) S.-M . For the chorus who talks about the fantastic garland of flowers it wears on its head , cf. Cratinus fragment 105 K.-A . Cf . further fragment 852 PMG ( \u201C flower \u201D dance) . The head decoration also acts as source of visual meaning .
#Text=[ back ] 58 . On the effeminate Dionysos th\u00EAlymorphos , see Casadio 1987:227\u2013228 ( = Casadio 1999:115\u2013117) .

#Text=[ back ] 59 . On Dionysiac transvestism , see Casadio 1987:227\u2013234 ( = Casadio 1999:115\u2013123 ) with list ( 1987:229n69 [ = 1999:117n69 ] ) of interpretative categories ( agrarian magic , reintegration into a state of paradise , transitional rites in the marginal phases of initiation of youths) . On the Ithyphalloi and Phallophoroi in this connection , see Kenner 1970:112 and Casadio 1987:229 ( = Casadio 1999:118) .

#Text=[ back ] 60 . Tarentine cloth is transparent and thus particularly arousing . It is doubtful , as I have said , whether the Ithyphalloi actually wore an erect phallus on their body ( though their name might suggest this ) that , as Herter thinks ( Herter 1938b:1679 and Herter 1947:21 ) , shimmered through this garment . The Spartan gypones dancers also wear the tarantinidion ( Pollux 4.104 ) ; cf. also Casadio 1987:231 ( = Casadio 1999:120) . For the transparent garment with girdle as aphrodisiac enticement , cf. Aristophanes Lysistrata 46ff . , especially 48 , \u03B4\u03B9\u03B1\u03C6\u03B1\u03BD\u1FC6 \u03C7\u03B9\u03C4\u03CE\u03BD\u03B9\u03B1 . On the feminine appearance achieved by the long ankle-length garment , cf. the dress of the tragic actor , the god Dionysus , and Agathon in Thesmophoriazusae 130ff . The six bearded , bald-headed transvestite dancers on the Sabouroff red-figure vase ( ca . 460 BCE ) from Malibu ( Malibu , J. Paul Getty Museum 86.AE.296 ; ARV 837 , 10 ; ill . Price 1990 , pl. 10b and Csapo 1997 , pl. 1C ) , who also wear the long khit\u00F4n , have often been compared to the Ithyphalloi , especially since they are also associated with a thyrsos-like phallus-staff ; for an extensive description of the exterior of this vase , see Reich 1903:276n2 ; cf. also Price 1990:164 and Csapo 1997:264 . The grotesque , bearded dancers wearing long feminine garments on an Attic black-figure vase ( Amsterdam 3356 ) from the middle of the sixth century BCE have also been compared to the Ithyphalloi ; see Webster in Pickard-Cambridge 1962:81 , 141 , 304 and ill . 21 ( pl. 6b) .

#Text=[ back ] 61 . On the kaunak\u00EA see Herter 1947:20 , Starkie Wasps , 332 ad loc. , MacDowell Wasps , 278\u2013279 ad 1137 , Sommerstein Wasps , 222 ad loc. , and Pickard Cambridge 1962:141n6 . The Thracian nickname \u03C4\u03C1\u03B9\u03B2\u03B1\u03BB\u03BB\u03BF\u03AF ( for \u03C4\u03C1\u03AF\u03C6\u03B1\u03BB\u03BB\u03BF\u03B9 ) for an Athenian drinking club should also be viewed in this context : the Thracians represented the quintessence of the wild barbarian for the Athenians ; Herter 1938c:1681 .

#Text=[ back ] 62 . For dance accompanying the \u03C6\u03B1\u03BB\u03BB\u03B9\u03BA\u03CC\u03BD , see Pollux 4.99\u2013100 . A \u03C6\u03B1\u03BB\u03BB\u03B9\u03BA\u03CC\u03BD is always a song to the phallus ; cf. Suda , s.v. \u03C6\u03B1\u03BB\u03BB\u03B9\u03BA\u03AC , \u03C6\u03B1\u03BB\u03BB\u03AC\u03BA\u03B9\u03BF\u03BD = Etymologicum Magnum . , s.v. \u03C6\u03AC\u03BB\u03B1\u03B9\u03BA\u03BF\u03BD ( 786 , 57\u201358 ) , Photius , s.v. \u03C6\u03B1\u03BB\u03BB\u03B9\u03BA\u03CC\u03BD , and schol . Aristophanes Acharnians 261 .

#Text=[ back ] 63 . As to whether the texts were spoken or sung , most scholars opt for the latter , despite the introductory \u03BB\u03AD\u03B3\u03BF\u03BD\u03C4\u03B5\u03C2 ; see , among others , West 1982:148 , \u201C the chant of the ( Athenian ? ) Ithyphalloi \u201D ; Wilamowitz I 1931/32:160n3 ( = repr . I , 156n4 ) , \u201C Delisches Kultlied \u201D [ \u201C Delian cult song \u201D ] ; Nilsson I 19673:592 , \u201C charakteristisches Lied \u201D [ \u201C characteristic song \u201D ] . Neither the meter of the first text nor that of the second offers a decisive answer to this question , but the song hypothesis does seem to be justified from a performative point of view . Other Ithyphalloi , who greeted Demetrios Poliorketes in Athens ( cf. below , n70 ) , are clearly connected with k\u00F4mos-like choral dancing : Demokhares of Athens , FGrHist 75 F 2 ( quoted in Athenaeus 253cd ) describes the performative situation as follows : \u03C0\u03C1\u03BF\u03C3\u03BF\u03B4\u03B9\u03B1\u03BA\u03BF\u1F76 \u03C7\u03BF\u03C1\u03BF\u1F76 \u03BA\u03B1\u1F76 \u1F30\u03B8\u03CD\u03C6\u03B1\u03BB\u03BB\u03BF\u03B9 \u03BC\u03B5\u03C4 \u2019 \u1F40\u03C1\u03C7\u03AE\u03C3\u03B5\u03C9\u03C2 \u03BA\u03B1\u1F76 \u1FA0\u03B4\u1FC6\u03C2 \u1F00\u03C0\u03AE\u03BD\u03C4\u03C9\u03BD \u03B1\u1F50\u03C4\u1FF7 \u03BA\u03B1\u1F76 \u1F10\u03C6\u03B9\u03C3\u03C4\u03AC\u03BC\u03B5\u03BD\u03BF\u03B9 \u03BA\u03B1\u03C4\u1F70 \u2020 \u03C4\u03BF\u1F7A\u03C2 \u1F44\u03C7\u03BB\u03BF\u03C5\u03C2 \u1F96\u03B4\u03BF\u03BD \u1F40\u03C1\u03C7\u03BF\u03CD\u03BC\u03B5\u03BD\u03BF\u03B9 \u03BA\u03B1\u1F76 \u1F10\u03C0\u1FB4\u03B4\u03BF\u03BD\u03C4\u03B5\u03C2 . See also the glosses in the Suda and in Photius , s.v. \u1F30\u03B8\u03CD\u03C6\u03B1\u03BB\u03BB\u03BF\u03B9\u00B7 . . . \u03BA\u03B1\u1F76 \u03C0\u03BF\u03B9\u03AE\u03BC\u03B1\u03C4\u03B1 \u03B4\u1F72 \u03BA\u03B1\u03BB\u03B5\u1FD6\u03C3\u03B8\u03B1\u03B9 , \u1F03 \u1F10\u03C0\u1F76 \u03C4\u1FF7 \u1F31\u03C3\u03C4\u03B1\u03BC\u03AD\u03BD\u1FF3 \u03C6\u03B1\u03BB\u03BB\u1FF7 \u1F84\u03B4\u03B5\u03C4\u03B1\u03B9 \u03BC\u03B5\u03C4 \u2019 \u1F40\u03C1\u03C7\u03AE\u03C3\u03B5\u03C9\u03C2 . The Athenian Ithyphalloi will have danced to an ithyphallic rhythm in accordance with their nature ; cf. the grammarian \u2019s quotation , repeating a quotation from Hypereides \u2019 speech again Arkhestratides ( Hypereides fragment 50 Jensen ) : \u03BF\u1F31 \u03C4\u03BF\u1F7A\u03C2 \u1F30\u03B8\u03C5\u03C6\u03AC\u03BB\u03BB\u03BF\u03C5\u03C2 \u1F10\u03BD \u03C4\u1FC7 \u1F40\u03C1\u03C7\u03AE\u03C3\u03C4\u03C1\u1FB3 \u1F40\u03C1\u03C7\u03BF\u03CD\u03BC\u03B5\u03BD\u03BF\u03B9 . For further dancing Ithyphalloi , cf. Athenaeus 129d ; the Phallophoroi mentioned by Antheas of Lindos also performed a k\u00F4mos ( Athenaeus 445ab) .

#Text=[ back ] 64 . It must be emphasized that the two juxtaposed passages should not be interpreted as a unique ritual sequence in the sense of a diachronic narrative , although Semos , or perhaps even Athenaeus , could to some extent have manipulated the juxtaposed variants in this direction .

#Text=[ back ] 66 . On t\u00F4thasmos see Fluck 1931:11\u201333 and Rusten 1977 , who emphasizes the exhibitionist element in addition to the ribald and aggressive ridicule . The Phallophoroi possibly opened their cloaks in a kind of anasyrisis or lifted them high so that the strapped-on erect member concealed underneath would appear . Herter had already suggested this concealment of the phallus under the cloak in the case of the Ithyphalloi . Cf . above , n47 . Of course both the bearer \u2019s object and the accompanying group could be phallic . Cf . the reverse of the so-called Heydemann cup ( Florence 3897 ) , which depicts a phallic procession at the rural Dionysia ( illustrations in Deubner 1932 , pl. 22:2 , Ghiron-Bistagne 1976:211 fig. 66 , and Csapo 1997 , pl. 4) . The cloak may have been removed for the t\u00F4thasmos , which is reminiscent of the ( aggressive ) scenes in the transition to the parabasis in Old Comedy ; cf. also Acharnians 626\u2013627 , Peace 729\u2013730 , Lysistrata 615 , and Thesmophoriazusae 656 . With these passages the ancient opinion ( schol . Peace 729 ) is generally reproduced that the cloak was removed in order to be able to move freely while dancing . Only at Wasps 408 do we find the removal of the long cloak ( together with the exposure of wasp \u2019s sting , reminiscent of a phallus ) not at the transition to the parabasis ; cf. also Sifakis 1971:86\u201388 , 98 , and 103\u2013108 .

#Text=[ back ] 67 . See Sommerstein 1996 . Nagy 1979:243\u2013252 shows the complementarity of praise and blame in iambos and indicates how k\u00F4mos and comedy , which developed from the latter , have a similar function . Just as the iambos uses ritualized aggression against an \u1F10\u03C7\u03B8\u03C1\u03CC\u03C2 and thereby creates a group solidarity among the \u03C6\u03AF\u03BB\u03BF\u03B9 at the symposium , so too the ridicule of individual citizens in ad hoc fashion in the marketplace serves to increase the cohesiveness of the whole community (249\u2013252) .

#Text=[ back ] 68 . Black soot , white gypsum , or yeast as original makeup help to create a distancing and symbolic emphasis , an effect also produced by masks ; cf. Pickard-Cambridge 1962:74\u201380 . The color black is also a particular marker of the Attic eph\u00EAbeia and other rites of puberty ; see Vidal-Naquet 1968 , especially 112 .

#Text=[ back ] 69 . The god here is probably Phales , the personification of the phallus in the procession at the rural Dionysia , but also connected with Dionysus . Cf . Pohlenz 1949:35 ( = Kl . Schr . II , 1965:501 ) : \u201C die Ithyphallen melden den Einzug ihres Gottes , der wohl eher Phales als Dionysos ist \u201D [ \u201C The Ithyphalloi announce the entry of their god , who is probably Phales rather than Dionysus \u201D ] . In the phallic procession at Acharnians 241\u2013279 , discussed in greater detail below , Phales is described as \u201C companion and fellow-comast of Dionysus \u201D ( \u03A6\u03B1\u03BB\u1FC6\u03C2 , \u1F11\u03C4\u03B1\u1FD6\u03C1\u03B5 \u0392\u03B1\u03BA\u03C7\u03AF\u03BF\u03C5 , \u03BE\u03CD\u03B3\u03BA\u03C9\u03BC\u03B5 , 263\u2013264) . On the phallus in the cult of Dionysus , see Herter 1938c:1701\u20131710 . On Phales , see Herter 1938 . In Methymna on Lesbos , Dionysus has the additional name Phallen ; Herter 1938a . For the theme of parousia in the entry procession , cf. the German Advent song \u201C Macht hoch die T\u00FCr , die Tor macht weit , es kommt der Herr der Herrlichkeit ! \u201D [ \u201C Make high the door , make wide the gate , here comes the master of magnificence ! \u201D ] and generally Weinreich 1929:34\u2013286 , especially 59\u201363 .

#Text=[ back ] 70 . The text is contested . The meter is normalized following Bergk or Tyrwhitt \u2019s conjecture (3ia|ith||3ia|ith||) . It would thus be identical to the hymn of Hermokles , also preserved in Athenaeus ( 253d\u2013f ) ( Duris of Samos , FGrHist 76 F 13 , carm . pop . fragment 46 B. [ = Bergk III 18824:674\u2013676 ] , Poetae Melici II D. [ = Diehl II1 1925:249\u2013251 ] and Powell 1925:173\u2013175 ) , which was composed for Demetrios Poliorketes when he entered Athens in Dionysiac costume in 291 ( ? ) BCE . A further parallel can be found in the small song by Theokles ( Athenaeus 497c , Poetae Melici III D. [ = Diehl II1 1925:251 ] and Powell 1925:173) . On the Theokles song : Athenaeus connects the drinking vessel described as a dikeras with Ptolemy Philadelphos , who is supposed to have decorated statues of Arsinoe with it . The fragment is rich in performative information ; performance in the here and now is emphasized ; cf. \u03C3\u03AE\u03BC\u03B5\u03C1\u03BF\u03BD , the first-person singular and plural , s\u00F4t\u00EAria , the Tekhnitai , a king , and the symposium . As with the other fragments of Semos preserved in Athenaeus that concern the Ithyphalloi and Phallophoroi and are introduced with \u03BB\u03AD\u03B3\u03BF\u03BD\u03C4\u03B5\u03C2 , the means of performance is also here much debated . Fraser I 1972:232\u2013233 discusses the text and thinks it is not clear who the speaker is . Contra Wilamowitz I 1924:166n2 : \u201C offenbar bei einer Prozession der Techniten vor Philadelphos gesungen . Ich hatte Theokles fr\u00FCher falsch unter Philopator gesetzt \u201D [ \u201C Apparently sung at a procession of the Tekhnitai in front of Philadelphos . I had previously incorrectly placed Theokles under the reign of Philopator \u201D ] . Here he refers to Wilamowitz 1921:127n2 , where he dates Theokles to the time of Philopator . [ back ] On the hymn to Demetrios Poliorketes : Tresp 1914:203 compares Semos \u2019 Ithyphalloi with the singing and dancing Ithyphalloi , who according to Demokhares of Athens , FGrHist 75 F 2 ( with paraphrase of the hymn , which is attested in Duris \u2019 version ) , greeted Demetrios ( Athenaeus 253c) . Cf . Habicht 19702:50\u201355 and 232\u2013233 , Habicht 1995:94\u2013103 , Parker 1996:258\u2013263 , and Stehle 1997:42\u201346 . For information about the Theokles and Hermokles text I thank Albert Henrichs ; cf. also Henrichs 1999 , in which the hymn to Demetrios is also addressed (243\u2013247) . Anacreon fragment 78 D. ( = 431 PMG ) already uses the combination 3ia|ith|| . On this cf. also Gentili 1952:95\u201396 ( now also Gentili/Lomiento 2003:124 ) , and West 1982:148 ( without Anacreon fragment 78 D.) . Rossbach/Westphal 18893:306 also mention Aristophanes fragment 425 K.-A . ( with the conjecture \u03B4\u03AC\u03C0\u03C4\u03BF\u03BD\u03C4\u03B1 , so that the first verse forms a trimeter ) ; cf. K.-A . in PCG III.2 , 233 . [ back ] In the form adopted by Page ( PMG ) and West 1982:148 , the first verse is a lekythion ( trochaic dimeter catalectic ) , which easily admits variations ; the ithyphallic represents the catalectic form of the lekythion . Wilamowitz \u2019s division ( Wilamowitz 1921:266n5 ) into four trochaic dimeters is not convincing . Once again , underlining indicates the performative element , and italicization here and in the following examples indicates matters specific to the phallus cult .

#Text=[ back ] 71 . There is the mistake in the apparatus to line 1 in Page ( PMG , 453 ) : he prints \u1F00\u03BD\u03AC\u03B3\u03B5\u03C4 \u2019 \u03BA\u1FF6\u03BC\u03BF\u03BD , \u03B5\u1F50\u03C1\u03C5\u03C7\u03C9\u03C1\u03AF\u03B1\u03BD coni . Tyrwhitt .

#Text=[ back ] 72 . On \u1F04\u03B3\u03B5 or \u1F04\u03BD\u03B1\u03B3\u03B5 as a performative signal of urgency in ritual , cf. above , chapter 1 , n23 . Cf . also Aristophanes Birds 1720\u20131721 : \u1F04\u03BD\u03B1\u03B3\u03B5 \u03B4\u03AF\u03B5\u03C7\u03B5 \u03C0\u03AC\u03C1\u03B1\u03B3\u03B5 \u03C0\u03AC\u03C1\u03B5\u03C7\u03B5\u00B7 | \u03C0\u03B5\u03C1\u03B9\u03C0\u03AD\u03C4\u03B5\u03C3\u03B8\u03B5 . . . ( self-address in fight songs ) ; cf. Dunbar Birds , 753 ad 1720 : \u201C This series of orders must have produced excited chorus-movements in the orchestra . \u201D Ibid. and in Dunbar Birds , 284 ad 383 , as well as 290 ad 400 , Dunbar notes that \u1F04\u03BD\u03B1\u03B3\u03B5 should here be understood as a technical military term . On the connection between ephebic military and choral service , Winkler 1990 ; the imperative is admittedly rather general and can be connected with any specific performance of an action : cf. Euripides Trojan Women 325 : \u1F04\u03BD\u03B1\u03B3\u03B5 \u03C7\u03BF\u03C1\u03CC\u03BD ( cf. in this connection Tyrwhitt \u2019s supplement \u1F00\u03BD\u03AC\u03B3\u03B5\u03C4 \u2019 in line 1 ) ; for the completion of a sacrifice or festival : LSJ , s.v. I.5 ; in particular the striking up of a song may be introduced in this way : e.g. Sophocles Women of Trachis 210\u2013211 and LSJ , s.v. I.7 .

#Text=[ back ] 73 . The ithyphallic meter is so called because of its use in the Dionysiac \u03C6\u03B1\u03BB\u03BB\u03B1\u03B3\u03C9\u03B3\u03AF\u03B1 ; see the sources in West 1982:97\u201398 with reference to Semos \u2019 Ithyphalloi . On the ithyphallic see West 1982:97\u2013101 , 146\u2013148 and Gentili 1952:94\u2013105 ( now also Gentili/Lomiento 2003:123\u2013128 ) ; Aristophanes \u2019 use of the asynartetic combination with a iambic dimeter ( the euripideus ) , as in Aristophanes Knights 756\u2013760 and 836\u2013840 , Clouds 1114 , Wasps 248\u2013272 , Frogs 396\u2013397 , 443\u2013447 , Pherecrates fragment 2.3 and fragment 195 K.-A . , is interesting ; like Euripides , Aristophanes uses the ithyphallic as a clausula , cf. Gentili 1952:104\u2013105 ( now also Gentili/Lomiento 2003:127\u2013128) . On the ithyphallic in Aristophanes , see also White 1912:73\u201374 ( \u00A7 203) . West 1982:146\u2013148 especially emphasizes the use of iambs and ithyphallics in traditional and ritual songs , which speaks in favor of the song hypothesis . Cf . ibid. , 148 , the combination of the ritual \u03C4\u03AE\u03BD\u03B5\u03BB\u03BB\u03B1 \u03BA\u03B1\u03BB\u03BB\u03AF\u03BD\u03B9\u03BA\u03B5 Archilochus fragment 324 W. and the refrain of the Palaikastro hymn with fragment 851a PMG . As is well known , Aristophanes incorporates much material from popular song ( Silk 1980:124\u2013129) . One could also argue that Aristophanes himself did not make many distinctions in rhythmic structure from current ritual forms . The conventionality , repetition , and simplicity that Aristophanes is criticized for in his lyrics ( Silk 1980 ) may well be grounded in the characteristic ritual nature of choral song , which emphasizes the here and now of the performance . Cf . Mathews \u2019 ( 1997 ) response to Silk \u2019s criticism , which refers to the ritual and performative dimension , especially to dance ( ibid. , 32\u201342) .
#Text=[ back ] 74 . The gods are often invoked in cletic hymns to observe and participate in choral dance . This occurs especially in the odes of the parabasis .

#Text=[ back ] 75 . Cf . Aeschylus Libation Bearers 942 : \u1F10\u03C0\u03BF\u03BB\u03BF\u03BB\u03CD\u03BE\u03B1\u03C4 \u2019 ( cf. the commentary of Sier 1988:289 ad loc. : \u201C Die Aufforderung zur Ololyge ist schon Artikulation des Jubels , die den Schrei ersetzt \u201D [ \u201C The command to pronounce the ololyg\u00EA is already an articulation of the rejoicing and takes the place of the actual shout\u201D]) . The word represents the action , and so the command already amounts to the chorus \u2019 moving apart . Cf . in another context Aristophanes Clouds 127 with Dover Clouds , 109 ad loc. ( with reference to Austin) .

#Text=[ back ] 76 . IG I3 1178.1 = CEG 12 ( pp. 10\u201311 Hansen ) ( funerary inscription for Silenos from Rhegium , 433/32 BCE ) : \u03B5\u1F50\u03C1\u03CD\u03C7\u03BF\u03C1\u03BF\u03B9 . . . \u1F08\u03B8\u1FC6\u03BD\u03B1\u03B9 , cf. Corinna fragment 655\u2013fragment 1.8 PMG : \u03B3\u1FC6\u03B1\u03BD \u03B5\u1F50\u03C1\u03BF\u03CD[\u03C7\u03BF\u03C1\u03BF\u03BD , fragment adesp . 934.20 PMG : \u03C0\u03CC\u03BB\u03B9\u03BD \u03B5\u1F50\u03C1\u03CD\u03C7\u03BF\u03C1\u03BF\u03BD . Cf . LSJ s.v. : \u201C with broad places , spacious , \u201D Homer Iliad 2.498 , 9.478 ; Odyssey 13.414 , 15.1 ; Palatine Anthology 7.99.5 ; roads broad enough for choral dance : Pindar Pythian Odes 8.55 , Euripides Bacchae 86\u201387 ( and the Delphic oracle at Demosthenes 21.52 ) ; for roads : Philodamus , Paean in Dionysum ( Powell 1925:165\u2013171 , 169 = K\u00E4ppel 1992:375\u2013380 , 379\u2013Pai . 39 ) , lines 145\u2013146 and Euripides Hercules Furens 783 . Cf . also Seaford 1996:159 ad Euripides Bacchae 86\u201387 : \u201C \u03B5\u1F50\u03C1\u03CD\u03C7\u03BF\u03C1\u03BF\u03C2 often seems to imply \u03C7\u1FF6\u03C1\u03BF\u03C2 ( place ) rather than \u03C7\u03BF\u03C1\u03CC\u03C2 ( dance and song ) \u201D ; and LSJ s.v. \u201C Prop. with broad dancing-places , cf. \u03C7\u03BF\u03C1\u03CC\u03C2 ; then a conventional epithet , perh . connected by poets with \u03C7\u1FF6\u03C1\u03BF\u03C2 . \u201D For the etymological connection of \u03C7\u1FF6\u03C1\u03BF\u03C2 and \u03C7\u03BF\u03C1\u03CC\u03C2 , see Boedeker 1974:85\u201391 . For the epithet \u201C with beautiful chorus \u201D ( \u03BA\u03B1\u03BB\u03BB\u03AF\u03C7\u03BF\u03C1\u03BF\u03C2 ) , cf. Euripides Heracles Furens 690 , Helen 1454\u20131455 , Phoenician Women 786 , Cresphontes fragment 453.7\u20138 N/Kannicht , Corinna fragment 669 PMG , Aristophanes Frogs 451 ; \u1F20\u03B0\u03C7\u03BF\u03C1\u03BF\u03C2 Appendix nova epigrammatum 2 , 520 , 7 Cougny ; \u03B5\u1F54\u03C7\u03BF\u03C1\u03BF\u03C2 Photius , s.v. \u03B5\u1F54\u03BA\u03C5\u03BA\u03BB\u03BF\u03C2 . Cf . also \u03B5\u1F50\u03C1\u03CD\u03BD\u03C9 , \u201C to clear the arena for dance , \u201D Homer Odyssey 8.260 . For \u03B5\u1F50\u03C1\u03C5\u03C7\u03C9\u03C1\u03AF\u03B1 : cf. Com . adesp . 257 K.-A . , \u03B5\u1F50\u03C1\u03C5\u03C7\u03C9\u03C1\u03AF\u03B1\u03C2 \u03C3\u03B5 \u03B4\u03B5\u1FD6 . The word refers metaphorically to free space for performing some action : [ Plato ] Minos 315d3\u20134 \u03B5\u1F50\u03C1\u03C5\u03C7\u03C9\u03C1\u03AF\u03B1 \u03C4\u1FC6\u03C2 \u1F00\u03C0\u03BF\u03B4\u03B5\u03AF\u03BE\u03B5\u03C9\u03C2 ; for apodeixis as public performance , cf. Nagy 1990:162 , 217\u2013224 . In keeping with the strong sexual coloring of the song , \u03B5\u1F50\u03C1\u03C5\u03C7\u03BF\u03B9\u03C1\u03AF\u03B1\u03BD ( \u2018 broadness of vagina \u2019 ) could also have been used in this passage ( line 1 ) or could at least have occurred to the audience . A similar textual suggestion is made by Bowie 1990:35\u201336 in connection with Aristophanes Wasps 834 ; instead of the transmitted \u03C6\u03B9\u03BB\u03BF\u03C7\u03C9\u03C1\u03AF\u03B1 he conjectures \u03C6\u03B9\u03BB\u03BF\u03C7\u03BF\u03B9\u03C1\u03AF\u03B1 ; one could construct \u03B5\u1F50\u03C1\u03C5\u03C7\u03BF\u03B9\u03C1\u03AF\u03B1 as a parallel to the frequent word \u03B5\u1F50\u03C1\u03C5\u03C0\u03C1\u03C9\u03BA\u03C4\u03AF\u03B1 ( \u2018 broadness of anus \u2019 ) , Aristophanes Acharnians 843 , Wasps 1070 : cf. on \u03B5\u1F50\u03C1\u03C5\u03C0\u03C1\u03C9\u03BA\u03C4\u03AF\u03B1 Henderson 19912:77 , on the corresponding adjective \u03B5\u1F50\u03C1\u03CD\u03C0\u03C1\u03C9\u03BA\u03C4\u03BF\u03C2 ibid. , 77 , 195 , 210 , 213\u2013214 , 218 . For the name \u03A7\u03BF\u03B9\u03C1\u03BF\u03C8\u03AC\u03BB\u03B1\u03C2 used of Dionysus in the Sicyonian mysteries , see Herter 1938c:1702 and Henderson 19912:132n128 .

#Text=[ back ] 77 . On the performative future , see Calame 1994/95:144 with 152n25 , Faraone 1995 , and Henrichs 1994/95:80 with 104n97 ; cf. already Norden 1939:199\u2013201 ( on the future in prayer) . The concept of the performative future and performative verb forms will here be transferred to the third person , although it has hitherto been applied generally to the first and second persons only . Cf . above , Introduction n112 . For \u03B8\u03AD\u03BB\u03C9 with the infinitive in the sense of the more commonly used future , cf. Pindar Pythian Odes 9.1\u20133 \u1F10\u03B8\u03AD\u03BB\u03C9 . . . \u03A0\u03C5\u03B8\u03B9\u03BF\u03BD\u03AF\u03BA\u03B1\u03BD . . . \u1F00\u03B3\u03B3\u03AD\u03BB\u03BB\u03C9\u03BD \u03A4\u03B5\u03BB\u03B5\u03C3\u03B9\u03BA\u03C1\u03AC\u03C4\u03B7 . . . \u03B3\u03B5\u03B3\u03C9\u03BD\u03B5\u1FD6\u03BD , Pindar Isthmian Odes 1.15\u201316 \u1F10\u03B8\u03AD\u03BB\u03C9 . . . \u1F10\u03BD\u03B1\u03C1\u03BC\u03CC\u03BE\u03B1\u03B9 \u03BD\u03B9\u03BD \u1F55\u03BC\u03BD\u1FF3 ; Thummer I 1968/69:128 classifies such constructions as examples of the \u201C \u2018 enkomiastische \u2019 Futur , das die gegenw\u00E4rtige Intention des Dichters ausdr\u00FCckt und niemals \u00FCber das Gedicht hinausweist \u201D [ \u201C \u2018 encomiastic \u2019 future , which expresses the poet \u2019s current intention and never refers beyond the poem \u201D ] ; it is identical to the performative future .

#Text=[ back ] 78 . The expression \u1F40\u03C1\u03B8\u1F78\u03C2 . . . \u03B2\u03B1\u03B4\u03AF\u03B6\u03B5\u03B9\u03BD corresponds to the formulation in the description of the Phallophoroi that follows , where it is said of the phallophoros that he enters thus ( \u1F30\u03B8\u1F7A \u03B2\u03B1\u03B4\u03AF\u03B6\u03C9\u03BD ) ; Semos \u2019 choice of vocabulary here is probably influenced by the song of the Ithyphalloi . On \u03B2\u03B1\u03AF\u03BD\u03B5\u03B9\u03BD ( cf. \u03B2\u03B1\u03AF\u03BD\u03BF\u03BD\u03C4\u03B5\u03C2 \u1F10\u03BD \u1FE5\u03C5\u03B8\u03BC\u1FF7 in the preceding performative information provided about the Phallophoroi ) , which is synonymous with \u03B2\u03B1\u03B4\u03AF\u03B6\u03B5\u03B9\u03BD , as a term in common parlance with sexual connotations , cf. Henderson 19912:19n70 ( \u201C fuck \u201D ) , 27 , 136 , 147 , 155 ( \u201C mounting \u201D ) , and 194n10 . For \u03BC\u03AD\u03C3\u03BF\u03C2 cf. ibid. , 156 . For its use in combination with the k\u00F4mos , cf. Aristophanes Wealth 1040 : \u1F10\u03C0\u1F76 \u03BA\u1FF6\u03BC\u03BF\u03BD \u03B2\u03B1\u03B4\u03AF\u03B6\u03B5\u03B9\u03BD ( k\u00F4mos of the young man about whom the old woman complains ; like the Ithyphalloi , he wears a garland and is drunk and out of control) .
