For \u03B2\u03B1\u03B4\u03AF\u03B6\u03B5\u03B9\u03BD as self-referential expression of the chorus cf. inter alia Thesmophoriazusae 1228\u20131229 : \u1F65\u03C1\u03B1 \u03B4\u03AE \u2019 \u03C3\u03C4\u03B9 \u03B2\u03B1\u03B4\u03AF\u03B6\u03B5\u03B9\u03BD | \u03BF\u1F34\u03BA\u03B1\u03B4 \u2019 \u1F11\u03BA\u03AC\u03C3\u03C4\u1FC3 ( in reference to the chorus \u2019 departure at the end of the play) .

#Text=[ back ] 79 . Cf . Timokles fragment 31.2 K.-A . ap . Athenaeus 246f , \u03B4\u03B5\u03B9\u03C0\u03BD\u03BF\u1FE6\u03C3\u03B9\u03BD \u1F10\u03C3\u03C6\u03C5\u03B4\u03C9\u03BC\u03AD\u03BD\u03BF\u03B9 . The transmitted \u1F10\u03C3\u03C6\u03C5\u03C1\u03C9\u03BC\u03AD\u03BD\u03BF\u03C2 probably slipped into the text because of the words \u03BC\u03AD\u03C7\u03C1\u03B9 \u03C4\u1FF6\u03BD \u03C3\u03C6\u03C5\u03C1\u1FF6\u03BD in the preceding description of the Ithyphalloi . If the god ( \u1F41 \u03B8\u03B5\u03CC\u03C2 ) is fitted out with ankle bands or some kind of foot covering ( \u201C mit Kn\u00F6chelbinden oder sonst einer Fu\u00DFbekleidung , \u201D Pape II , s.v. \u03C3\u03C6\u03C5\u03C1\u03CC\u03C9 ) or , something that would make more sense , with a garment that reaches all the way to the ankles , this does not refer to the phallus being carried in , but to the cult statue or the person representing a divinity such as Dionysus . But this would deprive the fragment of its ambiguity . Cf . Herter 1938b:1678 : \u201C Ob Dionysos oder der Phallos als solcher mit diesem \u03B8\u03B5\u03CC\u03C2 gemeint war , l\u00E4\u00DFt das Lied nicht erkennen \u201D [ \u201C It cannot be determined from the song whether Dionysus or the phallus as such was meant by the term \u03B8\u03B5\u03CC\u03C2 \u201D ] ( with a list of the commentators who argue for the one solution or the other ibid. , 1678\u20131679) . In any case , the solution appears to lie not in an either-or , but rather in a both-and framework . Bursting and swelling ( \u03C3\u03C6\u03C5\u03B4\u03BF\u1FE6\u03BD ) applies equally to both Dionysus and the phallus . For Dionysos \u03A6\u03BB\u03B5\u03CD\u03C2 ( from \u03C6\u03BB\u03AD\u03C9 , \u201C be full of , teem with \u201D ) , see Graf 1985:283\u2013284 , who considers ( Graf 1985:284n10 ) the suggested connection with \u03C6\u03B1\u03BB\u03BB\u03CC\u03C2 and \u03C6\u03B1\u03BB\u03AE\u03BD to be problematic . On the adjective \u1F40\u03C1\u03B8\u03CC\u03C2 in a vulgar sense , see Henderson 19912:112 . Cf . in particular the \u03C6\u03B1\u03BB\u03BB\u1F78\u03C2 \u1F40\u03C1\u03B8\u03CC\u03C2 in Dikaiopolis \u2019 phallic procession ( Aristophanes Acharnians 243 , 259\u2013260 ) and Csapo 1997:284 . On Orthos as name for Dionysus , see Herter 1938c:1702 ; on the ancient daim\u00F4nes called Orthanes worshiped in Attica , ibid. , 1693 .

#Text=[ back ] 80 . One may compare the aetiology for the phallag\u00F4gia at the Athenian City Dionysia ( schol . Aristophanes Acharnians 243 ) : The Athenians did not honor the god imported from Boeotia to Athens . The male population subsequently fell victim to a disease of the genitals . The Athenians were only freed from this after they introduced a ritual that consisted of Dionysus being brought phalli as a gift . The inversion of order is restored to equilibrium with a renewal of fertility for the community .

#Text=[ back ] 81 . The god addressed in the previous text ( fragment a ) , who through a kind of fusion is equated with the phallus , is sometimes also associated with Dionysus in his appearance as Phales . See above , n79 . As \u201C proem \u201D the fragment is naturally , as in Aristophanes , also already part of the whole song of praise that the chorus sings as an ensemble . It would be incorrect to assume that the iamboi ( 3ia|3ia|3ia|3ia|2ia cat . ) are here , in contrast to an actual hymn , only spoken or performed in a parakatalog\u00EA . On the sung and danced iamboi of the Phallophoroi , see West 1974:36 . On iambic trimeters in traditional and ritual chants , West 1982:147 . He cites fragments 847 , 851b , 860 , 870 , 883 PMG as examples of iambic trimeter ; fragments 861 , 868 , 876b , 879.2 , and 881 PMG as examples of slightly shortened forms of the trimeter ( ibid. , nn23\u201324) . Actual prooimia are kitharodic , rhapsodic , or choral-melic depending on the context ; cf. Calame 1995a:3 with n5 and Nagy 1990:353\u2013360 . Of course the movement of the evocatio ( e.g. \u201C Sing for me , Muse , of Apollo , who . . . \u201D ) that one finds in the Homeric Hymns with its particular function as proem should not be interchanged with the invocatio , the direct appeal to the divinity in cult hymns .

#Text=[ back ] 82 . \u1FA0\u03B4\u03AE is here somewhat synonymous with \u03BC\u03BF\u03BB\u03C0\u03AE , i.e. the unity of song and dance ( cf. Nagy 1990:94 ) ; in any case \u1FA0\u03B4\u03AE seems to mean in particular the diction of the song . Rhythm , melos , and \u00F4id\u00EA give rise to the \u03BC\u03BF\u1FE6\u03C3\u03B1 , the hymn as musical Gesamtkunstwerk . Hymns and dance performance often belong together : see e.g. Burkert 1985:102\u2013103 . Processions also often stop along the way and perform hymns and dance . In the theater , as in our case , the stopping is abbreviated because of spatial limitation . The procession could also of course have endlessly circled in the orchestra . [ back ] The prosodion is here performed by an entering k\u00F4mos , whose movements could in the broadest sense be deemed equivalent to a \u201C dance . \u201D We have unfortunately lost the dimension of melody and choreography . They may perhaps also have underlined the abnormal character of an inverted world ; one can imagine the noisy and shrill sound of auloi and obscene sexual gestures . All that is left is the \u03BB\u03CC\u03B3\u03BF\u03C2 of the \u1FA0\u03B4\u03AE , in which the description of the performative context does , however , allow us to make conclusions about the other semiotic levels . Nagy 1990:51 likewise distinguishes three dimensions : diction , the rhythmic structure of movement , and melody . Here he applies the threefold division of lyric poetry ( \u03BC\u03AD\u03BB\u03BF\u03C2 ) into logos , harmonia , and rhythm found in Plato Republic 398d and Aristotle Poetics 1447a21\u201323 : \u1F05\u03C0\u03B1\u03C3\u03B1\u03B9 [ sc . \u03C0\u03BF\u03B9\u03AE\u03C3\u03B5\u03B9\u03C2 , the genres of epic , tragedy , comedy , dithyramb , and lyric ] \u03BC\u1F72\u03BD \u03C0\u03BF\u03B9\u03BF\u1FE6\u03BD\u03C4\u03B1\u03B9 \u03C4\u1F74\u03BD \u03BC\u03AF\u03BC\u03B7\u03C3\u03B9\u03BD \u1F10\u03BD \u1FE5\u03C5\u03B8\u03BC\u1FF7 \u03BA\u03B1\u1F76 \u03BB\u03CC\u03B3\u1FF3 \u03BA\u03B1\u1F76 \u1F01\u03C1\u03BC\u03BF\u03BD\u03AF\u1FB3 . . . For the triad , cf. already Alcman fragment 39 Davies and above , chapter 1 , n495 . In the song of the Phallophoroi , dance ( \u1FE5\u03C5\u03B8\u03BC\u03CC\u03C2 ) , words , and melody are thus fused together in the \u03BC\u03AD\u03BB\u03BF\u03C2 , with the last two levels mentioned being subsumed under the concept \u1FA0\u03B4\u03AE . For \u03BC\u03BF\u1FE6\u03C3\u03B1 in the sense of a concrete song , generally in self-referential form ( \u03C4\u03AC\u03BD\u03B4\u03B5 \u03BC\u03BF\u1FE6\u03C3\u03B1\u03BD 1 ) , cf. Aeschylus Eumenides 308 \u03BC\u03BF\u1FE6\u03C3\u03B1\u03BD \u03C3\u03C4\u03C5\u03B3\u03B5\u03C1\u1F70\u03BD ( immediately after the similarly self-referential \u03C7\u03BF\u03C1\u1F78\u03BD \u1F05\u03C8\u03C9\u03BC\u03B5\u03BD [ Eumenides 307 ] ; cf. on \u1F55\u03BC\u03BD\u03BF\u03C2 \u03B4\u03AD\u03C3\u03BC\u03B9\u03BF\u03C2 above , pp. 62\u201365 ) , Aeschylus Suppliants 695 , Sophocles Women of Trachis 643 , and Aristophanes Thesmophoriazusae 107 ( with chapter 1 n165 ) ; Pindar Nemean Odes 3.28 \u039C\u03BF\u1FD6\u03C3\u03B1\u03BD \u03C6\u03AD\u03C1\u03B5\u03B9\u03BD ; cf. also in prose Plato Laws 829d .

#Text=[ back ] 83 . Ausfeld 1903 . Bremer 1981:196 prefers the division \u201C invocation , argument , and petition \u201D for actual cultic hymns . On form and composition of hymns see now Furley/Bremer I 2001:50\u201364 .

#Text=[ back ] 84 . Cf . Furley 1995 ; on the Greek hymn in general see , among others , W\u00FCnsch 1914:156\u2013170 , Key\u00DFner 1932 , Burkert 1985:102\u2013103 , Bremer 1981 , Lattke 1991:13\u201379 , Furley 1993 , Burkert 1994 , Calame 1995a:2\u20135 , and now Furley/Bremer I 2001:1\u201364 . On the place of the hymn between ritual and literature , which here occupies a central position , see the collective volume Cassio/Cerri 1991 .
#Text=[ back ] 85 . Cf . Norden 1913:143\u2013163 .

#Text=[ back ] 86 . Together with two satyrs , who have been connected by Cole 1993:31\u201333 with the comastic performers of this song , a naked and enthroned Dionysus also appears on the Karystios monument on Delos . Like his priest in Athens in the theater of Dionysus , on Delos the god himself had the right of proedria and was thus imagined as being present in an immediate sense .

#Text=[ back ] 87 . Cf . K\u00E4ppel 1992:54 and 330 ( test . 100 ) on Delos . This could also perhaps be assumed for fragment b because of the intensive style of speech , which K\u00E4ppel emphasizes as a characteristic of the genre . He does not , however , consider the text a paean . Sacrifice and symposium could also be made out to be possible connecting links in terms of occasion , although the important generic characteristic of the epiphthegma is not present . The metrical structure , but more particularly the framework of the inverted world , the element of the phallic and ridicule , are unusual for a paean . To sum up , one can say that this catchy folk song of the Hellenistic period integrates elements of the paean . Ghiron-Bistagne 1976:208\u2013209 and 245 call the phallic songs paeans .

#Text=[ back ] 88 . Cf . Kugelmeier 1996:152\u2013154 . The question continues to be posed ; Kugelmeier follows the majority of scholars in thinking that the scene in the Acharnians cannot be viewed as a copy of a phallic procession . For an approach to the problem using another formulation , see below , pp. 314\u2013325 .
#Text=[ back ] 89 . Kugelmeier 1996:154 .

#Text=[ back ] 90 . Bing 1988:22\u201323 connects the insistence on innovation with literacy and shows that the motif is especially typical of the Hellenistic period . But the topos goes back all the way to the archaic period . Among the older evidence he cites fragment 851b PMG besides Hesiod , Pindar , and Timotheos . Hellenistic poets introduced innovation in the category of the book in particular . Bing mentions Meleager \u2019s Garland , Palatine Anthology 4.1.55 , where the author calls his poems \u1F14\u03C1\u03BD\u03B5\u03B1 \u03C0\u03BF\u03BB\u03BB\u1F70 \u03BD\u03B5\u03CC\u03B3\u03C1\u03B1\u03C6\u03B1 ; similarly Philippos \u2019 Garland , Palatine Anthology 4.2.3 ; Boiskos of Kyzikos Suppl . Hell . 233.1 : \u03BA\u03B1\u03B9\u03BD\u03BF\u1FE6 \u03B3\u03C1\u03B1\u03C6\u03B5\u1F7A\u03C2 \u03C0\u03BF\u03B9\u03AE\u03BC\u03B1\u03C4\u03BF\u03C2 ; and Philikos of Corcyra Suppl . Hell . 677 : \u03BA\u03B1\u03B9\u03BD\u03BF\u03B3\u03C1\u03AC\u03C6\u03BF\u03C5 \u03C3\u03C5\u03BD\u03B8\u03AD\u03C3\u03B5\u03C9\u03C2 ( the last two poets thereby foreground their metrical innovations) . On the emphasis of the new in the living choral culture , see below , n93 . Henrichs 1993a:175\u2013177 also refers to the ancient tradition of this topos , which goes back to Pindar and Aristophanes ; ibid. , 176\u2013177n12 . He also includes fragment 851b PMG in this context , following Bing 1988:22 . For Aristophanes see now also Bierl 2004a:1\u20138 . For the motif of superiority , self-promotion , and originality in choral lyric , see Maehler 1963:93\u2013101 and Mastromarco 1987:83 with n17 . For emphasis on innovation in Hellenistic poetry , see Parsons 1993:163\u2013166 .

#Text=[ back ] 91 . The accumulation of \u201C a \u201D sounds is striking , as is the alliteration of \u03BA and \u03B1 , the homoioteleuta in -\u03BF\u03BD and -\u03B1\u03BD , the chiasmus stretching over five lines , \u03C4\u03AC\u03BD\u03B4\u03B5 \u03BC\u03BF\u1FE6\u03C3\u03B1\u03BD \u1F00\u03B3\u03BB\u03B1\u0390\u03B6\u03BF\u03BC\u03B5\u03BD and \u03BA\u03B1\u03C4\u03AC\u03C1\u03C7\u03BF\u03BC\u03B5\u03BD \u03C4\u1F78\u03BD \u1F55\u03BC\u03BD\u03BF\u03BD , the prominent antitheses and parallelisms : \u03C3\u03BF\u03AF , \u0392\u03AC\u03BA\u03C7\u03B5 , \u03C4\u03AC\u03BD\u03B4\u03B5 \u03BC\u03BF\u1FE6\u03C3\u03B1\u03BD \u1F00\u03B3\u03BB\u03B1\u0390\u03B6\u03BF\u03BC\u03B5\u03BD , | \u1F01\u03C0\u03BB\u03BF\u1FE6\u03BD \u1FE5\u03C5\u03B8\u03BC\u1F78\u03BD \u03C7\u03AD\u03BF\u03BD\u03C4\u03B5\u03C2 \u03B1\u1F30\u03CC\u03BB\u1FF3 \u03BC\u03AD\u03BB\u03B5\u03B9 , | \u03BA\u03B1\u03B9\u03BD\u1F70\u03BD \u1F00\u03C0\u03B1\u03C1\u03B8\u03AD\u03BD\u03B5\u03C5\u03C4\u03BF\u03BD , \u03BF\u1F54 \u03C4\u03B9 \u03C4\u03B1\u1FD6\u03C2 \u03C0\u03AC\u03C1\u03BF\u03C2 | \u03BA\u03B5\u03C7\u03C1\u03B7\u03BC\u03AD\u03BD\u03B1\u03BD \u1FA0\u03B4\u03B1\u1FD6\u03C3\u03B9\u03BD , \u1F00\u03BB\u03BB \u2019 \u1F00\u03BA\u03AE\u03C1\u03B1\u03C4\u03BF\u03BD | \u03BA\u03B1\u03C4\u03AC\u03C1\u03C7\u03BF\u03BC\u03B5\u03BD \u03C4\u1F78\u03BD \u1F55\u03BC\u03BD\u03BF\u03BD . The song uses forms from Attic drama , in which Doric coloring in lyrical sections is characteristic ( especially \u03B1 for \u03B7) . The doricisms do not go as far , for example , as using the Doric first-person plural ending -\u03BC\u03B5\u03C2 that is typical for Sikyon . The fragment is associated with this city because of the Phallophoroi mentioned immediately before this in Athenaeus ( Athenaeus 621f) . Perhaps the fragment is even a quotation from a contemporary Attic comedy ( from the fourth century [ ? ] ; see below , n123) .

#Text=[ back ] 92 . On the poetic structure of ritual , see Tambiah 1985:165 ( with reference 389n52 to Jakobson \u2019s \u201C poetic function , \u201D Jakobson 1960:358 [ cf. Selected Writings III , 27]) . Nagy 1990:33 rightly also connects song culture ( SONG ) to this ritual speech .

#Text=[ back ] 93 . Cf . Burkert 1985:103 : \u201C Although the names and basic rhythms of the dances are traditional , the cult in no way demands the repetition of ancient , magically fixed hymns . On the contrary , the hymn must always delight the god afresh at the festival ; therefore for dance and hymn there must always be someone who makes it , the poet , poietes . \u201D Cf . also Herter 1947:26 : \u201C es steckt darin auch schwerlich die Spekulation auf die Neugier des Publikums , die schon sp\u00E4teren Rhapsoden nicht fremd war , oder auch die Originalit\u00E4tssucht , die seit Pratinas , Kinesias und Timotheos das Programm so vieler Dichter bestimmt hat . Zwar haben sich gerade die attischen Komiker etwas darauf zugute getan , wenn sie eine \u2018 neue Idee \u2019 vorbringen konnten , aber ihre kultischen Vorl\u00E4ufer empfinden noch ganz unmittelbar , da\u00DF der Gottheit etwas Frisches und Unber\u00FChrtes als Weihegabe gef\u00E4llt \u201D [ \u201C this is unlikely to represent an attempt to gain the audience \u2019s curiosity , which was already a concern of the later rhapsodes , nor the quest for originality that had shaped the program of so many poets since Pratinas , Kinesias , and Timotheos . While it was advantageous for Attic comic playwrights if they could present a \u2018 new idea , \u2019 their cultic predecessors still had a direct sense that the god is pleased by an offering that is fresh and untouched \u201D ] . The one need not of course exclude the other . The interest of the spectators clearly also had to be awakened . Pickard-Cambridge 1962:141 seems to indicate the connections in the following statement , when he says that singers wanted to give the impression of improvisation ( \u201C no doubt supposed to be improvised on the spot\u201D) . All the same , he continues on the basis of the thesis that the text has a strongly Hellenistic form . But the improvisations only actually start after the song . For innovation as a requirement for comedy ( cf. now also Bierl 2002a ) and for novelty in Aristophanes Thesmophoriazusae 967 as a parabasis-like statement ( with comparable passages ) , see above , chapter 1 n49 ; cf. also the relative \u2019s remark about Euripides \u2019 \u201C new \u201D Helen ( Thesmophoriazusae 850 : \u03C4\u1F74\u03BD \u03BA\u03B1\u03B9\u03BD\u1F74\u03BD \u1F19\u03BB\u03AD\u03BD\u03B7\u03BD \u03BC\u03B9\u03BC\u03AE\u03C3\u03BF\u03BC\u03B1\u03B9 ) , in which Euripides \u2019 claim to originality shines through in comic fashion ; but Aristophanes \u2019 approach in this passage , namely to have the relative perform the Helen , is especially new . For Aristophanic self-advertisement , see Bremer 1993:160\u2013165 . For borrowings in parabaseis of metaphor and vocabulary in connection with personal originality and superiority in choral lyric , in particular in Pindar \u2019s epinician odes , see Mastromarco 1987:83\u201393 . [ back ] The topos of innovation in song is not a Hellenistic invention , but begins at a very early stage : Homer Odyssey 1.351\u2013352 : \u03C4\u1F74\u03BD \u03B3\u1F70\u03C1 \u1F00\u03BF\u03B9\u03B4\u1F74\u03BD \u03BC\u1FB6\u03BB\u03BB\u03BF\u03BD \u1F10\u03C0\u03B9\u03BA\u03BB\u03B5\u03AF\u03BF\u03C5\u03C3 \u2019 \u1F04\u03BD\u03B8\u03C1\u03C9\u03C0\u03BF\u03B9 , | \u1F25 \u03C4\u03B9\u03C2 \u1F00\u03CA\u03CC\u03BD\u03C4\u03B5\u03C3\u03C3\u03B9 \u03BD\u03B5\u03C9\u03C4\u03AC\u03C4\u03B7 \u1F00\u03BC\u03C6\u03B9\u03C0\u03AD\u03BB\u03B7\u03C4\u03B1\u03B9 ; Hesiod ( fragment 357.2 M.-W . ) reports how he and Homer sang songs on Delos : \u1F10\u03BD \u03BD\u03B5\u03B1\u03C1\u03BF\u1FD6\u03C2 \u1F55\u03BC\u03BD\u03BF\u03B9\u03C2 \u1FE5\u03AC\u03C8\u03B1\u03BD\u03C4\u03B5\u03C2 \u1F00\u03BF\u03B9\u03B4\u03AE\u03BD ; Alcman fragment 3\u2013fragment 1.1\u20132 Davies : \u1F48\u03BB]\u03C5\u03BC\u03C0\u03B9\u03AC\u03B4\u03B5\u03C2 \u03C0\u03B5\u03C1\u03AF \u03BC\u03B5 \u03C6\u03C1\u03AD\u03BD\u03B1\u03C2 | \u1F31\u03BC\u03AD\u03C1\u1FF3 \u03BD\u03AD\u03B1]\u03C2 \u1F00\u03BF\u03B9\u03B4\u03B1\u03C2 ( with Page \u2019s supplement CR 9 [ 1959]:16 ) ; Alcman fragment 4\u2013fragment 1.5\u20136 Davies : \u03B3\u03B1\u03C1\u03CD\u03BC\u03B1\u03C4\u03B1 \u03BC\u03B1\u03BB\u03C3\u03B1\u03BA\u1F70\u0323 [ | \u03BD\u03B5\u03CC\u03C7\u03BC \u2019 \u1F14\u03B4\u03B5\u03B9\u03BE\u03B1\u03BD ; Alcman fragment 14a Davies : \u039C\u1FF6\u03C3 \u2019 \u1F04\u03B3\u03B5 , \u039C\u1FF6\u03C3\u03B1 \u03BB\u03AF\u03B3\u03B7\u03B1 \u03C0\u03BF\u03BB\u03C5\u03BC\u03BC\u03B5\u03BB\u1F72\u03C2 | \u03B1\u1F30\u1F72\u03BD \u1F00\u03BF\u03B9\u03B4\u1F72 \u03BC\u03AD\u03BB\u03BF\u03C2 | \u03BD\u03B5\u03BF\u03C7\u03BC\u1F78\u03BD \u1F04\u03C1\u03C7\u03B5 \u03C0\u03B1\u03C1\u03C3\u03AD\u03BD\u03BF\u03B9\u03C2 \u1F00\u03B5\u03AF\u03B4\u03B7\u03BD ; Terpander fragment 6 Loeb ( = 4 Gostoli ) ( PMG , p. 363 ) : \u03C3\u03BF\u1F76 \u03B4 \u2019 \u1F21\u03BC\u03B5\u1FD6\u03C2 \u03C4\u03B5\u03C4\u03C1\u03AC\u03B3\u03B7\u03C1\u03C5\u03BD \u1F00\u03C0\u03BF\u03C3\u03C4\u03AD\u03C1\u03BE\u03B1\u03BD\u03C4\u03B5\u03C2 \u1F00\u03BF\u03B9\u03B4\u1F70\u03BD | \u1F11\u03C0\u03C4\u03B1\u03C4\u03CC\u03BD\u1FF3 \u03C6\u03CC\u03C1\u03BC\u03B9\u03B3\u03B3\u03B9 \u03BD\u03AD\u03BF\u03C5\u03C2 \u03BA\u03B5\u03BB\u03B1\u03B4\u03AE\u03C3\u03BF\u03BC\u03B5\u03BD \u1F55\u03BC\u03BD\u03BF\u03C5\u03C2 ; Pindar Nemean Odes 8.20\u201321 : \u03C0\u03BF\u03BB\u03BB\u1F70 \u03B3\u1F70\u03C1 \u03C0\u03BF\u03BB\u03BB\u1FB7 \u03BB\u03AD\u03BB\u03B5\u03BA\u03C4\u03B1\u03B9 , \u03BD\u03B5\u03B1\u03C1\u1F70 \u03B4 \u2019 \u1F10\u03BE\u03B5\u03C5\u03C1\u03CC\u03BD\u03C4\u03B1 \u03B4\u03CC\u03BC\u03B5\u03BD \u03B2\u03B1\u03C3\u03AC\u03BD\u1FF3 | \u1F10\u03C2 \u1F14\u03BB\u03B5\u03B3\u03C7\u03BF\u03BD , \u1F05\u03C0\u03B1\u03C2 \u03BA\u03AF\u03BD\u03B4\u03C5\u03BD\u03BF\u03C2 ; Pindar Olympian Odes 3.4\u20136 : \u039C\u03BF\u1FD6\u03C3\u03B1 \u03B4 \u2019 \u03BF\u1F55\u03C4\u03C9 \u03C0\u03BF\u03B9 \u03C0\u03B1\u03C1\u03AD- | \u03C3\u03C4\u03B1 \u03BC\u03BF\u03B9 \u03BD\u03B5\u03BF\u03C3\u03AF\u03B3\u03B1\u03BB\u03BF\u03BD \u03B5\u1F51\u03C1\u03CC\u03BD\u03C4\u03B9 \u03C4\u03C1\u03CC\u03C0\u03BF\u03BD | \u0394\u03C9\u03C1\u03AF\u1FF3 \u03C6\u03C9\u03BD\u1F70\u03BD \u1F10\u03BD\u03B1\u03C1\u03BC\u03CC\u03BE\u03B1\u03B9 \u03C0\u03B5\u03B4\u03AF\u03BB\u1FF3 | \u1F00\u03B3\u03BB\u03B1\u03CC\u03BA\u03C9\u03BC\u03BF\u03BD ; Pindar Olympian Odes 9.48\u201349 : \u03B1\u1F34\u03BD\u03B5\u03B9 \u03B4\u1F72 \u03C0\u03B1\u03BB\u03B1\u03B9\u1F78\u03BD \u03BC\u1F72\u03BD \u03BF\u1F36\u03BD\u03BF\u03BD , \u1F04\u03BD\u03B8\u03B5\u03B1 \u03B4 \u2019 \u1F55\u03BC\u03BD\u03C9\u03BD | \u03BD\u03B5\u03C9\u03C4\u03AD\u03C1\u03C9\u03BD ; Bacchylides Dithyrambs 19.8\u201310 : \u1F55\u03C6\u03B1\u03B9\u03BD\u03AD \u03BD\u03C5\u03BD \u1F10\u03BD | \u03C4\u03B1\u1FD6\u03C2 \u03C0\u03BF\u03BB\u03C5\u03B7\u03C1\u03AC\u03C4\u03BF\u03B9\u03C2 \u03C4\u03B9 \u03BA\u03B1\u03B9\u03BD\u1F78\u03BD | \u1F40\u03BB\u03B2\u03AF\u03B1\u03B9\u03C2 \u1F08\u03B8\u03AE\u03BD\u03B1\u03B9\u03C2 ; Euripides Trojan Women 512\u2013513 : \u039C\u03BF\u1FE6\u03C3\u03B1 , \u03BA\u03B1\u03B9\u03BD\u1FF6\u03BD \u1F55\u03BC\u03BD\u03C9\u03BD | \u1F86\u03C3\u03BF\u03BD \u03C3\u1F7A\u03BD \u03B4\u03B1\u03BA\u03C1\u03CD\u03BF\u03B9\u03C2 \u1FA0\u03B4\u1F70\u03BD \u1F10\u03C0\u03B9\u03BA\u03AE\u03B4\u03B5\u03B9\u03BF\u03BD ; Xenophon Cyropaedia 1.6.38 : \u1F10\u03BD \u03C4\u03BF\u1FD6\u03C2 \u03BC\u03BF\u03C5\u03C3\u03B9\u03BA\u03BF\u1FD6\u03C2 \u03C4\u1F70 \u03BD\u03AD\u03B1 \u03BA\u03B1\u1F76 \u1F00\u03BD\u03B8\u03B7\u03C1\u1F70 \u03B5\u1F50\u03B4\u03BF\u03BA\u03B9\u03BC\u03B5\u1FD6 . This motif appears particularly clearly in Timotheos fragment 796 PMG : \u03BF\u1F50\u03BA \u1F00\u03B5\u03AF\u03B4\u03C9 \u03C4\u1F70 \u03C0\u03B1\u03BB\u03B1\u03B9\u03AC , | \u03BA\u03B1\u03B9\u03BD\u1F70 \u03B3\u1F70\u03C1 \u1F00\u03BC\u1F70 \u03BA\u03C1\u03B5\u03AF\u03C3\u03C3\u03C9\u00B7 | \u03BD\u03AD\u03BF\u03C2 \u1F41 \u0396\u03B5\u1F7A\u03C2 \u03B2\u03B1\u03C3\u03B9\u03BB\u03B5\u03CD\u03B5\u03B9 , | \u03C4\u1F78 \u03C0\u03AC\u03BB\u03B1\u03B9 \u03B4 \u2019 \u1F26\u03BD \u039A\u03C1\u03CC\u03BD\u03BF\u03C2 \u1F04\u03C1\u03C7\u03C9\u03BD\u00B7 | \u1F00\u03C0\u03AF\u03C4\u03C9 \u039C\u03BF\u1FE6\u03C3\u03B1 \u03C0\u03B1\u03BB\u03B1\u03B9\u03AC . Cf . also Timotheos in his Persians , where he talks of how the Spartans brought him to account \u201C because I dishonor the older muse with new hymns \u201D fragments 791 , 211\u2013212 PMG ( \u1F45\u03C4\u03B9 \u03C0\u03B1\u03BB\u03B1\u03B9\u03BF\u03C4\u03AD\u03C1\u03B1\u03BD \u03BD\u03AD\u03BF\u03B9\u03C2 | \u1F55\u03BC\u03BD\u03BF\u03B9\u03C2 \u03BC\u03BF\u1FE6\u03C3\u03B1\u03BD \u1F00\u03C4\u03B9\u03BC\u1FF6 ) ; cf. the invocation of the paean that appears shortly before this , Timotheus fragments 791 , 202\u2013203 PMG : \u1F00\u03BB\u03BB \u2019 \u1F66 \u03C7\u03C1\u03C5\u03C3\u03B5\u03BF\u03BA\u03AF\u03B8\u03B1\u03C1\u03B9\u03BD \u1F00\u03AD- | \u03BE\u03C9\u03BD \u03BC\u03BF\u1FE6\u03C3\u03B1\u03BD \u03BD\u03B5\u03BF\u03C4\u03B5\u03C5\u03C7\u1FC6 . Cf . also carm . conviv . fragment 917c , 3\u20134 PMG : \u1F04\u03C1\u03C4\u03B9 \u03B2\u03C1\u03CD\u03BF\u03C5\u03C3\u03B1\u03BD \u1F00\u03BF\u03B9\u03B4\u1F70\u03BD | \u03C0\u03C1\u03C9\u03C4\u03BF\u03C0\u03B1\u03B3\u03B5\u1FD6 \u03C3\u03BF\u03C6\u03AF\u1FB3 \u03B4\u03B9\u03B1\u03C0\u03BF\u03AF\u03BA\u03B9\u03BB\u03BF\u03BD \u1F10\u03BA\u03C6\u03AD\u03C1\u03BF\u03BC\u03B5\u03BD ( as in fragment 851b PMG the skolion also belongs to the poetry of everyday use ; it is performed in the symposium as an expression of a living song culture by a group that appears in the performative verb form in the first-person plural) . Cf . also the insistence on originality in Pratinas fragment 710 PMG : \u03BF\u1F50 \u03B3\u1FB6\u03BD \u03B1\u1F50\u03BB\u03B1\u03BA\u03B9\u03C3\u03BC\u03AD\u03BD\u03B1\u03BD | \u1F00\u03C1\u1FF6\u03BD \u1F00\u03BB\u03BB \u2019 \u1F04\u03C3\u03BA\u03B1\u03C6\u03BF\u03BD \u03BC\u03B1\u03C4\u03B5\u03CD\u03C9\u03BD , and Kinesias in Aristophanes Birds 1376 : . . . \u03BD\u03AD\u03B1\u03BD ( i.e. \u1F41\u03B4\u1F78\u03BD ) \u1F10\u03C6\u03AD\u03C0\u03C9\u03BD and ibid. , 1384\u20131385 : \u03BA\u03B1\u03B9\u03BD\u1F70\u03C2 . . . \u1F00\u03BD\u03B1\u03B2\u03BF\u03BB\u03AC\u03C2 . [ back ] After Pindar and Aristophanes one may observe in Timotheos , Kinesias , and Pratinas , parallel to the transformation of culture by writing , a radicalization in the construction of artistic consciousness that leads to the Hellenistic practice . But the transitions are fluid ; in performance the motif is additionally seen as a self-referential confirmation of the ritual . In comedy , with Aristophanes we are still partly on the side of ritual , while similar utterances in Middle and New Comedy refer also to Hellenistic practice . Yet the theme of innovation is also part and parcel of the comic : one can laugh only about something that is new . Cf . now also Bierl 2002a . Because of the inversion of the world on the level of signs in the situational context it is even conceivable that comic elements appeared in the actual hymn .

#Text=[ back ] 94 . Cf . Pindar fragment 75.7\u20138 : \u0394\u03B9\u03CC\u03B8\u03B5\u03BD \u03C4\u03AD \u03BC\u03B5 \u03C3\u1F7A\u03BD \u1F00\u03B3\u03BB\u03B1\u0390\u1FB3 | \u1F34\u03B4\u03B5\u03C4\u03B5 \u03C0\u03BF\u03C1\u03B5\u03C5\u03B8\u03AD\u03BD\u03C4 \u2019 \u1F00\u03BF\u03B9\u03B4\u1FB6\u03BD ( in the self-referential and performative combination of song , dance , and music of the aulos , lines 18\u201319 ) and fragment 148 S.-M . : \u1F40\u03C1\u03C7\u03AE\u03C3\u03C4 \u2019 \u1F00\u03B3\u03BB\u03B1\u0390\u03B1\u03C2 \u1F00\u03BD\u03AC\u03C3\u03C3\u03C9\u03BD , \u03B5\u1F50\u03C1\u03C5\u03C6\u03AC\u03C1\u03B5\u03C4\u03C1 \u2019 \u1F0C\u03C0\u03BF\u03BB\u03BB\u03BF\u03BD ( for Apollo as dancer ) , here in connection with dance . For the kharis of choral dancing , cf. above , chapter 1 n92 . On \u1F00\u03B3\u03BB\u03B1\u0390\u03B6\u03C9 : the verb appears with the same meaning in Theocritus Epigrammata 1.4 . Cf . Etymologicum Magnum ( 9.52 ) , s.v. \u1F00\u03B3\u1FC6\u03BB\u03B1\u03B9\u00B7 \u03C4\u03B9\u03BC\u1FC6\u03C3\u03B1\u03B9 \u03B8\u03B5\u03CC\u03BD , \u1F00\u03B3\u03BB\u03B1\u0390\u03C3\u03B1\u03B9 ( = among others Lex . Bachm . [ 11 , 18 ] ) ; cf. K.-A . on Eupolis fragment 131 . Cf . \u1F10\u03C0\u03B1\u03B3\u03BB\u03B1\u0390\u03B6\u03C9 in Aristophanes Assemblywomen 575 ( \u201C praise \u201D ) , and Aristophanes fragment 700 K.-A . , Cratin . fragment 334 K.-A . ( \u201C make pure \u201D ) ; according to LSJ , s.v. , \u1F00\u03B3\u03BB\u03B1\u0390\u03B6\u03C9 never appears in Attic prose , which fits the song theory .

#Text=[ back ] 95 . The Kharites dance at the weddings of both Cadmus and Peleus ( Quintus Smyrnaeus . 4.140) . Furthermore , the verb is also reminiscent of Aglauros , who together with the other daughters of Cecrops also represents a dancing thiasos .

#Text=[ back ] 96 . Cf . Bacchylides Epinician Odes 3.5\u20136 ( in connection with Nike ) : \u03C3\u03B5\u03CD\u03BF\u03BD]\u03C4\u03BF \u03B3\u1F70\u03C1 \u03C3\u1F7A\u03BD \u1F51\u03C0\u03B5\u03C1\u03CC\u03C7\u1FF3 \u03C4\u03B5 \u039D\u03AF\u03BA\u1FB3 | \u03C3\u1F7A\u03BD \u1F08\u03B3]\u03BB\u03B1\u0390\u1FB3 . . . Splendor and the personification Aglaia are necessary elements for victory and are central aspects of the victory celebration ; hence the importance of the word in epinicians . The three Kharites are addressed in self-referential form as the appropriate guarantors of the subsequent k\u00F4mos : cf. Pindar Olympian Odes 14.13\u201317 : \u03C0\u03CC\u03C4\u03BD\u03B9 \u2019 \u1F08\u03B3\u03BB\u03B1\u0390\u03B1 | \u03C6\u03B9\u03BB\u03B7\u03C3\u03AF\u03BC\u03BF\u03BB\u03C0\u03AD \u03C4 \u2019 \u0395\u1F50\u03C6\u03C1\u03BF\u03C3\u03CD\u03BD\u03B1 , \u03B8\u03B5\u1FF6\u03BD \u03BA\u03C1\u03B1\u03C4\u03AF\u03C3\u03C4\u03BF\u03C5 | \u03C0\u03B1\u1FD6\u03B4\u03B5\u03C2 , \u1F10\u03C0\u03B1\u03BA\u03BF\u03BF\u1FD6\u03C4\u03B5 \u03BD\u1FE6\u03BD , \u0398\u03B1\u03BB\u03AF\u03B1 \u03C4\u03B5 | \u1F10\u03C1\u03B1\u03C3\u03AF\u03BC\u03BF\u03BB\u03C0\u03B5 , \u1F30\u03B4\u03BF\u1FD6\u03C3\u03B1 \u03C4\u03CC\u03BD\u03B4\u03B5 \u03BA\u1FF6\u03BC\u03BF\u03BD \u1F10\u03C0 \u2019 \u03B5\u1F50\u03BC\u03B5\u03BD\u03B5\u1FD6 \u03C4\u03CD\u03C7\u1FB3 | \u03BA\u03BF\u1FE6\u03C6\u03B1 \u03B2\u03B9\u03B2\u1FF6\u03BD\u03C4\u03B1 . On the poetically-shaped names of the Kharites , see also Kannicht 1989:31 . On the shining of the k\u00F4mos , cf. Pindar Olympian Odes 3.5\u20136 : \u03C6\u03C9\u03BD\u1F70\u03BD . . . \u1F00\u03B3\u03BB\u03B1\u03CC\u03BA\u03C9\u03BC\u03BF\u03BD . K\u00F4mos and victory are also of importance in this song . On dancing and splendor , Pindar Pythian Odes 1.2 : \u03B2\u03AC\u03C3\u03B9\u03C2 \u1F00\u03B3\u03BB\u03B1\u0390\u03B1\u03C2 \u1F00\u03C1\u03C7\u03AC .
#Text=[ back ] 97 . Solon fragment 1.1 G.-P . : \u1F00\u03B3\u03BB\u03B1\u1F70 \u03C4\u03AD\u03BA\u03BD\u03B1 .

#Text=[ back ] 98 . Cf . the adjective \u1F00\u03B3\u03BB\u03B1\u03CC\u03C2 , \u201C shining , \u201D \u201C glowing , \u201D \u201C shimmering \u201D ; cf. the epithet in connection with the liquid nature of water , \u1F00\u03B3\u03BB\u03B1\u1F78\u03BD \u1F55\u03B4\u03C9\u03C1 ( Homer Iliad 2.307 ) ; \u1F00\u03B3\u03BB\u03B1\u0390\u03B6\u03C9 thus extends beyond the meaning \u201C give as an honour \u201D that LSJ , s.v. \u1F00\u03B3\u03BB\u03B1\u0390\u03B6\u03C9 I.2 assign it in this passage ( on the meaning \u201C praise , \u201D \u201C honor , \u201D see above , n94 ) , which Campbell 1993:239 translates accordingly as : \u201C To you , Bacchus , we give glory with this music . \u201D It also implies in a quite concrete sense the splendor and glow of the song , the performance , and the Dionysiac drink . For the combination with offerings that decorate the sanctuary , cf. Isyllus , Paean in Aesculapium ( Powell 1925:132\u2013136 , 133 = K\u00E4ppel 1992:380\u2013383 , 381\u2013Pai . 40 ) , line 28 : \u03B8\u03C5\u03C3\u03AF\u03B1\u03B9\u03C2 \u1F20\u03B3\u03BB\u03AC\u03B9\u03C3\u03B5\u03BD \u03C4\u03AD\u03BC\u03B5\u03BD\u03BF\u03C2 .

#Text=[ back ] 99 . For \u1FE5\u03C5\u03B8\u03BC\u03CC\u03C2 as the ordering of movement ( \u1F21 \u03C4\u1FC6\u03C2 \u03BA\u03B9\u03BD\u03AE\u03C3\u03B5\u03C9\u03C2 \u03C4\u03AC\u03BE\u03B9\u03C2 ) , cf. Plato Laws 665a : \u03C4\u1FC7 \u03B4\u1F74 \u03C4\u1FC6\u03C2 \u03BA\u03B9\u03BD\u03AE\u03C3\u03B5\u03C9\u03C2 \u03C4\u03AC\u03BE\u03B5\u03B9 \u1FE5\u03C5\u03B8\u03BC\u1F78\u03C2 \u1F44\u03BD\u03BF\u03BC\u03B1 \u03B5\u1F34\u03B7 , \u03C4\u1FC7 \u03B4\u1F72 \u03B1\u1F56 \u03C4\u1FC6\u03C2 \u03C6\u03C9\u03BD\u1FC6\u03C2 , \u03C4\u03BF\u1FE6 \u03C4\u03B5 \u1F40\u03BE\u03AD\u03BF\u03C2 \u1F05\u03BC\u03B1 \u03BA\u03B1\u1F76 \u03B2\u03B1\u03C1\u03AD\u03BF\u03C2 \u03C3\u03C5\u03B3\u03BA\u03B5-\u03C1\u03B1\u03BD\u03BD\u03C5\u03BC\u03AD\u03BD\u03C9\u03BD , \u1F01\u03C1\u03BC\u03BF\u03BD\u03AF\u03B1 \u1F44\u03BD\u03BF\u03BC\u03B1 \u03C0\u03C1\u03BF\u03C3\u03B1\u03B3\u03BF\u03C1\u03B5\u03CD\u03BF\u03B9\u03C4\u03BF , \u03C7\u03BF\u03C1\u03B5\u03AF\u03B1 \u03B4\u1F72 \u03C4\u1F78 \u03C3\u03C5\u03BD\u03B1\u03BC\u03C6\u03CC\u03C4\u03B5\u03C1\u03BF\u03BD \u03BA\u03BB\u03B7\u03B8\u03B5\u03AF\u03B7 . In connection with movement in dance , cf. Aristophanes Thesmophoriazusae 955a/b : \u1FE5\u03C5\u03B8- | \u03BC\u1F78\u03BD \u03C7\u03BF\u03C1\u03B5\u03AF\u03B1\u03C2 ; Plato Laws 670b : \u03B2\u03B1\u03AF\u03BD\u03B5\u03B9\u03BD \u1F10\u03BD \u1FE5\u03C5\u03B8\u03BC\u1FF7 ; Xenophon Cyropaedia . 1.3.10 : \u1F40\u03C1\u03C7\u03B5\u1FD6\u03C3\u03B8\u03B1\u03B9 \u1F10\u03BD \u1FE5\u03C5\u03B8\u03BC\u1FF7 . Without indicating parallels Thiele 1902:409n3 thinks that the expression \u1FE5\u03C5\u03B8\u03BC\u1F78\u03BD \u03C7\u03AD\u03B5\u03B9\u03BD is \u201C gut und alt \u201D [ \u201C good and old \u201D ] . Cf . the passages in LSJ , s.v. \u03C7\u03AD\u03C9 III.1 \u201C of the voice\u201D\u2014e.g . Homer Odyssey 19.521 : \u03C7\u03AD\u03B5\u03B9 \u03C0\u03BF\u03BB\u03C5\u03B4\u03B5\u03C5\u03BA\u03AD\u03B1 \u03C6\u03C9\u03BD\u03AE\u03BD ; Pindar Isthmian Odes 8.58 : \u1F10\u03C0\u1F76 \u03B8\u03C1\u1FC6\u03BD\u03CC\u03BD \u03C4\u03B5 \u03C0\u03BF\u03BB\u03CD\u03C6\u03B1\u03BC\u03BF\u03BD \u1F14\u03C7\u03B5\u03B1\u03BD ; Aeschylus Suppliants 631\u2013632 : \u03BA\u03BB\u03CD\u03BF\u03B9\u03C4 \u2019 \u03B5\u1F50\u03BA\u03C4\u03B1\u1FD6\u03B1 \u03B3\u03AD\u03BD\u03B5\u03B9 \u03C7\u03B5\u03BF\u03CD\u03C3\u03B1\u03C2 ; and especially Aristophanes Wasps 1020 ( parabasis ) : \u03BA\u03C9\u03BC\u1FF3\u03B4\u03B9\u03BA\u1F70 \u03C0\u03BF\u03BB\u03BB\u1F70 \u03C7\u03AD\u03B1\u03C3\u03B8\u03B1\u03B9 . On the metaphorical combination \u1F55\u03BC\u03BD\u03BF\u03C5\u03C2 \u03BF\u1F30\u03BD\u03BF\u03C7\u03BF\u03B5\u1FD6\u03BD , see Dionysius Elegiacus 3.1 G.-P . ( for the combination of wine and poetry , see also Dionysius Elegiacus 1.1\u20132) . [ back ] In Anaphe , men and women indulge in mutual ridicule during sacrifice to Apollo Aigletes ( Apollonius of Rhodes 4.1713\u20131730 ) ; Apollo and Dionysus are particularly connected with splendor and the k\u00F4mos . Ritual ridicule , sacrifice , emphasis on shining appearance , and elements of an inverted world are also found in a ritual context in the Thesmophoriazusae and our fragment . Cf . the remarks on Thesmophoriazusae 101\u2013129 above , pp. 137\u2013149 ; on Apollo \u2019s splendor and performance , cf. especially Thesmophoriazusae 126\u2013128 ; the self-command \u1F04\u03B3\u03B1\u03BB\u03BB\u03B5 is identical with the performers \u2019 \u1F00\u03B3\u03BB\u03B1\u0390\u03B6\u03BF\u03BC\u03B5\u03BD . Cf . Etymologicum Magnum ( 9.52 ) , s.v. \u1F00\u03B3\u1FC6\u03BB\u03B1\u03B9\u00B7 \u03C4\u03B9\u03BC\u1FC6\u03C3\u03B1\u03B9 \u03B8\u03B5\u03CC\u03BD , \u1F00\u03B3\u03BB\u03B1\u0390\u03C3\u03B1\u03B9 ( = among others Lex . Bachm . [ 11 , 18 ] ) with the form \u1F04\u03B3\u03B1\u03BB\u03BB\u03B5 Thesmophoriazusae 128 ; cf. further K.-A . on Eupolis fragment 131 ( PCG V , 371) . \u039A\u03C9\u03BC\u03B1\u1FD6\u03BF\u03C2 is also a name given to Apollo in Naukratis ; see also Ghiron-Bistagne 1976:273 , who identifies the Apollo ( ibid. , 275 ) on a Laconian cup ( ibid. , fig. 127 , Museum of Tarento 20909 ) as this Komaios .

#Text=[ back ] 100 . For \u03B1\u1F30\u03CC\u03BB\u1FF3 \u03BC\u03AD\u03BB\u03B5\u03B9 cf. Lycophron Alexandra 671 ; cf. Telestes fragment 806.3\u20134 PMG : \u03B1\u1F30\u03BF\u03BB\u03BF\u03BC\u03CC\u03C1\u03C6\u03BF\u03B9\u03C2 ( coni . Wilamowitz , adopted by Campbell 1993 , 128 ) | . . . \u03BA\u03B1\u03BB\u03AC\u03BC\u03BF\u03B9\u03C2 . \u201C Quickly moving \u201D : Homer Iliad 19.404 : \u03C0\u03CC\u03B4\u03B1\u03C2 \u03B1\u1F30\u03CC\u03BB\u03BF\u03C2 \u1F35\u03C0\u03C0\u03BF\u03C2 ; \u201C glittering \u201D : of objects , e.g. \u03C4\u03B5\u03CD\u03C7\u03B5\u03B1 , Homer Iliad 5.294\u2013295 ; especially of music and dance : Euripides Ion 499 : \u1F51\u03C0 \u2019 \u03B1\u1F30\u03CC\u03BB\u03B1\u03C2 \u1F30\u03B1\u03C7\u1FB6\u03C2 ; in the context of choral projection Ion 492ff . ( on the Makrai rocks , where the Aglauridai perform their choruses in front of the temple of Athena ) ; Aristophanes Frogs 247\u2013248 : \u1F14\u03BD\u03C5\u03B4\u03C1\u03BF\u03BD \u1F10\u03BD \u03B2\u03C5\u03B8\u1FF7 \u03C7\u03BF\u03C1\u03B5\u03AF\u03B1\u03BD | \u03B1\u1F30\u03CC\u03BB\u03B1\u03BD \u1F10\u03C6\u03B8\u03B5\u03B3\u03BE\u03AC\u03BC\u03B5\u03C3\u03B8\u03B1 ( in the song of the Frogs , which bears a great similarity to fragment 851b PMG in terms of performativity ; on the self-referential word \u03C7\u03BF\u03C1\u03B5\u03AF\u03B1 , cf. also Aristophanes Frogs 336 , 396\u2013397 ; cf. also Thesmophoriazusae 980b and 982) . Kugelmeier 1996:154 sees in the \u201C buntschillernden Melodie \u201D [ \u201C brightly shimmering melody \u201D ] an antithesis to the simple rhythm . Admittedly the composer of the song had no other choice but to use iamboi ; the traditional occasion , in particular the element of ridicule that follows , determines the genre ; the musical framework in comparison with everyday speech is always festive . Variation does not necessarily have to be equated with artistic intention as seen in the Hellenistic period , but is also a recognized element of ritual style .

#Text=[ back ] 101 . Cf . the synonymous \u1F00\u03BA\u03B7\u03C1\u03AC\u03C3\u03B9\u03BF\u03C2 in connection with the word wine in Homer Odyssey 9.204\u2013205 : \u03BF\u1F36\u03BD\u03BF\u03BD . . . | \u1F21\u03B4\u1F7A\u03BD \u1F00\u03BA\u03B7\u03C1\u03AC\u03C3\u03B9\u03BF\u03BD , \u03B8\u03B5\u1FD6\u03BF\u03BD \u03C0\u03BF\u03C4\u03CC\u03BD . The adjective \u1F00\u03BA\u03AE\u03C1\u03B1\u03C4\u03BF\u03C2 can be derived both from \u03BA\u03B5\u03C1\u03AC\u03C9 = \u03BA\u03B5\u03C1\u03AC\u03BD\u03BD\u03C5\u03BC\u03B9 ( i.e. meaning \u201C unmixed \u201D ; cf. Aeschylus Persians 614\u2013615 : \u1F00\u03BA\u03AE\u03C1\u03B1\u03C4\u03CC\u03BD \u03C4\u03B5 \u03BC\u03B7\u03C4\u03C1\u1F78\u03C2 \u1F00\u03B3\u03C1\u03AF\u03B1\u03C2 \u1F04\u03C0\u03BF | \u03C0\u03BF\u03C4\u03CC\u03BD ; the passage occurs in a clear description of \u03C7\u03BF\u03B1\u03AF [ ibid. , 607\u2013622 ] ) and from \u03BA\u03B7\u03C1\u03B1\u03AF\u03BD\u03C9 ( i.e. meaning \u201C unharmed , \u201D \u201C unadulterated , \u201D \u201C untouched , \u201D \u201C pure \u201D ; cf. Homer Iliad 24.303 and Theocritus Idylls 22.38 in connection with \u1F55\u03B4\u03C9\u03C1) . Cf . LSJ , s.v. The two etymologically distinct roots of the signifiers are connected on the level of the signified in terms of the concept of purity . Both meanings , that of the unmixed and that of the ritually untouched , play a part in this case and are retained when used of this claim to originality . Gold is in particular spoken of as unmixed , unadulterated , noble , and pure : cf. Archilochus fragments 91.3 and 93a , 6\u20137 . W. Unmixed wine ( like milk and honey ) is unusual and indicates a deviation from the norm : these ingredients are typical of \u03C7\u03BF\u03B1\u03AF ; cf. Aeschylus Persians 607\u2013622 ; cf. on this Graf 1980:217 : \u201C Strukturalistisch gesehen , geh\u00F6rt der ungemischte Wein auf die Seite von Milch und Honig : die M\u00E4naden schlagen denn auch , ausser Milch \u2013 und Honigquellen , solche von reinem Wein . . . Weinlose Libationen\u2014mit Honig , Milch , Wasser , Melikraton , \u00D6l\u2014und solche mit reinem Wein m\u00FCssten also zusammengehen , in Opposition zur Spende mit gemischtem Wein und dem Normalopfer , das sie begleitet , stehen \u201D [ \u201C From a structuralist point of view , unmixed wine belongs together with milk and honey : apart from striking open streams of milk and honey , the maenads also produce ones of pure wine . . . Wineless libations\u2014with honey , milk , water , melikraton , oil\u2014and those using unmixed wine thus must belong together , in opposition to libation with mixed wine and the normal sacrifice that accompanies it \u201D ] . Graf emphasizes in particular the symbolic function of pure wine ( ibid. , 219 ) : \u201C Den Austritt in die Marginalit\u00E4t bezeichnet umgekehrt unter anderem die Libation mit reinem Wein \u201D [ \u201C Libation with pure wine signifies among other things departure into marginality \u201D ] . For wineless libation , see Henrichs 1983 and Henrichs 1984 . Wine was normally drunk mixed with water . Unmixed wine , the sign of the wild and uncivilized , is only drunk by barbarians , beast-men like centaurs or satyrs , or the Cyclops in the Odyssey ( Homer Odyssey 9.345\u2013974 ) ; cf. also the barbarian and bestial in the actors \u2019 \u03BA\u03B1\u03C5\u03BD\u03AC\u03BA\u03B7 costume . [ back ] Probably precisely because of the concept of the \u1F00\u03BA\u03AE\u03C1\u03B1\u03C4\u03BF\u03BD , West treats the song fragment 851b PMG as a \u201C parody \u201D ( West 1974:36 ) or \u201C imitation \u201D ( West 1982:147n23 ) of Euripides Hippolytus 73\u201378 : \u03C3\u03BF\u1F76 \u03C4\u03CC\u03BD\u03B4\u03B5 \u03C0\u03BB\u03B5\u03BA\u03C4\u1F78\u03BD \u03C3\u03C4\u03AD\u03C6\u03B1\u03BD\u03BF\u03BD \u1F10\u03BE \u1F00\u03BA\u03B7\u03C1\u03AC\u03C4\u03BF\u03C5 | \u03BB\u03B5\u03B9\u03BC\u1FF6\u03BD\u03BF\u03C2 , \u1F66 \u03B4\u03AD\u03C3\u03C0\u03BF\u03B9\u03BD\u03B1 , \u03BA\u03BF\u03C3\u03BC\u03AE\u03C3\u03B1\u03C2 \u03C6\u03AD\u03C1\u03C9 , | \u1F14\u03BD\u03B8 \u2019 \u03BF\u1F54\u03C4\u03B5 \u03C0\u03BF\u03B9\u03BC\u1F74\u03BD \u1F00\u03BE\u03B9\u03BF\u1FD6 \u03C6\u03AD\u03C1\u03B2\u03B5\u03B9\u03BD \u03B2\u03BF\u03C4\u1F70 | \u03BF\u1F54\u03C4 \u2019 \u1F26\u03BB\u03B8\u03AD \u03C0\u03C9 \u03C3\u03AF\u03B4\u03B7\u03C1\u03BF\u03C2 , \u1F00\u03BB\u03BB \u2019 \u1F00\u03BA\u03AE\u03C1\u03B1\u03C4\u03BF\u03BD | \u03BC\u03AD\u03BB\u03B9\u03C3\u03C3\u03B1 \u03BB\u03B5\u03B9\u03BC\u1FF6\u03BD \u2019 \u1F20\u03C1\u03B9\u03BD\u1F74 \u03B4\u03B9\u03AD\u03C1\u03C7\u03B5\u03C4\u03B1\u03B9 | \u0391\u1F30\u03B4\u1F7C\u03C2 \u03B4\u1F72 \u03C0\u03BF\u03C4\u03B1\u03BC\u03AF\u03B1\u03B9\u03C3\u03B9 \u03BA\u03B7\u03C0\u03B5\u03CD\u03B5\u03B9 \u03B4\u03C1\u03CC\u03C3\u03BF\u03B9\u03C2 . On \u1F00\u03BA\u03AE\u03C1\u03B1\u03C4\u03BF\u03BD see the extensive comments of Barrett 1964:171\u2013172 ad Euripides Hippolytus 73\u201376 and 79\u201381 . Parallels may be found in terms of syntax and partly in terms of content : \u03C3\u03BF\u03AF in first position , the deictically emphasized object of dedication ( \u03C4\u03CC\u03BD\u03B4\u03B5 \u03C3\u03C4\u03AD\u03C6\u03B1\u03BD\u03BF\u03BD , \u03C4\u03AC\u03BD\u03B4\u03B5 \u03BC\u03BF\u1FE6\u03C3\u03B1\u03BD ) , the address in the vocative , the participial style ( \u03C7\u03AD\u03BF\u03BD\u03C4\u03B5\u03C2 , \u03BA\u03BF\u03C3\u03BC\u03AE\u03C3\u03B1\u03C2 ) , the performative situation with the verb in the first person , the antithesis \u03BF\u1F50 . . . \u1F00\u03BB\u03BB\u03AC emphasizing ritual purity . The decisive difference is that Hippolytos alone speaks , whereas in the Semos song a group is performing , and Hippolytos offers a garland , while the chorus offers a hymn ; in the utterance in Hippolytos \u2019 song there is also of course a \u201C garland \u201D of words alongside the actual object . An important point in common is also its location in a k\u00F4mos ( Hippolytus 55 ) ; the previous strophes stage a k\u00F4mos , where Hippolytos orders his attendants to sing ( 58\u201360 ) and as \u1F14\u03BE\u03B1\u03C1\u03C7\u03BF\u03C2 then sings the hymn with them (61\u201372) . Cf . Barrett 1964:169 ad Euripides Hippolytus 58\u201360 . Neither Barrett 1964:167\u2013176 ad Euripides Hippolytus 58\u201387 , especially 170\u2013171 ad 73\u201376 , nor Stockert in the latest Teubner edition of the Hippolytus ( Stuttgart/Leipzig 1994 ) , 10 ( in the list of testimonia ad 73\u201387 ) mentions fragment 851b PMG . The commonalities do not appear to be extensive enough to call this an imitation ; the parallels depend rather on the fact that both texts express rituality . Hence the emphasis on purity and the stylistic similarity , such as the Du-Stil and the participial predication ( cf. Norden 1913:143\u2013163 , 166\u2013168) .

#Text=[ back ] 102 . Cf . Dionysius Elegiacus 3.1 G.-P . \u1F55\u03BC\u03BD\u03BF\u03C5\u03C2 \u03BF\u1F30\u03BD\u03BF\u03C7\u03BF\u03B5\u1FD6\u03BD . For the transferral of the idea of \u03C3\u03C0\u03AD\u03BD\u03B4\u03B5\u03B9\u03BD or \u03C7\u03AD\u03B5\u03B9\u03BD to a song , cf. fragment adesp . 941 PMG ( = carm . pop . 49 D. , Terpander fragment 3 B. , 4 Loeb , 8 Gostoli ) : \u03C3\u03C0\u03AD\u03BD\u03B4\u03C9\u03BC\u03B5\u03BD \u03C4\u03B1\u1FD6\u03C2 \u039C\u03BD\u03AC\u03BC\u03B1\u03C2 \u03C0\u03B1\u03B9\u03C3\u1F76\u03BD \u039C\u03BF\u03CD\u03C3\u03B1\u03B9\u03C2 | \u03BA\u03B1\u1F76 \u03C4\u1FF7 \u039C\u03BF\u03C5\u03C3\u03AC\u03C1\u03C7\u1FF3 \u039B\u03B1\u03C4\u03BF\u1FE6\u03C2 \u03C5\u1F31\u03B5\u1FD6 ; Pindar Isthmian Odes 6 , 7\u20139 , especially line 9 : \u03C3\u03C0\u03AD\u03BD\u03B4\u03B5\u03B9\u03BD \u03BC\u03B5\u03BB\u03B9\u03C6\u03B8\u03CC\u03B3\u03B3\u03BF\u03B9\u03C2 \u1F00\u03BF\u03B9\u03B4\u03B1\u1FD6\u03C2 ; and Pindar Olympian Odes 7.1\u201310 , especially 7\u20139 : \u03BA\u03B1\u1F76 \u1F10\u03B3\u1F7C \u03BD\u03AD\u03BA\u03C4\u03B1\u03C1 \u03C7\u03C5\u03C4\u03CC\u03BD , \u039C\u03BF\u03B9\u03C3\u1FB6\u03BD \u03B4\u03CC\u03C3\u03B9\u03BD , \u1F00\u03B5\u03B8\u03BB\u03BF\u03C6\u03CC\u03C1\u03BF\u03B9\u03C2 | \u1F00\u03BD\u03B4\u03C1\u03AC\u03C3\u03B9\u03BD \u03C0\u03AD\u03BC\u03C0\u03C9\u03BD , \u03B3\u03BB\u03C5\u03BA\u1F7A\u03BD \u03BA\u03B1\u03C1\u03C0\u1F78\u03BD \u03C6\u03C1\u03B5\u03BD\u03CC\u03C2 , \u1F31\u03BB\u03AC\u03C3\u03BA\u03BF\u03BC\u03B1\u03B9 . The paean , with which the song has sometimes been associated , was closely connected with sacrifice and the symposium . Between the dinner and the actual round of drinking a libation was made to the gods and a paean sung , which served as the opening to the symposium proper . Cf . K\u00E4ppel 1992:51\u201354 with test . 73\u201384 .

#Text=[ back ] 103 . On libations , see Graf 1980 , Burkert 1985:70\u201373 , Jameson/Jordan/Kotansky 1993:70\u201373 . For the distinction between \u03C3\u03C0\u03BF\u03BD\u03B4\u03B1\u03AF and \u03C7\u03BF\u03B1\u03AF , see Rudhardt 1958:240\u2013248 and Casabona 1966:231\u2013297 . On the distinction between the more common verb \u03C3\u03C0\u03AD\u03BD\u03B4\u03C9 and \u03C7\u03AD\u03C9 , see Burkert 1985:70 and Jameson/Jordan/Kotansky 1993:71 .

#Text=[ back ] 104 . Similarly Herter 1947:26 : \u201C Zwar haben sich gerade die attischen Komiker etwas darauf zugute getan , wenn sie eine \u2018 neue Idee \u2019 vorbringen konnten , aber ihre kultischen Vorl\u00E4ufer empfinden noch ganz unmittelbar , da\u00DF der Gottheit etwas Frisches und Unber\u00FChrtes als Weihegabe gef\u00E4llt \u201D [ \u201C While it was advantageous for Attic comic playwrights if they could present a \u2018 new idea , \u2019 their cultic predecessors still have an immediate sense that the god is pleased by an offering that is fresh and untouched \u201D ] . Cf . for example the lex sacra ( text of A and B with translation in Jameson/Jordan/Kotansky 1993:14\u201317 ) of Selinous , A 10ff . ; the sacrificial context involves various libations of wine ( A 10 ) and a honey mixture ( A 13 ) , then a trapeza and klin\u00EA are to be set out for the pure Tritopatores , with a pure covering , olive wreaths , and a honey mixture in new vessels ( A 15 : \u03BA\u03B1\u03B9\u03BD\u03B1\u1FD6\u03C2 \u03C0\u03BF\u03C4\u03B5\u03C1\u03AF\u03B4\u03B5\u0323[\u03C3]\u03B9) . The suggestions here of theoxenia and aparkh\u00EA are noteworthy . Cf . Jameson/Jordan/Kotansky 1993:67\u201370 . New and pure fittings and equipment are sometimes strict preconditions for particular rites ; cf. Xenophanes fragment 1 G.-P . ( offering before symposium ) and Jameson/Jordan/Kotansky 1993:35\u201336 ad A 15 with particular reference to conditions in a cult calendar of the fourth century BCE from Kos ( Sokolowski 1969 [ LSCG ] , Nr . 151 A\u2013C = SIG3 1025\u20131027) .

#Text=[ back ] 105 . At the same time the actors are also characterized as \u201C wild men \u201D from the Outside . On dressing as satyrs at the Anthesteria , who represent \u201C wild men \u201D of this type , see Seaford 1984:7n17 and 19 ( with reference to the modern Greek Kallikantzaroi as descendants of the satyrs) . On the Kallikantzaroi , who still survive in the folk belief of the Peloponnese and the Greek islands , see Lawson 1910:190\u2013255 ( on the centaurs ) and Ginzburg 1989:186\u2013187 , 201\u2013202 ( in connection with many other similar groups , e.g. the Eskari , Surovaskari , Coledari , Reg\u00F6s) . Cf . the description ( Ginzburg 1989:186 ) of the Kallikantzaroi , who in many ways show points of connection with our actors as well : \u201C Die Kallikantzaroi sind scheu\u00DFliche , schwarze , zottige Wesen , . . . fast immer sind sie m\u00E4nnlichen Geschlechts , mit riesigen Genitalien ausgestattet \u201D [ \u201C The Kallikantzaroi are repulsive , black , shaggy creatures , . . . they are almost always male , equipped with massive genitalia \u201D ] . K\u00F4mos , beggar ritual , ecstasy , dressing up as animals , vulgar emphasis on the sexual sphere , ridicule , fighting , and the personification of the dead are typical of groups like these , who perform between Christmas and Epiphany ( new year \u2019s festival ! ) . Leaves and flowers are often ritual indicators of marginality , in particular of youth in the liminal phase of initiation , who embody mythical figures of this type in their groups : see Jeanmaire 1939:174 , 177 , 179 , 181 , 189 , 221 ; Brelich 1969 in his excellent introduction ( 13\u2013112 ) , especially in the morphology ( 25\u201344 ) of these rites of puberty , 72n60 ( leaves ) , 88n111 ( wood spirits) . The k\u00F4mos , the procession of drunken players , represents the reactualization of these liminal experiences of puberty initiation rites . In a scholion to Aeschines \u2019 speech 1.52 ( 115 Dilts ) we find the following interesting explanation : \u039A\u03B7\u03B4\u03C9\u03BD\u03AF\u03B4\u03B7\u03BD ] \u03BF\u1F57\u03C4\u03BF\u03B9 \u03C0\u03B1\u03B9\u03B4\u03B5\u03C1\u03B1\u03C3\u03C4\u03B1\u03AF , \u1F10\u03C0\u03C9\u03BD\u03C5\u03BC\u03AF\u03B1\u03C2 \u1F14\u03C7\u03BF\u03BD\u03C4\u03B5\u03C2 \u2018 \u1F04\u03B3\u03C1\u03B9\u03BF\u03B9 \u03BA\u03B1\u1F76 \u03A4\u03C1\u03B9\u03B2\u03B1\u03BB\u03BB\u03BF\u1F76 \u03BA\u03B1\u1F76 \u039A\u03AD\u03BD\u03C4\u03B1\u03C5\u03C1\u03BF\u03B9 . \u2019 The figures explained here are thus pederasts ( on the connection to pederasty and initiation in the symposium see Bremmer 1990 ) , and in particular they have the bynames \u201C wild ones , \u201D \u201C Triballoi \u201D ( like the Athenian groups mentioned in Demosth . 54.39 ) , and \u201C centaurs , \u201D which also refers to phallic wildness .

#Text=[ back ] 106 . Vegetative imagery also lies behind the performative verb \u1F00\u03B3\u03BB\u03B1\u0390\u03B6\u03BF\u03BC\u03B5\u03BD , following Hesychius ( s.v. \u1F00\u03B3\u03BB\u03B1\u0390\u03B6\u03B5\u03B9\u00B7 \u03B8\u03AC\u03BB\u03BB\u03B5\u03B9 ) ; cf. K.-A . on Eupolis fragment 419 . Dionysus was himself described with the name \u1F0C\u03BD\u03B8\u03B9\u03BF\u03C2 ( IG II/III2 1356.9 and Pausanias 1.31.4) . Parallel to Thalia ( who forms the Kharites along with Aglaia and Euphrosyne ) as the name of the personified festival is the verb \u03B8\u03AC\u03BB\u03BB\u03B5\u03B9\u03BD ; cf. Kannicht 1989:31n10 . For Dionysus as god of growth , sprouting , and blooming , and for his other cultic epithets corresponding to this idea , see Blech 1982:182\u2013183 . The Greeks always connected the Anthesteria via folk etymology with the maturation , or \u201C blossoming , \u201D of wine . The Anthesteria have a strong connection with symbolic indications of performance : those who perform the rites are dressed as \u201C wild men , \u201D it is a festival of the inverted world , of exception , anarchy , transition , and the new year ; masquerade and the dead , the return of the dead as ghosts and barbarians , the staging of the origins of civilization , and wine also play a role here . On the Anthesteria in general , see Deubner 1932:93\u2013123 , Burkert 1983:213\u2013243 , and Auffarth 1991:202\u2013276 ; on the Anthesteria as the frame of reference of the Wealth , see Bierl 1994 .
#Text=[ back ] 107 . On offerings of first fruits , see Burkert 1985:66\u201368 and Jameson/Jordan/Kotansky 1993:67\u201370 .

#Text=[ back ] 108 . This text thus lends itself extremely well to the approach based on the Nouvelle Histoire , which treats poetry as offering ; cf. the fundamental study by Svenbro 1984 ( who does not mention fragment 851b PMG , Dionysius Elegiacus 3.1 G.-P . , and fragment adesp . 941 PMG [ = Terp . fragments 3 B. , 4 Loeb , 8 Gostoli]) . Svenbro makes an interesting connection between song ( \u03BC\u03AD\u03BB\u03BF\u03C2 ) and the homonym \u03BC\u03AD\u03BB\u03BF\u03C2 , which comes from the same root and means a human or animal limb ( 221 ) , and analyzes Greek metrics and the bodily nature of its technical terms as a science that bases itself on the model of ritual killing . In a dissertation ( 1992 ) supervised by Richard Martin , Sfyroeras attempts to apply this theory to comedy . Cf . especially 8\u201313 ( unfortunately the examples adduced there , especially the incorrectly interpreted Herodotean passage [ Herodotus 5.67.5 ] , are not very convincing) . Nevertheless , Sfyroeras \u2019 thesis of a fundamental connection between sacrifice and comedy ( see now Sfyroeras 2004 ) precisely in the light of this ritual song , which shows so many similarities to the k\u00F4mos and ritual poetry , seems well worth considering .

#Text=[ back ] 109 . On the practice of performing dithyramb , paean , and hyporcheme in a circle as prelude to a sacrificial rite , see also Furley 1993:35\u201336 . Cf . ibid. , 36 : \u201C Animal sacrifice survives to this day at some festivals in Greece : hymns are sung while the animal is led round the sacrificial pit . \u201D On the presentation of the dithyramb at the thymel\u00EA , Pratinas fragment 708.1\u20132 PMG : \u03C4\u03AF\u03C2 \u1F41 \u03B8\u03CC\u03C1\u03C5\u03B2\u03BF\u03C2 \u1F45\u03B4\u03B5 ; \u03C4\u03AF \u03C4\u03AC\u03B4\u03B5 \u03C4\u1F70 \u03C7\u03BF\u03C1\u03B5\u03CD\u03BC\u03B1\u03C4\u03B1 ; | \u03C4\u03AF\u03C2 \u1F55\u03B2\u03C1\u03B9\u03C2 \u1F14\u03BC\u03BF\u03BB\u03B5\u03BD \u1F10\u03C0\u1F76 \u0394\u03B9\u03BF\u03BD\u03C5\u03C3\u03B9\u03AC\u03B4\u03B1 \u03C0\u03BF\u03BB\u03C5\u03C0\u03AC\u03C4\u03B1\u03B3\u03B1 \u03B8\u03C5\u03BC\u03AD\u03BB\u03B1\u03BD . On the connection between paean and sacrifice , see K\u00E4ppel 1992:44\u201347 , 49\u201351 , 55\u201356 ( and test . 95 ) , 58\u201363 , 81 , 285 and in connection with discussion of the Erythraean paean to Asklepios ( Pai . 37 ) ( ibid. , 190\u2013192 on the sacred law Pai . 36a ) and treatment of the Philodamus paean ( Pai . 39 ) , the occasion for which is provided by a theoxenia ( ibid. , 210 , 254) . The garlands worn by participants at a sacrifice and by symposiasts ( Eitrem 1915:64\u201375 , Burkert 1985:56 with 368n5 , Jameson/Jordan/Kotansky 1993:68 ) correspond to those worn by the performers of our song here . On the combination of sacrificial ritual and drama , see Burkert 1966a . The art of drama arose from improvisations at rural goat sacrifices . Intermediary stages remain in the folk custom . [ back ] The simplex \u1F04\u03C1\u03C7\u03B5\u03C3\u03B8\u03B1\u03B9 and the composite \u03BA\u03B1\u03C4\u03AC\u03C1\u03C7\u03B5\u03B9\u03BD/ -\u03B5\u03C3\u03B8\u03B1\u03B9 describe both the general beginning of an action and in particular the completion of practices that introduce sacrifices ; for \u03BA\u03B1\u03C4\u03AC\u03C1\u03C7\u03B5\u03C3\u03B8\u03B1\u03B9 in the meaning \u201C wash hands , \u201D \u201C sprinkle barley \u201D ( Homer Odyssey 3.445 ) , \u201C pasture the animal for slaughter , \u201D and other preparatory actions before sacrifice , see Dunbar Birds , 541\u2013542 ad Aristophanes Birds 959 . By contrast , \u1F00\u03C0\u03AC\u03C1\u03C7\u03B5\u03C3\u03B8\u03B1\u03B9 is limited to a particular ritual meaning ( it is only later attested as synonym for \u1F04\u03C1\u03C7\u03B5\u03C3\u03B8\u03B1\u03B9 ; LSJ s.v. \u1F00\u03C0\u03AC\u03C1\u03C7\u03BF\u03BC\u03B1\u03B9) . Burkert 1985:56 mentions \u1F04\u03C1\u03C7\u03B5\u03C3\u03B8\u03B1\u03B9 , \u03BA\u03B1\u03C4\u03AC\u03C1\u03C7\u03B5\u03C3\u03B8\u03B1\u03B9 , and \u1F00\u03C0\u03AC\u03C1\u03C7\u03B5\u03C3\u03B8\u03B1\u03B9 as technical terms for particular rites carried out before sacrifice . The meaning of simply \u201C beginning , \u201D \u201C starting out , \u201D and the preparatory ceremonies for sacrifice are blended together in the ritual language of the song .

#Text=[ back ] 110 . The verbs \u1F04\u03C1\u03C7\u03B5\u03B9\u03BD and \u03BA\u03B1\u03C4\u03AC\u03C1\u03C7\u03B5\u03B9\u03BD appear with the uncommon accusative construction in the performative context of the introduction ; cf. Pindar Nemean Odes 3.10\u201311 : \u1F04\u03C1\u03C7\u03B5 . . . | \u03B4\u03CC\u03BA\u03B9\u03BC\u03BF\u03BD \u1F55\u03BC\u03BD\u03BF\u03BD ; Alcman fragment 98 Davies : \u03B8\u03BF\u03AF\u03BD\u03B1\u03B9\u03C2 \u03B4\u1F72 \u03BA\u03B1\u1F76 \u1F10\u03BD \u03B8\u03B9\u03AC\u03C3\u03BF\u03B9\u03C3\u03B9\u03BD | \u1F00\u03BD\u03B4\u03C1\u03B5\u03AF\u03C9\u03BD \u03C0\u03B1\u03C1\u1F70 \u03B4\u03B1\u03B9\u03C4\u03C5\u03BC\u03CC\u03BD\u03B5\u03C3\u03C3\u03B9 \u03C0\u03C1\u03AD\u03C0\u03B5\u03B9 \u03C0\u03B1\u03B9\u1FB6\u03BD\u03B1 \u03BA\u03B1\u03C4\u03AC\u03C1\u03C7\u03B7\u03BD ; and our passage fragment 851b.5 PMG : \u03BA\u03B1\u03C4\u03AC\u03C1\u03C7\u03BF\u03BC\u03B5\u03BD \u03C4\u1F78\u03BD \u1F55\u03BC\u03BD\u03BF\u03BD . Cf . also Plato Euthydemus 283b : \u03B8\u03B1\u03C5\u03BC\u03B1\u03C3\u03C4\u1F78\u03BD \u03B3\u03AC\u03C1 \u03C4\u03B9\u03BD\u03B1 , \u1F66 \u039A\u03C1\u03AF\u03C4\u03C9\u03BD , \u1F01\u03BD\u1F74\u03C1 \u03BA\u03B1\u03C4\u1FC6\u03C1\u03C7\u03B5\u03BD \u03BB\u03CC\u03B3\u03BF\u03BD . For \u1F04\u03C1\u03C7\u03B5\u03C3\u03B8\u03B1\u03B9 with the accusative cf. Alcman fragment 48 Davies : \u039B\u03B1\u03C4\u03BF\u0390\u03B4\u03B1 , \u03C4\u03AD\u03BF \u03B4 \u2019 \u1F00\u03C1\u03C7 \u03BF\u03C2 \u03C7\u03BF\u03C1\u03CC\u03BD ( coni . West ) ; Sophocles fragment 737b PMG = K\u00E4ppel 1992:366\u2013367 , 366\u2013Pai . 32.2 , line 2 : \u03C3\u03AD[\u03B8]\u03B5\u03BD \u1F04\u03C1\u03BE\u03BF\u03BC\u03B1\u0323\u03B9\u0323 ( coni . Oliver ) \u1F55\u03BC]\u03BD\u03BF\u03BD . With this one may also associate \u1F10\u03BE\u03AC\u03C1\u03C7\u03B5\u03B9\u03BD , which followed by either accusative or genitive refers to striking up a song , especially with reference to the choral leader : Homer Odyssey 4.19 : \u03BC\u03BF\u03BB\u03C0\u1FC6\u03C2 ; Iliad 18.51 : \u03B3\u03CC\u03BF\u03B9\u03BF ; with accusative : Homeric Hymns 27.18 : \u03C7\u03BF\u03C1\u03BF\u03CD\u03C2 ; Archilochus fragment 120 W. : \u03B4\u03B9\u03B8\u03CD\u03C1\u03B1\u03BC\u03B2\u03BF\u03BD ; fragment 121 W. : \u039B\u03AD\u03C3\u03B2\u03B9\u03BF\u03BD \u03C0\u03B1\u03B9\u03AE\u03BF\u03BD\u03B1 ; for \u1F10\u03BE\u03AC\u03C1\u03C7\u03B5\u03B9\u03BD with the accusative , implying a chorus , see Zimmermann 1992:19\u201323 with further passages 19n3 . For the performative future \u1F00\u03B5\u03AF\u03C3\u03BF\u03BC\u03B1\u03B9 ( cf. the self-referential \u1FA0\u03B4\u03B1\u1FD6\u03C3\u03B9\u03BD , fragment 851b.4 PMG ) cf. Alcman fragment 28 : \u1F00\u03B5\u03AF\u03C3\u03BF\u03BC\u03B1\u03B9 and 29 Davies : \u1F10\u03B3\u1F7C\u03BD \u03B4 \u2019 \u1F00\u03B5\u03AF\u03C3\u03BF\u03BC\u03B1\u03B9 . On the topos of the beginning of a song in the Homeric hymns : \u1F04\u03C1\u03C7\u03BF\u03BC \u2019 \u1F00\u03B5\u03AF\u03B4\u03B5\u03B9\u03BD : Homeric Hymns 2.1 , 11.1 , 13.1 , 16.1 , 22.1 , 26.1 , 28.1 ; \u1F00\u03B5\u03AF\u03C3\u03BF\u03BC\u03B1\u03B9 : Homeric Hymns 10.1 , 15.1 , 23.1 , 30.1 ; \u1F00\u03B5\u03AF\u03B4\u03C9 : Homeric Hymns 12.1 , 18.1 , 27.1 ; \u039C\u03BF\u03C5\u03C3\u03AC\u03C9\u03BD \u1F04\u03C1\u03C7\u03C9\u03BC\u03B1\u03B9 : Homeric Hymns 25.1 ; on this introductory formula see Calame 1995a:6\u20138 . For anabol\u00EA see Comotti 1989 and Zimmermann 1992:22 . This has to be understood as originally being an improvised prelude . Zimmermann summarizes Comotti \u2019s theory of the content of the anabol\u00EA as follows ( ibid. ) : \u201C Vorstellung des folgenden Chorlieds , Widmung an Dionysos , Kritik anderer Dichter und poetologische Reflexionen d\u00FCrften der Inhalt solcher urspr\u00FCnglich zur Kithara , sp\u00E4ter auch zu Fl\u00F6tenmusik gesungener Pro\u00F6mien gewesen sein , die sich im Verlauf des f\u00FCnften Jahrhunderts zu regelrechten responsionslosen Bravourarien entwickelt h\u00E4tten \u201D [ \u201C The presentation of the following choral song , dedication to Dionysus , criticism of other poets , and poetological reflections must have been the content of these kinds of prooimia , which were originally sung to the accompaniment of the kithara , later also to that of the aulos , and which during the course of the fifth century would have developed into fixed bravura arias without responsion \u201D ] . In this connection Zimmermann 1992:22 refers to the well-known Aristotelian theory of the development of tragedy and comedy ( Poetics 1449a9\u201313 ) : \u03B3\u03B5\u03BD\u03BF\u03BC\u03AD\u03BD\u03B7 \u03B4 \u2019 \u03BF\u1F56\u03BD \u1F00\u03C0 \u2019 \u1F00\u03C1\u03C7\u1FC6\u03C2 \u03B1\u1F50\u03C4\u03BF\u03C3\u03C7\u03B5\u03B4\u03B9\u03B1\u03C3\u03C4\u03B9\u03BA\u1FC6\u03C2\u2014\u03BA\u03B1\u1F76 \u03B1\u1F50\u03C4\u1F74 \u03BA\u03B1\u1F76 \u1F21 \u03BA\u03C9\u03BC\u1FF3\u03B4\u03AF\u03B1 , \u03BA\u03B1\u1F76 \u1F21 \u03BC\u1F72\u03BD \u1F00\u03C0\u1F78 \u03C4\u1FF6\u03BD \u1F10\u03BE\u03B1\u03C1\u03C7\u03CC\u03BD\u03C4\u03C9\u03BD \u03C4\u1F78\u03BD \u03B4\u03B9\u03B8\u03CD\u03C1\u03B1\u03BC\u03B2\u03BF\u03BD , \u1F21 \u03B4\u1F72 \u1F00\u03C0\u1F78 \u03C4\u1FF6\u03BD \u03C4\u1F70 \u03C6\u03B1\u03BB\u03BB\u03B9\u03BA\u1F70 \u1F03 \u1F14\u03C4\u03B9 \u03BA\u03B1\u1F76 \u03BD\u1FE6\u03BD \u1F10\u03BD \u03C0\u03BF\u03BB\u03BB\u03B1\u1FD6\u03C2 \u03C4\u1FF6\u03BD \u03C0\u03CC\u03BB\u03B5\u03C9\u03BD \u03B4\u03B9\u03B1\u03BC\u03AD\u03BD\u03B5\u03B9 \u03BD\u03BF\u03BC\u03B9\u03B6\u03CC\u03BC\u03B5\u03BD\u03B1 \u03BA\u03C4\u03BB . Our song could thus relate in self-referential fashion to the prelude of a \u03C6\u03B1\u03BB\u03BB\u03B9\u03BA\u03CC\u03BD . However it is not an \u1F14\u03BE\u03B1\u03C1\u03C7\u03BF\u03C2 , rather the entire group , who takes up the introduction .

#Text=[ back ] 111 . Zimmermann 1992:22 also makes an interesting reference to a folk song ; in fragment 871 PMG the women of Elis use the form of a hymnos kl\u00EAtikos to call for the epiphany of Dionysus .

#Text=[ back ] 112 . With their feminizing costumes the presenters through their utterance of \u1F00\u03B3\u03BB\u03B1\u0390\u03B6\u03BF\u03BC\u03B5\u03BD themselves become in a sense the Kharites ; in other words , they assume in part a feminine role . Girls on the threshold of adulthood are often represented in \u03C7\u03BF\u03C1\u03BF\u03AF . The masculine identity of the actors thereby touches , in terms of content , the border region between man and woman . It is significant that the participle \u03C7\u03AD\u03BF\u03BD\u03C4\u03B5\u03C2 does not assume the feminine form relating to the chorus \u2019 possible role , but refers to the actual gender of the singers .

#Text=[ back ] 113 . Cf . Euripides Phoenician Women 1739 : \u1F00\u03C0\u03B1\u03C1\u03B8\u03AD\u03BD\u03B5\u03C5\u03C4 \u2019 \u1F01\u03BB\u03C9\u03BC\u03AD\u03BD\u03B1 and Iphigenia in Aulis 993 : \u1F00\u03C0\u03B1\u03C1\u03B8\u03AD\u03BD\u03B5\u03C5\u03C4\u03B1 \u03BC\u1F72\u03BD \u03C4\u03AC\u03B4 \u2019 . Navarre 1911:249 thus translates the adjective as \u201C qui n\u2019est pas fait pour des jeunes filles \u201D [ \u201C not designed for young girls \u201D ] ; similarly Horn 1970:68 ( \u201C ein Inhalt , der sich nicht f\u00FCr zarte M\u00E4dchenohren eignet \u201D [ \u201C content not suited for the tender ears of maidens \u201D ] ) ; Kugelmeier 1996:154n270 also seems to be of this opinion . The adjective is ambiguous : 1 . ) It can mean \u201C virginal , \u2019 i.e. before defloration ( as if from \u03C0\u03B1\u03C1\u03B8\u03B5\u03BD\u03B5\u03CD\u03C9 = \u03BA\u03BF\u03C1\u03B5\u03CD\u03C9 ) ; it is thus treated by the majority of scholars as synonym in asyndeton of \u03BA\u03B1\u03B9\u03BD\u03AC\u03BD ( cf. Sophocles fragment 304 Radt) . 2 . ) It may refer to the opposite condition of no longer being a virgin , i.e. \u201C unmaidenly \u201D ( cf. schol . Theocritus Idylls 2.41 , 279 Wendel) . The above-mentioned meaning \u201C not fitting for a virgin \u201D can be viewed as a subcategory of (2) . The metaphor of the song as something mixed or blended is contaminated in the ritual text with the idea of defloration as offering .
#Text=[ back ] 114 . Cf . Cole 1993 .
#Text=[ back ] 115 . Because the lack of sources the origin can unfortunately probably never be known with certainty .

#Text=[ back ] 116 . On the parabasis as ritual core and original element : for earlier literature , before the actual influence of the Cambridge ritualists , see Hubbard 1991:16n2 ; Cornford and Murray as prominent representatives of this direction in scholarship deliver opinions in this vein ; Cornford ( 19612:93 ) says of the parabasis in The Origin of Attic Comedy , which appeared in 1914 : \u201C With its stiff canonical structure , it has all the air of a piece of ritual procedure awkwardly interrupting the course of the play \u201D ; see also Cornford 19612:110 . Murray ( 1933:12 ) sees it as \u201C a nugget of unassimilated ritual embedded in the structure of the play . \u201D This opinion has endured up until comparatively recently ; Kranz 1933:25 , Herter 1947:31\u201332 , Kranz 1949:1125 , Lesky 19713:273 ( \u201C Kernst\u00FCck \u201D ) , Seaford 1977:85\u201386 , and Reckford 1987:488 . [ back ] The origin of comedy has often been connected with the song of the Phallophoroi ( the Ithyphalloi , Deikelistai , Autokabdaloi , and phallika ) but only in a general fashion . Cornford 19612:110\u2013111 thinks the development can only have lead to the parabasis , because the Phallophoroi did not assume any dramatic role ( he does however think the phallic rites were connected with the k\u00F4mos , ibid. 111\u2013114 ) ; Herter 1947:16\u201342 and passim attempts an organic reconstruction using the chorus of the Ithyphalloi in particular ; he thinks a plot arose from parabasis-like song ; Pohlenz 1949 ( = Kl . Schr . II 1965:497\u2013510 ) believes that the song represents only one possible developmental step toward the parabasis ; cf. also Giangrande 1963 , Lesky 19713:271\u2013273 ( relation to carnival and parabasis , later mimicry ) , Reckford 1987:443\u2013498 , especially 487\u2013488 ( following Cornford , Semos \u2019 song is characterized as a \u201C rudimentary k\u00F4mos from which \u2018 comedy \u2019 grew\u201D) . Contra , among others , Radermacher Fr\u00F6sche , 12 , Pickard-Cambridge 1962:133\u2013147 , H\u00E4ndel 1963:84 , 108 , Sifakis 1971:20 , 69 and Leonhardt 1991:37\u201338 , who are skeptical about a link between the song of the Phallophoroi and the genesis of comedy or the parabasis . For a history of the interpretation of the parabasis , see Sifakis 1971:15\u201320 , and now also Imperio 2004:11\u201314 . How a dramatic plot is supposed to have arisen from the undramatic phallika has always been viewed as a particularly problematic question . Herter 1938b:1677 replies with the Aristotelian formula that Aristotle does not derive comedy immediately from the \u03C6\u03B1\u03BB\u03BB\u03B9\u03BA\u03AC themselves , but traces it merely to the \u1F10\u03BE\u03AC\u03C1\u03C7\u03BF\u03BD\u03C4\u03B5\u03C2 \u03C4\u1F70 \u03C6\u03B1\u03BB\u03BB\u03B9\u03BA\u03AC ; he also says the element of improvisation is critical . German scholarship was fond of making a connection between the Phallophoroi and the parabasis , which in turn was interpreted as an original song of entry (parodos) . The main arguments advanced were : a ) the term parabasis is synonymous with parodos ; b ) anapaests are typical of the marching rhythm of the entry procession ; the Phallophoroi also form an entry procession ; c ) it was the chorus \u2019 job to salute the gods immediately after their entry procession ( parabasis odes) . See Sifakis 1971:111\u2013112n21 for literature on the parabasis-parodos thesis .

#Text=[ back ] 117 . On the comparison between the parabasis , especially the epirrhematic syzygy , and the Hellenistic Phallophoroi and Ithyphalloi ( hymns and ridicule ) , see Kolster 1829:51\u201361 , Koester 1835:16\u201318 ( both derive the parabasis directly from phallic songs ) , Muff 1871:6\u20137 , Herter 1947 : Pohlenz 1949:37 ( = Kl . Schr . II 1965:503 ) , and Reckford 1987:487\u2013488 . The parabasis odes as reflexes of cult hymns have been extensively discussed by Fraenkel ( 1931 and 1962:191\u2013215 ) ; he shows that the greeting is directed at all the polis gods , not just Dionysus , as is the case with the Phallophoroi . Kranz thinks ( 1919:162n4 , 163 and 1933:30 ) that all choruses originally directed their song only to Dionysos Lenaios ( on the Phallophoroi , see Kranz 1919:164) . Gelzer 1960:210 combines Fraenkel \u2019s theory of the dependency of the odes on cult lyric with the German Phallophoroi theory ( the epirrhematic syzygy is based on the song of the Phallophoroi , a view held since Kolster 1829:60) . Gelzer 1960:210 says : \u201C Das [ Phallophoroi-Lied ] scheint also eine Art Vorstufe zur Parabase gewesen zu sein , die sich an anderen Orten an bestimmten Festen noch als selbst\u00E4ndige Begehung erhalten hatte , in Athen aber in die Kom\u00F6die eingegangen war . Die G\u00F6tter werden in der Syzygie unabh\u00E4ngig von der speziellen Funktion des Chors im jeweiligen St\u00FCck angerufen , und nur ganz \u00E4u\u00DFerliche Zus\u00E4tze lassen die Hymnen als vom Chor des jeweiligen St\u00FCcks vorgetragen erscheinen \u201D [ \u201C The song of the Phallophoroi thus seems to have been a kind of precursor to the parabasis , which in other areas was still preserved as an independent celebration at certain festivals , but in Athens became part of comedy . In the syzygy the gods were invoked independently of the chorus \u2019 particular function in the given play , and it is only through additions of a completely superficial nature that the hymns appear to be performed by the chorus of that particular play \u201D ] . Cf . also Gelzer 1966:69 , where the development from indecent \u03C6\u03B1\u03BB\u03BB\u03B9\u03BA\u03CC\u03BD to parabasis is described ; but it is not quite correct to speak of a \u201C Funktions\u00E4nderung zum R\u00FCgegedicht \u201D [ \u201C change of function to blame poem \u201D ] , especially since mockery also formed part of the ritual of the Phallophoroi . [ back ] Cornford 19612:95 is skeptical of this ; he thinks that the elements of invocation and ridicule were in fact present in the phallic song and in the parabasis , but that the structure in the phallic song was different , because invective could be improvised endlessly . He therefore argues against the genesis of the parabasis from the phallic song , and sees rather a relationship between the latter and the exodos . Cf . also ibid. 110\u2013114 . The remarks of Pickard-Cambridge 1962 , 142\u2013144 are also highly critical .

#Text=[ back ] 118 . For the theory of the irrelevant digression , see the earlier bibliography in Hubbard 1991:16n4 ; cf. further among others Zielinski 1885:184\u2013187 , Pickard-Cambridge 1962:199 , Kranz 1933:25 , Gelzer 1960:208 , H\u00E4ndel 1963:85 , Sifakis 1971:66 , 69 , Dover 1972:49 , and Heath 1987:18\u201323 , 43\u201344 . Criticism of this position has recently been mounting ; cf. Bowie 1982 , Harriott 1986:20\u201336 , Reckford 1987 , and Hubbard 1991 ( Hubbard reads the self-referential remarks of the poet as intertextual commentary and references of the poet to his work) . To this debate add now Imperio 2004:13\u201314 .

#Text=[ back ] 119 . The characteristic style of speech used between the players and the participants/audience is important here ( cf. Athenaeus 622b : \u1F10\u03C0\u03B9\u03C3\u03C4\u03C1\u03AD\u03C6\u03BF\u03C5\u03C3\u03B9\u03BD \u03B5\u1F30\u03C2 \u03C4\u1F78 \u03B8\u03AD\u03B1\u03C4\u03C1\u03BF\u03BD with the expression at the beginning of the parabasis Aristophanes Acharnians 629 : \u03BF\u1F54\u03C0\u03C9 \u03C0\u03B1\u03C1\u03AD\u03B2\u03B7 \u03C0\u03C1\u1F78\u03C2 \u03C4\u1F78 \u03B8\u03AD\u03B1\u03C4\u03C1\u03BF\u03BD , Knights 508 : \u03C0\u03C1\u1F78\u03C2 \u03C4\u1F78 \u03B8\u03AD\u03B1\u03C4\u03C1\u03BF\u03BD \u03C0\u03B1\u03C1\u03B1\u03B2\u1FC6\u03BD\u03B1\u03B9 , Peace 735 : \u03C0\u03C1\u1F78\u03C2 \u03C4\u1F78 \u03B8\u03AD\u03B1\u03C4\u03C1\u03BF\u03BD \u03C0\u03B1\u03C1\u03B1\u03B2\u1F70\u03C2 \u1F10\u03BD \u03C4\u03BF\u1FD6\u03C2 \u1F00\u03BD\u03B1\u03C0\u03B1\u03AF\u03C3\u03C4\u03BF\u03B9\u03C2) . Cf . early on Schmid 1929:635 : \u201C Die Handlung spielt sich zwischen Chor und Publikum ab und entspricht der altattischen Parabase . \u201D [ \u201C The action is acted out between the chorus and the audience and corresponds to the old Attic parabasis . \u201D ] Cf . also Muff 1871:7 and Kranz 1933:30 . The presenters do not play entirely within a dramatic role and within a dramatic plot that the spectators simply witness while submerging themselves therein , but actually enter into direct contact with their surroundings , while oscillating between their real and their fictitious identity . They criticize and ridicule individuals in the surrounding area and they worship the gods of the community in front of and together with the audience .
#Text=[ back ] 120 . See H\u00E4ndel 1963:84 , 109 and Sifakis 1971:20 .
#Text=[ back ] 121 . See H\u00E4ndel 1963:84 and Sifakis 1971:20 , 59\u201370 , especially 68\u201369 .
#Text=[ back ] 122 . See H\u00E4ndel 1963:107\u2013109n17 and Sifakis 1971:17\u201321 . Sifakis describes the odes as \u201C a relic of genuine Kultlyrik \u201D ( ibid. , 69) .

#Text=[ back ] 123 . There is much to suggest this , especially since the examples of the boastful doctor and the Theban mania for strange words in the immediately preceding quotation from Sosibios ( Athenaeus 621d\u2013622a ) are drawn from contemporary New Comedy ( Alexis fragment 146 K.-A . and Strattis fragment 49 K.-A.) . See also the reference to language above , n56 . Porson attributed the song of the Phallophoroi to Pratinas ( as referred to in Bergk III 18824:657 ad carm . pop . 8 B. , who does not , however , think the reasoning is sound) .

#Text=[ back ] 124 . Because of an incorrect interpretation of \u03C0\u03B1\u03C1\u03B1\u03B2\u03B1\u03AF\u03BD\u03B5\u03B9\u03BD and the entrance-like character of the two phallic songs , it used to be thought that the parabasis was originally a song sung while entering .

#Text=[ back ] 125 . Consider among others Kolster 1829:52 , 59\u201360 , Koester 1835:16\u201317 , M\u00FCller II 1857:197\u2013198 , van Leeuwen Acharnians , 50\u201351 ad 261 ( also with reference to Sosibios [ Athenaeus 621d ] on improvised comic scenes at performances of this kind at the rural Dionysia ! ) , Cornford 19612:103\u2013109 , especially 103\u2013104 , 108 , K\u00F6rte 1921:1218\u20131219 , Herter 1938b:1675ff . , Herter 1947:24ff . ( who emphasizes the parallels to the song of the Ithyphalloi ) , Pickard-Cambridge 1962:145\u2013147 , Gelzer 1966:69 , Horn 1970:63\u201371 , especially 68 , Ghiron-Bistagne 1976:208\u2013213 ( who refuses to see any k\u00F4mos either in the Aristophanic song or in that of the Phallophoroi , but sees instead an honorable \u03C0\u03BF\u03BC\u03C0\u03AE ) , Carri\u00E8re 1979:19 and 34n14 , Zimmermann II 1985:41 , Prato 1987:216 with n48 ( with special reference to the iambic meter of the Phallophoroi ) , Cole 1993:26 ( only implicitly ) , Habash 1995:567 , Kugelmeier 1996:151\u2013154 , and Csapo 1997:284 . Cf . now also Olson Acharnians , 140 ad 237\u2013279 , 147 ad 261 , and P\u00FCtz 2003:161\u2013163 .

#Text=[ back ] 126 . Many only see the nondramatic aspect in this song as well ; cf. Pickard-Cambridge 1962:146 : \u201C In neither is there anything dramatic ; the agents represent no one but themselves . \u201D Cf . Herter 1938b:1677 and Horn 1970:66\u201367 ; likewise Kugelmeier 1996:154 does not recognize an \u201C actual dramatic function \u201D therein . Similarly now Olson Acharnians , 141 ad 241\u2013279 : \u201C . . . this scene , which briefly interrupts the forward movement of the action to offer a vision of life in an ideal world of peace . . . \u201D The remarks of Leonhardt 1991:38 in this connection are unclear : \u201C Die ber\u00FChmte Szene der Acharner des Aristophanes ist in keiner Weise mit der Struktur des St\u00FCckes ver-kn\u00FCpft , sondern allein von der Handlung her begr\u00FCndet ; die Feier der l\u00E4ndlichen Dionysien symbolisiert die Segnungen des Friedens , den der Hauptheld Dikaiopolis mit den Spartanern geschlossen hat . Somit kommt der Parodie des Phallikon kein anderer Stellenwert zu als den zahlreichen Dithyramben \u2013 , Trag\u00F6dien \u2013 und Hymnenparodien , die sich in den Kom\u00F6dien allenthalben finden . \u201D [ \u201C The famous scene from the Acharnians of Aristophanes is in no way joined to the structure of the play , but is motivated only in terms of plot ; the celebration of the rural Dionysia symbolizes the blessings of the peace that the protagonist Dikaiopolis has concluded with the Spartans . Thus the parody of the phallikon possesses no more significance than do the countless parodies of dithyrambs , tragedies , and hymns found everywhere in comedies . \u201D ] Because it is embedded in the plot of the Acharnians the song does not represent a true copy of a phallophoria ; cf. Herter 1938b:1676 . Webster in Pickard-Cambridge 1962:146 refers to the differences between this and Semos \u2019 Phallophoroi : a ) the latter have a distinctive costume ; b ) they run toward the spectators and ridicule them ; c ) the \u03C6\u03B1\u03BB\u03BB\u03BF\u03C6\u03CC\u03C1\u03BF\u03C2 is blackened with soot . Nevertheless , there can be no doubt that the spectacle represents the staging of a cult . According to Gelzer 1992:49 the passage is not a parody at all : \u201C Dieses kompakte Genrebild des l\u00E4ndlichen Dionysosfestes ist gewiss mit der drastischen Verve des damals wohl kaum mehr als 20j\u00E4hrigen Dichters gew\u00FCrzt ; aber es ist als solches kein Witz , sondern die Darstellung eines l\u00E4ndlichen Kultes \u201D [ \u201C This compact genre painting of the rural Dionysia is certainly spiced with the graphic verve of the poet , who was probably not much more than twenty at the time ; but as such it is not a joke , rather the presentation of a rural cult \u201D ] .

#Text=[ back ] 127 . According to schol . Acharnians 202 , the rural Dionysia correspond to the Lenaia , the festival of the performance ( cf. Pickard-Cambridge 1962:144\u2013145) . Actually the Lenaia , celebrated in the month Gamelion , is a quite separate celebration from the rural Dionysia . The latter was celebrated in individual demes already in the month Poseideon . On the inadvertent connection , see Deubner 1932:124 . Still , elements of other festivals of Dionysus , such as , for example , mockery delivered by people on carts , were transferred from the Khoes to the Lenaia . Typical of the Lenaia and also of the rural Dionysia were the \u03C0\u03BF\u03BC\u03C0\u03AE , \u1F00\u03C0\u03B1\u03C1\u03C7\u03AE , and \u1F00\u03B3\u03CE\u03BD ( with presentations of comedies and tragedies) . In particular , competitions of \u03BA\u1FF6\u03BC\u03BF\u03B9 are attested for the rural Dionysia , and are of great importance for the origin of comedy . Similar elements ( \u03B5\u1F30\u03C3\u03B1\u03B3\u03C9\u03B3\u03AE , \u03C0\u03BF\u03BC\u03C0\u03AE , and \u03BA\u1FF6\u03BC\u03BF\u03C2 ) were also familiar to the audience of the Greater Dionysia . On the individual festivals of Dionysus ( Anthesteria , Lenaia , rural and city Dionysia ) , see Deubner 1932:93\u2013142 ; on the Lenaia and rural Dionysia , ibid. , 123\u2013138 . M\u00F6llendorff 1995:130\u2013131 in the context of lines 195\u2013202 talks of an interplay of two locations and festival times ; still , it is doubtful whether \u0394\u03B9\u03BF\u03BD\u03CD\u03C3\u03B9\u03B1 ( 195 ) refers to the Lenaia . Throughout the play , rites of Dionysus , in particular the Anthesteria , are reworked in pastiche-like fashion ; see Habash 1995 and Fisher 1993 .

#Text=[ back ] 128 .
