Cf . the performative announcement in the future Acharnians 202 : \u1F04\u03BE\u03C9 \u03C4\u1F70 \u03BA\u03B1\u03C4 \u2019 \u1F00\u03B3\u03C1\u03BF\u1F7A\u03C2 \u03B5\u1F30\u03C3\u03B9\u1F7C\u03BD \u0394\u03B9\u03BF\u03BD\u03CD\u03C3\u03B9\u03B1 . The preparatory line 240 : \u03B8\u03CD\u03C3\u03C9\u03BD . . . \u1F10\u03BE\u03AD\u03C1\u03C7\u03B5\u03C4\u03B1\u03B9 has the hero , who has left in line 202 , now return , so that the deme is now to be imagined as the location . For the relation of city and countryside in this passage , see Henrichs 1990:269\u2013270 . Cf . also Henderson 19912:59\u201360 and Habash 1995:560\u2013567 .

#Text=[ back ] 129 . For the Eleusinian dimension of Amphitheos as spondophoros , see Bowie 1993:21 ; for the procession ibid. , 26\u201327 . On the connection of the Lenaia with Eleusis , see Deubner 1932:125\u2013126 . Amphitheos fetches the spondai ( cf. Acharnians 131 , 178 , 186 ) , and Dikaiopolis offers them to the god of the performance as wine ( 199 , 208 ) and song (263ff.) . On the metaphorical usage of spondai in the Acharnians , see Newiger 1957:104\u2013106 .
#Text=[ back ] 130 . Similarly Pickard-Cambridge 1962:146 .

#Text=[ back ] 131 . Cf . above , nn99 and 102 on \u03C3\u03C0\u03AD\u03BD\u03B4\u03C9 , \u03C7\u03AD\u03C9 , and \u1F00\u03C0\u03AC\u03C1\u03C7\u03BF\u03BC\u03B1\u03B9 . In the typical language of ritual , the usual elements are mixed together . Cf . the performative expressions \u1F00\u03C0\u03B1\u03C1\u03BE\u03CE\u03BC\u03B5\u03B8\u03B1 ( Acharnians 244 ) , \u03BA\u03B1\u03C4\u03B1\u03C7\u03AD\u03C9 ( 246 ) , and \u03C3\u03C0\u03BF\u03BD\u03B4\u1F70\u03C2 ( 251 , 268) . In addition , \u03B8\u03CD\u03C3\u03B1\u03BD\u03C4\u03B1 ( 249 ) and the accessories for the \u1F00\u03C0\u03B1\u03C1\u03C7\u03AE as a whole refer to sacrifice . The scholia to Aristophanes Acharnians 242 and 243 seem to relate the text to the phallophoria of the Greater Dionysia rather than to the rural Dionysia .

#Text=[ back ] 132 . Through the instruction \u03B8\u03B5\u1FF6 \u03BC \u2019 \u1F00\u03C0\u1F78 \u03C4\u03BF\u1FE6 \u03C4\u03AD\u03B3\u03BF\u03C5\u03C2 ( 262 ) , she also becomes the internal female \u201C spectator \u201D in the theatrical spectacle , which is at the same time ritual , being presented on stage . The woman \u2019s viewing from the roof is especially connected with the ecstatic ritual of the Adonis procession . See Aristophanes Lysistrata 389 : \u1F45 \u03C4 \u2019 \u1F08\u03B4\u03C9\u03BD\u03B9\u03B1\u03C3\u03BC\u1F78\u03C2 \u03BF\u1F57\u03C4\u03BF\u03C2 \u03BF\u1F51\u03C0\u1F76 \u03C4\u1FF6\u03BD \u03C4\u03B5\u03B3\u1FF6\u03BD with Henderson Lysistrata , 119 ad loc. See also Baudy 1992:34 with n188 . A reason for this may be that the festival of Adonia was thought of as particularly sexual and wild , with the phallus playing a key role ; cf. Baudy 1992:38\u201339 , especially the reference to the begetting of illegitimate children at this festival as a motif in comedy .

#Text=[ back ] 133 . The instruction to her to watch out that nobody snatch and eat her gold jewelry ( \u03C7\u03C1\u03C5\u03C3\u03AF\u03B1 ) could also contain a vulgar double entendre , alluding to her endangered virginity . Cf . Hesychius , s.v. \u03C7\u03C1\u03C5\u03C3\u03AF\u03BF\u03BD\u00B7 \u03C4\u1F78 \u03C4\u1FF6\u03BD \u03C0\u03B1\u03B9\u03B4\u03AF\u03C9\u03BD \u03B1\u1F30\u03B4\u03BF\u1FD6\u03BF\u03BD . See Henderson 19912:131 with reference to Birds 670 ( \u03C7\u03C1\u03C5\u03C3\u03CC\u03BD in the sense of \u03BA\u03C5\u03C3\u03CC\u03C2 ) , who does not however refer to the passage here and its secondary meaning . Cf . Henderson 19912:144 and 178 on \u03C4\u03C1\u03B1\u03B3\u03AE\u03BC\u03B1\u03C4\u03B1 . In contrast to the Thesmophoria ( Thesmophoriazusae 293\u2013294 ) , the slave-girl Thratta is not here excluded from the festival ; she can be snatched and enjoyed ( Acharnians 271\u2013275) .

#Text=[ back ] 134 . On the \u03B5\u1F50\u03C6\u03B7\u03BC\u03AF\u03B1 formula that introduces cultic activity , see Kleinknecht 1937:21n4 with references , 33\u201334 , 38 , and 151 . Cf . also already Acharnians 237\u2013238 . The address concerns the chorus as well as audience , to which the chorus extends itself . Cf . also the servant \u2019s cry before Agathon \u2019s performance and Krytilla \u2019s before the assembly at the Thesmophoria ( Aristophanes Thesmophoriazusae 39 , 295) . On the \u201C we \u201D forms : 244 , \u1F00\u03C0\u03B1\u03C1\u03BE\u03CE\u03BC\u03B5\u03B8\u03B1 ( \u2018 let us begin the aparkh\u00EA \u2019 ) ; at the same time it is in turn a reference to the beginning of the performance as offering that the mini-group and the whole community bring to the god . The \u201C we \u201D in the protasis \u1F10\u1F70\u03BD \u03BC\u03B5\u03B8 \u2019 \u1F21\u03BC\u1FF6\u03BD \u03BE\u03C5\u03BC\u03C0\u03AF\u03B7\u03C2 ( 277 ) also includes the assembled polis as a collective , especially as Dikaiopolis before this repeatedly emphasizes the fact that he wants to drink alone ( 199 , 251\u2013252 , 268\u2013269) . The audience thus imperceptibly becomes an accomplice to this peace agreement .

#Text=[ back ] 135 . Kugelmeier 1996:153 even thinks of \u201C lustige Tanzbewegungen \u201D [ \u201C comic dance movements \u201D ] . In comedy , a choral dance quite often leads to a solo dance : one has only to think of Philokleon \u2019s ecstatic dance at the end of the Wasps . In general one may also characterize the body language of the entering comasts as choral kinetics , that is , as dance in the broader sense of the term .

#Text=[ back ] 136 . Dionysus brings together all these concepts . The idea of worshiping for peace through communal drinking , which symbolizes peace and sacrifice , is likewise quite concrete . On a bone tablet from Olbia ( SEG 28 [ 1972]:660 , p. 192 ) there appears next to the name of Dionysus the inscription \u0395\u0399\u03A1\u0397\u039D\u0397 \u03A0\u039F\u039B\u0395\u039C\u039F\u03A3 among other things . This ambivalence is also of great importance for the Acharnians . Dionysus is peace , to be sure , but peace cannot be wholly subsumed under Dionysus , because the god also carries within him an element of Ares . For Ares and Dionysus , see Lonnoy 1985 and Bierl 1991:154\u2013157 .

#Text=[ back ] 137 . Together with the painting of the generic picture one may also think of Dikaiopolis \u2019 mimic accompaniment . Even the idea of the rape ( cf. now also Olson Acharnians , 150 ad 272\u2013275 ) of a wood-stealing slave-girl bears a possible similarity to the fruit thieves , who according to Sosibios are simple pranksters ( \u1F10\u03BC\u03B9\u03BC\u03B5\u1FD6\u03C4\u03BF \u03B3\u03AC\u03C1 \u03C4\u03B9\u03C2 \u1F10\u03BD \u03B5\u1F50\u03C4\u03B5\u03BB\u03B5\u1FD6 \u03C4\u1FC7 \u03BB\u03AD\u03BE\u03B5\u03B9 \u03BA\u03BB\u03AD\u03C0\u03C4\u03BF\u03BD\u03C4\u03AC\u03C2 \u03C4\u03B9\u03BD\u03B1\u03C2 \u1F40\u03C0\u03CE\u03C1\u03B1\u03BD , Athenaeus 621d) . This connection was already thought of by van Leeuwen ( Acharnians , 51 ad 272 ) and more recently also by Habash 1995:566n27 . On the mimic and dance-like presentation of meat-stealing , see Pollux 4.105 . Aristophanes criticizes this form of cheap farce ( cf. Clouds 537\u2013560 , Wasps 57\u201363 , Peace 739\u2013751 , Frogs 1\u201318 ) , but himself constantly uses thieving , sex , scatology , and ribald sexual expressions in his comedies in order to raise the laughter essential to comedy from his audience ; cf. Halliwell 1991a:290 . The proto-comedy of Dikaiopolis would accordingly form a hymn with mimic interludes by the \u1F10\u03BE\u03AC\u03C1\u03C7\u03C9\u03BD , though here he of course performs without a chorus . From this one-man show a scene using actors could have arisen , in which two or three players perform small comic skits of this type , being constantly interrupted by the songs and hymns of a k\u00F4mos-chorus , with a leader who strikes up the song . [ back ] Even the sympotic conclusion is combined with allusions to the sexual sphere : Dionysus is summoned to drink with Dikaiopolis ; if he does so , he can also slurp a bowl of peace the next morning for his hangover\u2014the notion of cunnilingus also lies behind this . On \u03C4\u03C1\u03CD\u03B2\u03BB\u03B9\u03BF\u03BD cf. Henderson 19912:143 and 186 with reference to Peace 716 : \u1F45\u03C3\u03BF\u03BD \u1FE5\u03BF\u03C6\u03AE\u03C3\u03B5\u03B9 \u03B6\u03C9\u03BC\u1F78\u03BD \u1F21\u03BC\u03B5\u03C1\u1FF6\u03BD \u03C4\u03C1\u03B9\u1FF6\u03BD ( but Olson Peace , 214 ad loc. now argues against this interpretation) . Sommerstein Acharnians , 169 ad 278 correctly notes that \u03B5\u1F30\u03C1\u03AE\u03BD\u03B7\u03C2 here comes as a surprise instead of \u201C soup \u201D (\u03B6\u03C9\u03BC\u03CC\u03C2) . For breakfast ( cf. \u1F15\u03C9\u03B8\u03B5\u03BD ) in this vulgar sense , see Henderson 19912:186 . On the chauvinistic character of the song , see Silk 1980:132\u2013133 . The equally strongly performative song of the Frogs ( Aristophanes Frogs 209\u2013267 ) forms a similar k\u00F4mos procession , in which only the transition into another comic world is shown on stage . There , wine-drinking at the Khoes/Khytroi during the Anthesteria is also reworked . The Frogs strike up a song that the hungover crowd sings at the Khytroi ( \u1F41 \u03BA\u03C1\u03B1\u03B9\u03C0\u03B1\u03BB\u03CC\u03BA\u03C9\u03BC\u03BF\u03C2 . . . \u03BB\u03B1\u1FF6\u03BD \u1F44\u03C7\u03BB\u03BF\u03C2 , Frogs 218\u2013219b with Dover Frogs , 223\u2013224 ad loc.) . The solitary celebration and drinking are generally reminiscent of the eerie ritual of drinking in isolation at the Khoes with which the Acharnians ends . Cf . Acharnians 1068ff . The priest of Dionysus , the representative of the god , really does become his \u03C3\u03C5\u03BC\u03C0\u03CC\u03C4\u03B7\u03C2 ( cf. the invitation at 1087) . In the end Dikaiopolis becomes the victor in the Khoes competition ; as prize he receives a wineskin and enjoys himself with two whores .

#Text=[ back ] 138 . Redundancy and repetition are characteristic of the language of cult . The typical doublings are particularly apparent here : \u03B5\u1F50\u03C6\u03B7\u03BC\u03B5\u1FD6\u03C4\u03B5 , \u03B5\u1F50\u03C6\u03B7\u03BC\u03B5\u1FD6\u03C4\u03B5 ( Acharnians 237 , 241 ) and the refrain-like cultic shout \u03A6\u03B1\u03BB\u1FC6\u03C2 \u03A6\u03B1\u03BB\u1FC6\u03C2 ( 271 , 276) . On the repeated invocation , cf. Pratinas TrGF I 4 F 3.16 : \u03B8\u03C1\u03B9\u03B1\u03BC\u03B2\u03BF\u03B4\u03B9\u03B8\u03CD\u03C1\u03B1\u03BC\u03B2\u03B5 = fragment 708 , 15 PMG : \u03B8\u03C1\u03AF\u03B1\u03BC\u03B2\u03B5 \u03B4\u03B9\u03B8\u03CD\u03C1\u03B1\u03BC\u03B2\u03B5 ; Aristophanes Frogs 316\u2013317 , 325 , 342 : \u1F3C\u03B1\u03BA\u03C7 \u2019 \u1F66 \u1F3C\u03B1\u03BA\u03C7\u03B5 ; Aristophanes Thesmophoriazusae 993b : \u1F66 \u0395\u1F54\u03B9 \u2019 , \u0395\u1F54\u03B9 \u2019 , \u03B5\u1F50\u03BF\u1FD6 ( with Henrichs 1982:230n164) . West 1974:23 and Nagy 1979:242\u2013243 point out that the noun \u1F34\u03B1\u03BC\u03B2\u03BF\u03C2 , like \u03B4\u03B9\u03B8\u03CD\u03C1\u03B1\u03BC\u03B2\u03BF\u03C2 , \u03B8\u03C1\u03AF\u03B1\u03BC\u03B2\u03BF\u03C2 , and \u1F34\u03B8\u03C5\u03BC\u03B2\u03BF\u03C2 in the cult of Dionysus , refers to a person or type of dance . The Phales shout , which is in iambic form , belongs to precisely this style of mocking speech . Repetitions in vocabulary are found in the following passages : \u03C3\u03C0\u03BF\u03BD\u03B4\u03AC\u03C2\u2014Acharnians 251 , 268 ; \u1F40\u03C1\u03B8\u03CC\u03C2\u2014243 , 259 ; \u03C6\u03B1\u03BB\u03BB\u03CC\u03C2\u2014243 , 260 ; \u03C3\u03C4\u03C1\u03B1\u03C4\u03B9\u1FB6\u03C2 \u1F00\u03C0\u03B1\u03BB\u03BB\u03B1\u03C7\u03B8\u03AD\u03BD\u03C4\u03B1 , 251\u2014\u03BC\u03B1\u03C7\u1FF6\u03BD | \u03BA\u03B1\u1F76 \u039B\u03B1\u03BC\u03AC\u03C7\u03C9\u03BD \u1F00\u03C0\u03B1\u03BB\u03BB\u03B1\u03B3\u03B5\u03AF\u03C2 , 269\u2013270 ( cf. already \u03C0\u03BF\u03BB\u03AD\u03BC\u03BF\u03C5 \u03BA\u03B1\u1F76 \u03BA\u03B1\u03BA\u1FF6\u03BD \u1F00\u03C0\u03B1\u03BB\u03BB\u03B1\u03B3\u03B5\u1F76\u03C2 , 201 ) ; \u03C0\u03C1\u03CC\u03B2\u03B1\u03B9\u03BD\u03B5 257\u2014\u03C0\u03C1\u03CC\u03B2\u03B1 262 . The above-mentioned elements of ritual style do not , however , exclude the possibility that the song was composed following literary standards . For an evaluation , see Silk 1980:131\u2013136 , who categorizes this song , despite his tendency generally to relativize the artistic quality of Aristophanic poetry , as \u201C low lyrics plus \u201D (133) .

#Text=[ back ] 139 . The announcement \u1F10\u03B3\u1F7C \u03B4 \u2019 \u1F00\u03BA\u03BF\u03BB\u03BF\u03C5\u03B8\u1FF6\u03BD \u1F84\u03C3\u03BF\u03BC\u03B1\u03B9 \u03C4\u1F78 \u03C6\u03B1\u03BB\u03BB\u03B9\u03BA\u03CC\u03BD ( 261 ) corresponds to the performative future typical of such songs ; cf. , for instance , the formula \u1F00\u03B5\u03AF\u03C3\u03BF\u03BC\u03B1\u03B9 in the Homeric hymns above , n110 .

#Text=[ back ] 140 . Cf . the emphasis on the breaking of sexual norms ( pederasty and adultery [ 265 ] , rape [ 271\u2013275 ] ) and nocturnal gangs of young men (264\u2013265) . The elements are clearly reminiscent of the comastic activity of the Athenian Ithyphalloi and Autolekythoi described in Demosthenes 54.14 . The comic hero reactualizes practices in ritual action that can be interpreted as the remnants of archaic aristocratic initiation . He thereby undergoes the rejuvenation characteristic of it .

#Text=[ back ] 141 . Similarly M\u00F6llendorff 1995:131 with n57 and now also Olson Acharnians , 146 ad 257\u2013258 . The expression used by Semos , \u03B5\u1F30\u03C2 \u03C4\u1F78 \u03B8\u03AD\u03B1\u03C4\u03C1\u03BF\u03BD \u03BB\u03AD\u03B3\u03BF\u03BD\u03C4\u03B5\u03C2 ( Athenaeus 622b ) , is reflected in the expression \u1F15\u03BA\u03C4\u1FF3 \u03C3 \u2019 \u1F14\u03C4\u03B5\u03B9 \u03C0\u03C1\u03BF\u03C3\u03B5\u1FD6\u03C0\u03BF\u03BD \u03B5\u1F30\u03C2 | \u03C4\u1F78\u03BD \u03B4\u1FC6\u03BC\u03BF\u03BD \u1F10\u03BB\u03B8\u1F7C\u03BD \u1F04\u03C3\u03BC\u03B5\u03BD\u03BF\u03C2 ( 266\u2013267 ) , which has two senses . The surface meaning is that Dikaiopolis , after five years , has at long last returned to his native deme ; \u03B4\u1FC6\u03BC\u03BF\u03C2 can of course also be understood as the people , assembled in the theater . In the intertwining of places and times , he now performs in the procession in front of the people and in his hymn addresses Dionysos-Phales , who is present in the here and now of the theater . The verb \u03B5\u1F30\u03C3\u03AD\u03C1\u03C7\u03B5\u03C3\u03B8\u03B1\u03B9 means among other things the entry of chorus or player onto the stage ; cf. e.g. Plato Republic 580b and Xenophon Anabasis 6.1.9 . The verb is used in the same sense in the opening description of the Ithyphalloi above ( Athenaeus 622b) . Dikaiopolis too has entered the orchestra and now addresses the audience . The manner of expression is naturally kept consciously ambivalent ; cf. the announcement already in line 202 , where \u03B5\u1F30\u03C3\u03B9\u03CE\u03BD refers both to going in behind the stage and to the future entry in lines 237ff . For \u1F44\u03C7\u03BB\u03BF\u03C2 in the sense of the mass of citizens of the polis , cf. also Aristophanes Frogs 219b and Demokhares of Athens FGrHist 75 F 2 ( quoted in Athenaeus 253c ) , describing the Ithyphalloi who greeted Demetrios Poliorketes in Athens ( . . . \u1F30\u03B8\u03CD\u03C6\u03B1\u03BB\u03BB\u03BF\u03B9 \u03BC\u03B5\u03C4 \u2019 \u1F40\u03C1\u03C7\u03AE\u03C3\u03B5\u03C9\u03C2 \u03BA\u03B1\u1F76 \u1FA0\u03B4\u1FC6\u03C2 \u1F00\u03C0\u03AE\u03BD\u03C4\u03C9\u03BD \u03B1\u1F50\u03C4\u1FF7 \u03BA\u03B1\u1F76 \u1F10\u03C6\u03B9\u03C3\u03C4\u03AC\u03BC\u03B5\u03BD\u03BF\u03B9 \u03BA\u03B1\u03C4\u1F70 \u2020 \u03C4\u03BF\u1F7A\u03C2 \u1F44\u03C7\u03BB\u03BF\u03C5\u03C2 \u1F96\u03B4\u03BF\u03BD \u1F40\u03C1\u03C7\u03BF\u03CD\u03BC\u03B5\u03BD\u03BF\u03B9 \u03BA\u03B1\u1F76 \u1F10\u03C0\u1FB4\u03B4\u03BF\u03BD\u03C4\u03B5\u03C2 . . . ) ; for \u1F44\u03C7\u03BB\u03BF\u03C2 used of a crowd of maenads , cf. Euripides Bacchae 117 and 1058 . On the quasi-choral element in this song , see also Parker 1997:128 : \u201C One might speculate that this is a solo , not a choral , hymn-form , but the fact that Dicaeopolis sings it as a solo does not prove that . In his miniature festival , he may be representing a choir , just as his daughter represents a whole troup of basket-carriers and his wife an \u1F44\u03C7\u03BB\u03BF\u03C2 . \u201D

#Text=[ back ] 142 . Cf . the adverb \u03BA\u03B5\u03C7\u03B1\u03C1\u03B9\u03C3\u03BC\u03AD\u03BD\u03C9\u03C2 ( 248 ) , which refers to the \u03C7\u03AC\u03C1\u03B9\u03C2 of the performance and the pleasure of the god . The song is furthermore a parodos within a parodos .

#Text=[ back ] 143 . According to Warning 1976:283\u2013287 , the purposeful plot or sujet is , to use terminology derived from a distinction drawn by E. v. Hartmann , an \u201C anderweitige Handlung \u201D [ \u201C an additional action/plot ( in another time or place ) \u201D ] , on which the paradigmatic comic elements , the \u201C komischen Handlungen \u201D ( Hartmann 1887:334 ) [ \u201C comic actions \u201D ] , \u201C gleichsam parasit\u00E4r operieren \u201D [ \u201C simultaneously operate in parasitic fashion \u201D ] ( Warning 1976:287) . According to Warning ( 323 ) , the commedia dell\u2019arte , with which Aristophanes has much in common in terms of occupying a central position between literature and open ritual form , is an exemplary instance of \u201C wie die schematische anderweitige Handlung als Erm\u00F6glichungsstruktur der eigentlich komischen Handlungen fungiert \u201D [ \u201C how the schematic other action or plot functions as enabling structure of the actual comic actions \u201D ] . Here , as there , we must speak of secondary improvisation .

#Text=[ back ] 144 . Despite \u201C komischer Z\u00FCge \u201D [ \u201C comic traits \u201D ] Kleinknecht 1937:53n5 , among others , does not see a parody in this \u201C schlicht-volkst\u00FCmliche Opfergebet und Phallophorenlied \u201D [ \u201C simple popular sacrificial prayer and song of Phallophoroi \u201D ] ; cf. also Prato 1987:216 . Similarly , Horn 1970:57 views the song as \u201C ernstes Gebetspastiche \u201D [ \u201C serious prayer pastiche \u201D ] based on popular forms . Horn appears to be on the right track , even though he is chiefly thinking ( as does previous scholarship ) of the problem of written models . The distinction between serious and not serious does not present itself if one uses rituality as a point of departure , since in the religious domain the nonserious , the comic , and the offensive are interwoven with the phallic procession .

#Text=[ back ] 145 . The \u201C schw\u00E4chere Ankl\u00E4nge \u201D [ \u201C rather weak reminiscences\u201D]\u2014according to Kugelmeier 1996:154 the command at Acharnians 253 , \u1F04\u03B3 \u2019 , \u1F66 \u03B8\u03CD\u03B3\u03B1\u03C4\u03B5\u03C1 an \u1F00\u03BD\u03AC\u03B3\u03B5\u03C4 \u2019 , and the content of Acharnians 257 , \u03C0\u03C1\u03CC\u03B2\u03B1\u03B9\u03BD\u03B5 , \u03BA\u1F00\u03BD \u03C4\u1F64\u03C7\u03BB\u1FF3 \u03C6\u03C5\u03BB\u03AC\u03C4\u03C4\u03B5\u03C3\u03B8\u03B1\u03B9 , are somewhat reminiscent of \u03B4\u03B9\u1F70 \u03BC\u03AD\u03C3\u03BF\u03C5 \u03B2\u03B1\u03B4\u03AF\u03B6\u03B5\u03B9\u03BD in lines 1 and 4 of the song of the Ithyphalloi ( fragment 851a PMG)\u2014are typically motivated by the characteristic performative style of speech . Accordingly , the much more obvious connection between Acharnians 243 , 259 and fragment 851a.3 ( \u1F40\u03C1\u03B8\u03CC\u03C2 ; cf. on this Csapo 1997:284 ) and the relationship of the themes is based on the common nature of their occasion and genre . The reference to \u03C4\u03AE\u03BD\u03B4\u03B5 \u03C4\u1F74\u03BD \u03C0\u03BF\u03BC\u03C0\u03AE\u03BD ( Acharnians 248 ) is comparable to the expression \u03C4\u03AC\u03BD\u03B4\u03B5 \u03BC\u03BF\u1FE6\u03C3\u03B1\u03BD ( fragment 851b.1 PMG ) ; deixis of the here and now is a sign of performance , which refers in self-referential form , using demonstrative pronouns , at one moment to the cultic activity and movement of the procession , at another to the singing . In the same way , the similar syntactic form of Acharnians 263\u2013270 and fragment 851b with direct address in the vocative , predicate containing a performative verb in the first person , and subsequent elaboration using circumstantial participles , as well as the subsequent \u03B3\u03AC\u03C1 ( Acharnians 271 and fragment 851a.3 ) , belongs to cultic language .

#Text=[ back ] 146 . The only thing that is roughly reminiscent of a reflection ( Acharnians 271ff . : \u03C0\u03BF\u03BB\u03BB\u1FF7 \u03B3\u03AC\u03C1 \u1F10\u03C3\u03B8 \u2019 \u1F25\u03B4\u03B9\u03BF\u03BD . . . ) is actually an order to enact the idea . The construction using a comparative in the neuter singular ( generally as a question \u03C4\u03AF \u03BA\u03AC\u03BB\u03BB\u03B9\u03BF\u03BD ; ) with hortatory sense also appears to belong to the language of cult : cf. Euripides Bacchae 877\u2013881 and 897\u2013901 in the traditional form and Dodds 19602:186\u2013188 ad Euripidse Bacchae 877\u2013881 ( contra Blake \u2019s conjecture , recently accepted again by Seaford 1996:218\u2013219 ad Euripides Bacchae 877\u2013881) . Cf . the prosodion Pindar fragment 89a S.-M . and Aristophanes Knights 1264ff . in connection with the performative activity of the chorus \u2019 own singing ( \u03C4\u03AF \u03BA\u03AC\u03BB\u03BB\u03B9\u03BF\u03BD . . . \u1F00\u03B5\u1FD6\u03C3\u03B1\u03B9 , or \u1F00\u03B5\u03AF\u03B4\u03B5\u03B9\u03BD ) , so that Aristophanes makes an intertextual connection to Pindar ; cf. Fraenkel 1962:204\u2013207 .

#Text=[ back ] 147 . Particularly in the song of the Frogs ( Aristophanes Frogs 209\u2013267 ) and in the procession song of the chorus of initiates as they enter ( Frogs 316\u2013459 ) , as well as in the parodos of Euripides \u2019 Bacchae ( Bacchae 64\u2013169 ) , the connection of the performative and the cultic ( k\u00F4mos and Iakkhos-\u03C0\u03BF\u03BC\u03C0\u03AE ) occurs in precisely the same way as in the song of the Phallophoroi ( fragment 851b PMG ) ; in particular , the short strophes directed at Demeter ( Frogs 385a\u2013393 ) and Iakkhos ( Frogs 398\u2013413 ) are likewise ( following the division made by Radermacher Fr\u00F6sche and Coulon ) sung in lyric iambics ; the purely performative transition to the Iakkhos song with the command to now invoke this god ( Frogs 394\u2013397 ) uses the rhythm ia|lec ith||2ia ith ( according to the scheme of Dover Frogs , 245 ) , which is distantly reminiscent of the Ithyphalloi . For parallels between these passages , see also Silk 1980:145 . Radermacher Fr\u00F6sche , 190 ad 354\u2013371 suggests that an authentic Eleusinian song of initiates functioned as the model for the strophes ; Fraenkel 1962:201\u2013202 connects the rhythm with traditional cult songs , while Zimmermann I 1985:130n51 connects that of the Iakkhos invocation particularly with Acharnians 263\u2013279 and the Phallophoroi .
